text:
This is my recipe and I am thrilled you all are loving it!  Here is the recipe for Bill Echols Taco Seasoning.  It really makes this recipe.
1 tablespoon chili powder 
1/4 teaspoon garlic powder 
1/4 teaspoon onion powder 
1/4 teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes 
1/4 teaspoon dried oregano 
1/2 teaspoon paprika 
1 1/2 teaspoons ground cumin 
1 teaspoon sea salt 
1 teaspoon black pepper

text:
I wasn't sure about making this as I hate beer and no one in my house drinks it.  I also don't like very spicy foods. However, I took a chance and used Heineken for this recipe as well as the taco seasoning and tomatoes with chilies and the soup was DELICIOUS. I couldn't detect a "beer" taste in the soup at all and found it to be a bit on the mild side. Everyone in my family loved it. I made another pot for tailgating - it was the most popular dish - everyone wanted seconds and the recipe. It's easy to put together.  You could easily substitute chicken broth, as many people have, and leave off the cheese and sour cream (or use reduced calorie products)and use baked chips to make it more diet friendly.  I put mine in the crock pot before going to bed.  The chicken was frozen when I put it in the pot.  The next morning, it was so well cooked, I didn't have to take it out and shred it.  All I had to do is "grab" each breast a couple of times with tongs and the chicken just fell apart.  Then I gave it a good stir and that's all it took to shred it.

text:
I brought this to my Texas Holdem Poker nite.  Everyone liked it.  Im on a budget of 20 dollars.  So I only used 4 chicken breast, doubled the recipe, added water no beer or chicken broth ( the chicken makes its own in the water) doubled everything else. You need large crockpot.  Just threw everything in the crockpot.  Took chicken out about 4 or 5  hours later cut it up threw back in.  Also added a little cumin and chilli powder next time I will add a little cilantro.  Served it with nacho chips.  Sour cream and cheese would have been good with it though.  Served a crowd and was under my 20 dollar budget. And even after cutting the chiken back there was still a good amount in it.

text:
People are really getting on my nerves saying "Leave out the beer!" No, do not leave out the beer. USE THE CORRECT KIND OF BEER!!! You need to use a DARK, MEXICAN BEER, not your husband's Natty Light, Miller Lite, Colt45 or whatever it is people have been using. This is an excellent recipe, I urge people to not leave out "key ingredients".

text:
Very good!  I cooked this for 10 hours instead of 5 (since I was at work) & it turned out great.  I followed advice from other reviewers & added 1 tsp garlic powder, 1/2 tsp cummin & 4 T taco seasoning.  Used pinto beans instead of chili beans and added a full 28 oz can of diced tomatoes.  I also added about a teaspoon of sugar at the end - I felt the beer gave it a weird bite or bitter taste.  Next time I'll skip the beer and just add chicken broth in it's place.   Defintely needs a dollop of sour cream and shredded cheddar, but overall a keeper recipe!

text:
Five stars for quick, easy, and tasty.  Plus, I already had everything in the house.  I left out the beer and used one cup homemade chicken broth instead.  I used two chicken breasts and that seemed like a good amount.  I also used fire-roasted frozen corn from Trader Joe's (instead of canned).  Garnished with light sour cream and fresh cilantro, and served with tortilla strips for dipping!  Yum!

text:
This is a great recipe, low in fat and full of fiber.  Yummy!!! It made alot and would be great when you have guests over for dinner.  I did make a couple of changes based on previous reviews.  I left out the onion because my family doesn't like it.  I left out the beer and added 1 can of cream of chicken soup and 1/2 cup of chicken broth (both FF). I used lowfat sourcream and reduced fat mexican cheese and lowfat tortilla chips when serving the soup.

text:
If I could give this recipe more than five stars, I totally would. It is AMAZING. I will say that a key to making this soup so good is using a homemade taco seasoning. Cuts down on the salt, and boosts the flavor. I used three tablespoons of homemade taco seasoning which happened to be the perfect amount. Plus, rinse your canned vegetables/beans! This will cut back on the salt taste that you would normally notice. You want to taste the seasoning, not the salt! The only things I changed on this recipe is adding worchestershire sauce AND I used a large can of tomato paste, in place of the tomato sauce, and only adding 8 oz. of water. It made it thicker than sauce but the tomato flavor was much richer. I used two large cans of cooked chicken which was a good amount. My husband RAVED about this soup, and he's not much of a soup eater. He had two helpings. And I was so taken aback by the flavor of this soup. I paired it with the Mexican Cornbread 2 from this site. Really complimented each other well. Thank you times infinity for the person who shared this recipe. I look forward to the following day's leftovers!

text:
Really Good!  1 key ingredient is to use MEXICAN Tomato sauce (found in the Mexican aisle at the grocery store).  It adds SO much more flavor then regular tomato sauce and definitely gives it a kick.  I used the recommend taco spices and Corona.  I only had 1 can of Rotel so I left the other one out totally.  I also drained both the chili beans & black beans which is why it my soup ended up so thick (which was fine by us).... The next day, we used the shredded chicken (there was a lot) for tacos and the day after I made enchiladas out of it which were awesome (dipped corn tortillas in warm cream of mushroom soup, piled on some of the chicken mixture, shredded cheese and green onion.  Rolled and put in baking dish.  Poured 1 can of red enchilada sauce over dish, covered with cheese.  Wrapped dish in foil and baked at 350 for 30 minutes (20 covered, 10 uncovered). Really Delicious :)... And we still have a ton of chicken left over!

text:
I would actually rate this about a 4.5....I thought it was a great EASY meal, but my husband said it was just ok.  Suprisingly enough as we both very much enjoy beer, I think it was the "beer" taste he (and I) didn't care for.  I did use a Sam Adams Summer Ale which is a pretty flavorful beer, so perhaps that was the problem.  I will try a black and tan next time and if the "beer taste" stil exists, I'll switch to chicken broth.  I followed the recipe, except I used kidney beans and only 3 chicken breasts (it was plenty of chicken!).  The best part of this soup is that the prep that took the longest was dicing an onion!  Thanks for the recipe!

*Update*  I just thoroughly ENJOYED a bowl of leftover soup...the beer taste was much less noticable reheated....it was outstanding!!!

*UPDATE 2*  I made this the second time using chicken broth in place of the beer and what a difference!  We both thoroughly enjoyed it and the leftovers are amazing.

text:
This was absolutely delicious and easy!  My husband ate two bowls, and would have eaten three but was too full!  I cut the chicken into bite sized pieces (schedule did not allow time for shredding tonight), and added fresh chopped cilantro.  I spiced the mix up with two tablespoons of chili powder, a teaspoon of cumin, and a teaspoon of cayenne pepper. Cooked for 8 hours on low. Thanks so much for sharing!  Added 5/6/11:  I've made this so many times, I think I've perfected it by adding more cumin, only one can black beans (skip the chili beans) and subbing one of the cans of Rotel for a can of zucchini with tomato.  I also add a small diced summer squash for even more veg.  This freezes well, too.

text:
Absolutely delicious!  Wish I could give it MORE than 5 stars!!!  I made the recommended Bill Echol's taco seasoning, and put all of it in the soup.  Used a bottle of Shiner Bock for the beer.  Did not need to remove the chicken breasts after the 5 hours, just used two forks in the crock pot and they shredded easily. Served each bowl topped with fresh cilantro, and had a 'topping bar' that everyone used to top their soup as they liked - tortilla chips, diced tomatoes, diced avocado, sour cream, grated cheese, and fresh lime wedges to squeeze over the soup! CanNOT say enough about it!  Very healthy, ingredients were inexpensive, and the whole bowl had a great fresh taste with the cilantro and fresh lime, a creaminess from the sour cream, crunch from the crunched up chips, and gooeyness from the cheese!

text:
Good recipe. I like to sear the chicken before putting it in the slow cooker - it adds a lot of flavor. If you don't like beer, use an equal amount of chicken broth. Just watch the other salt that you add. I drain and rinse my beans, always. I don't use premade taco seasoning - I just add cumin, chili powder, Mexican oregano to taste. Fresh, chopped garlic is an absolute must, 2 or 3 cloves. A little lime juice and/or cilantro are nice additions at the end.

text:
This is one of the BEST recipes that I have gotten off of this site!  I have been looking for a chicken tortilla soup that tastes like the one I order at the Islands Restaurant.  This is it!  Instead of the beer, I use chicken broth.  I use 2 cans of diced tomatoes and 2 cans of Ro-tel. I used all kidney beans because I like them.  One time I substituted one tablespoon of chili powder for the taco seasoning and added a few "tamed jalapena peppers in a jar."  I added shredded mozzarella cheese to thicken it.  Delish!  I won't be ordering this soup at The Islands anymore.  Thank you RaisinKane aka Patti!

text:
Very good!  I can't believe I haven't rated this.  We have this almost religiously.  The beans are easy to substitute with anything you have on hand.  It's also easy to cook on the stove in a dutch oven... It never needs to be cooked as long as it says... or it can be cooked longer!  Very versatile.  Yuengling Light has been my beer of choice lately, but I've used Heineken and Dos Equis with good results -- I think I've used Miller Lite at times, too.  With this last batch, I doubled all the canned ingredients (added an extra can of cream corn), the beer, and tripled Bill Echols' Taco Seasoning I -- it was awesome but too spicy for the kids.  So, the next day (today), I added two more cans of corn, a can of light red kidney beans, two cans of vegetarian beans packed in tomato sauce and another batch of Bill Echols' seasoning (minus the pepper flakes) -- YUM!  The kids really enjoyed the less spicy version, and I'm enjoying a super cheap meal that has fed us multiple times.  As I said, it is VERY versatile. =]

EXCELLENT, EXCELLENT!  I didn't have time to do this in the slow cooker, so I adjusted for the stove-top. Adding shredded cheese and a dolup of sour cream after poured into a bowl is a MUST.  This one will become a winter staple at my house.

None
text:
WHOA! As is, it's a zero-star recipe. It gets five stars IF (1) the two cans of tomatoes/green chilies are substituted with two cans diced tomatoes and one can diced green chilies, (2) LOW-SODIUM taco seasoning is used (3) it’s boiled vs "slow cooked." It’s also good with or without chicken!  

For the boiled version: saute the onions; add everything else including already-cooked chicken. Preferred frozen corn, a little healthier (reduces the sodium), when I could eat it. Now, I just add another type of bean. The type of beer doesn't make a difference. But, it DOES need the beer (learned the hard way). Boil to evaporate the alcohol. It's so light and refreshing!   

About the cans of tomatoes and green chilies: Too much chilies taste, and it majorly dragged down the flavor. Same with slow cooking for SEVEN hours. Yuck. You cook away all the flavor, and the beans were mush. We threw it out.   

We look forward to this about once a month—year round!

Tasty!  I used a can of pinto beans instead of black beans (didn't have any).  Also, 15 oz. tomato sauce.  1 3/4 c. frozen corn, 1 can mexican diced tomatos and 1 can diced tomatoes, also the chili beans and this taco seasoning:  Here is the recipe for Bill Echols Taco Seasoning. It really makes this recipe. 1 tablespoon chili powder 1/4 teaspoon garlic powder 1/4 teaspoon onion powder 1/4 teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes 1/4 teaspoon dried oregano 1/2 teaspoon paprika 1 1/2 teaspoons ground cumin 1 teaspoon sea salt 1 teaspoon black pepper.(used only 2 tsp . chili powder in the seasoning though)
also 1 Rolling Rock beer.  Delicious!

text:
Excellent!  We loved this recipe and will try again.  Used beer and it turned out great.  I've cooked with beer many times and it's not a taste issue at all once it's cooked, it's about the ingredients of the beer working in the recipe.  PERFECT for the cooler night ahead as we go into winter time. 

UPDATE 12/7/2013 : This has been a cold night soup, a Thanksgiving soup, and a company's coming tonight soup.  SOOOOOOOO easy, sooooooo good, this is a must in our recipe book.  To keep down the calories (it's already pretty healthy) use a low fat sour cream, less cheese, and white corn tortilla instead of chips as the sides/toppers.

Yum! Yum! I had frozen corn instead of canned.  I didn't use the tomato sauce because I did not want a tomato base. I have made 4-5 different kinds of "taco" soups... this was delicious, but after 5 hours, my chicken was starting to get overcooked (a little mushy) (maybe my cooker cooks hotter ??). And, by slow cooking, the lid is on the entire time, and I don't think the alcohol gets to cook off. I could taste the beer too much. When I make again, I will use broth or stock instead of the beer and cook for only 4-5 hours with my slow cooker.

This recipe was soooo EASY to make. I made it twice, but because the first time I made it I just used a Michelob Ultra that was sitting in my fridge from a road race that I was trying to get rid of and it ended up giving the soup a funky taste. NO FUNKY TASTE WITH HIGHER QUALITY BEER! Entire family loved it.

text:
This is a great recipe.  The only change - I used Trader Joe's frozen fire roasted corn instead of canned corn.  I highly recommend using Bill Echols taco seasoning recipe (as the author suggests) on this site instead of a pre-packaged taco seasoning.    Garnishes I'd recommend in addition to the standard chips, cheddar and sour cream are lime wedges and fresh cilantro.  A squeeze of lime and a scattering of fresh cilantro when serving really adds brightness and brings out all the wonderful flavors.   Family loves this.

This turned out great!  I didn't have all the right ingredients because I had planned on a different dinner tonight.  The only substitutions I had to make was cajun seasoning + cumin instead of taco seasoning.  I had 1 can of diced tomatoes with chilis and 1 plain. I sauted the onion in olive oil with some minced garlic before adding to the crock pot.  I didn't have any corn, but will make sure to pick some up next time I make this.  Turned out awsome, my husband went back for seconds.  Thanks for sharing!  To sarah, some of the other reviewers mentioned using chicken stock in place of the beer.

This is good.  I made it with ground beef instead of chicken only cause I needed something quicker and on hand.  It is just like the slow cooker taco soup.  I omitted the corn.  I used kidney beans, pinto beans and the black beans, all drained and chicken broth instead of the beer.  I used one can of diced tomatos and discovered it was Italian style which I think added even more flavor and then added a small can of diced green chilies.  Everything else I did the same.  It is like chili but I think better.  I cooked it on the stove instead of the slow cooker and it was done in less than a half hour. Tastes great the next day also.

text:
This recipe is, to put it simply, awesome. I've always made it with the homemade taco seasoning referenced by other reviewers so I can't say how it would taste with the packaged stuff from the grocery store. With the homemade stuff, it comes out delicious and has met with rave reviews every time that I've made it.

I've made this 3 times now and the last time doubled the seasoning to kick things up a notch which was appreciated by all but two of my children who don't like spicy. I definitely recommend this recipe!

Oh, and I put in 1 fewer chicken breasts than called for - as-written we felt that the quantity of chicken once shredded was a little much. If you like a meaty soup then you'll like it as-written; however, we like it better with a little less meat. Excellent recipe!!

text:
I love the simplicity of this recipe. It's rare that I can follow a recipe verbatim due to some dietary requirements in my household, and that was the case here. But I didn't have to change much. I made Bill Echols' taco seasoning as is recommended in the reviews. I used fresh roasted and diced Hatch green chiles and diced up 3 tomatoes (subbing this for the Rotel). Made my own black beans and used frozen corn. The beer I used was a Sam Adams Oktoberfest, and I only used 2 boneless skinless chicken breasts. The two breasts totaled 1.45 lbs. of chicken and that was plenty.

It was really easy to make and came out quite good. If I make it again though I might skip the corn and add a blend of masa and chicken broth.

text:
Hmmmm, and very unexpected. Am not too fond of beans but I absolutely LOVED this recipe. It was too large for my slow cooker so I made it in the oven, 3hrs at 350, then in the fridge overnight, next day I cut up the chicken and back in the oven at 350 for 2 hours. 
In Québec, we can't find tomatoes with chilies so I put in about 10-15 slices of jalapenos, chopped finely and used one pack of Old ElPasso taco seasoning and replaced the chili beans with baby red beans bacause again, I couldn't find them... served with Kraft Mexican cheese, low fat sour cream and tortillas.... de-li-cious ... a sure bet after a long day outside playing in the snow !!!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I made several changes but also think the recipe is just fine the way it is. The only change I strongly recommend is that I used 2 chicken breasts and 1 package of thigh fillets (boneless; skinless). The thighs were much more moist. I might only use thighs next time- they're cheaper anyway. And don't chicken out (pun intended) on the beer- I used a Newcastle and the final product was great. I roasted 2 ears of corn on the grill and also added some roasted jalepenos- but again I don't think you have to do either.  One of the very few "simple" recipes that was actually good! One note: tortilla soup is often served/made with only chicken stock as the base. (Think chicken noodle soup with tortilla strips instead of noodles).This is much heartier with a stronger tomato flavor. If you prefer the chicken noodle soup style this isn't for you.

text:
Delicious! I followed this recipe almost exactly as far as ingredients go, but added my own twist. Based on other reviews, I did leave out the beer.  After I dumped in the ingredients, I put some water in each can to rinse out the contents and added that to the soup because it did not seem like enough liquid. After 7 hours in the crockpot on low, I added a (12 oz??) bag of shredded cheddar.  I also mixed some cooled broth with flour and added that to the soup to thicken it slightly.  We served it with hearty bread, tortilla chips, and a dollop of sour cream.  My family loved it!

text:
This was very well received by the family when I made it last weekend. I just got done making another batch to freeze. My DH doesn't often like soups with beans, but this one he really likes. I made a few minor changes that I don't think change up the recipe that much. I used two 15 ounce cans of petite diced tomatoes and two 4 oz cans of mild diced chilies. That is what I had on hand.  I doubled the black beans. I substituted chicken broth for the beer and used 5 chicken breasts. Looking at the most useful reviews, I followed the author's recipe for homemade taco seasoning and used 2 T of the seasoning. This turned out great and will be in my collection of make agains.

text:
Very tasty! I put my chicken in frozen, and after 3 hours took it out and diced (personal preference to shredded). I used Sam Adams Boston Lager for the beer, and frozen corn instead of canned. I used the Echols taco seasoning recipe in the first review, but went a little light on the crushed pepper flakes and chili powder (neither my son or I like very spicy foods). Everything else was as stated. Great flavor, not too spicy (I was worried about all the canned chilis in the tomatoes). I liked it best with lite sour cream stirred in to make it creamy. Also made a great dip for the 'Hint of Lime' tortilla chips! Picky boyfriend ate quite a bit, so I know he liked it!

This recipe was so easy and so delicious! I tend to like more creamy soups, so before I added the shredded chicken, I put about three-fourths of the soup in the blender and pureed it. then I put it back into the crockpot with the chicken. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Outstanding! Some additions to this make it perfect and more wholesome!
I boiled a whole chicken and created good stock with veggies and herbs, let it cool, then deboned and used about half the chicken (saving the rest for another meal-freeze in ziplock bag).
I sauteed onion, sweet pepper, and celery and put into the pot. Added sliced carrots, several cloves of garlic and a cup or so of frozen corn.
Used a few cups of the homemade stock, one can of rotel, and some tomato sauce (could use any kind of canned tomatoes).
Used one can of kidneys and one can of pintos.
Top with cilantro, grated cheese, and lime tortilla chips. Serve with cornbread or corn muffins.
Everyone's favorite!
Thanks to all previous reviewers for the great ideas and additions!

text:
I altered this recipe a bit based on what I had on hand, but we love it and are now making it for the third time in three weeks.  It's beyond easy and better than any we've had in restaurants!

I used the Bill Echols seasoning that was recommended, and the first time I made it I thought it called for the whole mixture, but it was delish so I've continued to make it that way.  I didn't have beer so I used chicken broth and some water, and 2 cans of black beans (vs chili beans), 2 cans of Mexi-corn, and 1 can of tomatoes with about a pound of chicken plus the onion.  I garnish it with lime juice, cilantro, sliced jalapenos, sour cream, shredded cheese, and tortilla strips.

I've got it going in the crock pot right now in fact!

text:
This is SO delicious! I have made this probably 20 times since I ran into the recipe.  I make it exactly as written, have lots of leftovers which is still very good the next day. I let this cook in my crockpot on low while I'm at work all day,(12 hours) I'm sure it's done much sooner but because of my commute/schedule I have to let it cook that long, I come home and shred the chicken, let it cook maybe another half hour to an hour. It makes the whole house smell so good. The beer gives it a really good flavor, melds everything together, kind of a tangy taste if I'm describing that correctly. DO NOT leave that part out, even if it sounds strange, it wouldn't taste the same without it.  Great recipe!

text:
It was a cold morning and I decided to throw this in the slow cooker so it would be ready for lunch. I ended up doing it on 3.5 hours on high and it was very delicious, hearty and satisfying. Based on the ingredients I had, I used three cans of chicken already chunked up, a bottle of Oktoberfest beer (because I live in Germany and it was dark and perfect for the recipe), and because I only had one can of Rotel, I used another of plain diced tomatoes and a can of Mexican corn. Our bowls were topped with shredded Pepper Jack cheese. The whole family, even children ages 2 and 4, ate this right up. Thank you for the easy and cheap recipe that is so tasty.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I'm giving this 4 stars because I had to make alterations from the original recipe.  But following the alterations, I loved this soup! 

Beans: 1 can of chili beans and 1 can of kidney beans (with the liquid), I used frozen corn (much better flavor), added 1 can of low sodium tomato soup, omitted the beer and replaced it with chicken stock, replaced the tomatoes and chilies with tomatoes and chilies with lime and cilantro, used 1 packet of chipotle taco seasoning and 1/2 of original low sodium taco seasoning, added 2 teaspoons of cumin, added 1Tb of Sriracha, 1Tbs of garlic powder, and pinch of nutmeg.  For the final change, I replaced the chicken breasts with Wegmans Cilantro-Lime Marinated Boneless, Skinless Chicken Thighs.  I cooked for a total of 8hrs.  Topped with a dollop of sour cream and shredded cheddar cheese and chopped cilantro.  This was amazing and had the perfect amount of kick to it.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I took someone's suggestion and did this on the stovetop.  I browned the chicken, then the onions, then added everything else, including about 45 oz of chicken stock (left off the beer).  I didn't have 2 cans of tomatoes so substituted a jar of salsa for one of the cans and used homemade taco seasoning.  I simmered it about 1 1/2 hours, then shredded the chicken, added it back to the pot and served.  The chicken stayed tender this way.  I was able to keep it from overcooking.  This soup as written has been one of my favorites and a freezer staple every winter.  I'm giving it 5 stars because I already loved it, but the stovetop method is my new favorite.  Addition:  I've found that a squeeze of fresh lime juice is a good substitute for sour cream in this recipe, plus this soup is really good with a few slices of avocado on top.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As other reviewers have mentioned this recipe does NOT make your house smell good while brewing. That being said, the soup is delicious. I made a few changes. I added about 1/2 more of fresh chopped onion, onion powder, garlic powder, approx. 1/4 - 1/2 cup of water, approx. 1/2 cup of sugar, salt & pepper (like others suggested), and Italian seasoning. I not only drained, but also rinsed my beans before adding them to the crock-pot,  I used frozen corn, because that's what I already had and a Corona beer that had been in my frig for literally months (seriously). This soup is very spicy, but its fabulous! I especially like it when served with the sour cream, cheddar cheese, and tortilla toppings, as suggested by the recipe. I'm really happy I made this! Thanks! :)
My advice for those who are thinking of making this... I think you ABSOLUTELY must tweak this recipe per your specifications. If you know you don't like the bitterness of canned tomato sauce, you have to add sugar, if you are a big onion fan (like me) add more onion, if you like herbs, add herbs, if you don't like beer use white wine, but whatever you do, PLEASE DO NOT USE A CHEAP beer. This is an excellent base and for many its fantastic just the way it is, but if you are a picky Lady like I am, you must tweak it to cater to YOUR taste buds. You are doing yourself an injustice not to spice it up to your liking. That's one of the things I really like about this website. Its encouraged! :)

text:
Love, love, LOVE this recipe!  We always add our chicken breasts frozen, and they cook and shred just fine.  We usually only add 2 chicken breasts, because we store them in the freezer 2 in a package.  We usually add 3 cans of beans, either 2 kidney and 1 black bean, or 2 black bean and 1 kidney.  We use chicken broth instead of beer.  For us, this comes out more like a chilli.  We put cheese on top of it and scoop it up with Tortilla Chips instead of a spoon.  So yummy, so cheap and easy to make, and everyone LOVES it!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Probably the best and most tastiest recipe!  I have made this three times so far and each time without the beer.  This last time I used higher end thin sliced chicken breasts (no gristle), two cans of corn, chicken broth, two large yellow onions, two packages of taco seasoning (my local market has a delicious non-name brand taco seasoning packet), a little extra sea salt, Ro*Tel with habanero, hot chili beans and the rest of ingredients as listed.  I did not add any cheese or the tortilla chips which really aren't needed.  Definitely serve with a dollop of sour cream.  It turns into a scrumptious, south-west style "chili bordering on soup" (especially the next day).  The husband loves this so much he tries to come home for lunch to eat it then has it again for dinner.  This last time, I had an extra cup of cooked rice which I threw in the slow cooker as well.  This is a fantastic weekend recipe that is delicious when done and makes perfect leftovers.  Keep in mind the chicken gets tender and easy to shred in the slow cooker so shred it after about 4 hours then mix into the soup.  Yummy!

text:
Great recipe!! I varied the recipe slightly but this recipe is solid and changes can be made w/out sacrificing taste. I sauteed the onions first just to carmelize them for flavor; I had no chili beans so I skipped those, used frozen corn, skipped the beer since I hate beer and have none, made the great taco seasoning that Patti attached to this recipe, and I used canned (Kirkland-Costco) chicken since that's all I had. It was delicious! My husband and coworkers raved about it (all guys)! Try this recipe, you won't regret it!

text:
Made as directed & this was really good! (I accidentaly left out the onion @ the start & added about a Tbsp of dried minced onion & a tsp of onion powder later in the process.) SUPER easy to put together and the chicken was so tender it was easy to shred after 5 hours. Even my boyfriend who dosen't like chicken (b/c it's "bland") was pleased with this. Even with Mild chili beans & mild taco seasoning this had some kick, but not a turnoff to those who are sensitive to heat. I'll be making this again & trying it with beef, too!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe.  I tweaked it in the following ways. I use two 15 oz cans of diced tomatoes and omitted the tomato sauce. I added a packet of ranch dressing mix and two cloves garlic, minced.  For the beans I used one can of Cuban style black beans and one can of Chipotle pinto beans. I also added a large can of diced ortega chilis.  I use 4 chicken breasts and halfway thru I chop the breast up and add them back to the pot.  It has a kick, great for a rainy cold day!  We serve ours with white rice, either on the side or  the chicken mix served on top.

HATE TO REVIEW SOMETHING THAT WASN'T MADE EXACTLY LIKE THE RECIPE. BUT, I DIDN'T LIKE THE FLAVOR 'AS IS', SO, THIS IS WHAT I CHANGED: USED 2 CANS OF FIRE ROASTED TOMATOES WITH GREEN CHILIS, ADDED A PACKAGE OF DRY RANCH DRESSING MIX, ADDED A PACKAGE OF DRY ONION SOUP MIX. ADDED JUICE FROM 2 VERY JUICY LIMES WHILE COOKING. ABOUT 30 MINS. BEFORE SERVING I ADDED ABOUT 4 TBSP OF CHOPPED FINE CILANTRO. WITH THESE ADDITIONS I THOUGHT IT WAS GOOD. WITHOUT MY CHANGES THAT'S WHY I GAVE IT 3 STARS. WITH MY CHANGES I'D RATE IT A 5 STAR RECIPE.

userID:
2185517
Display Name:
UHElle
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/375660.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I LOVE this recipe. A friend shared it on her blog, & it's one of my favourites! Sure, you could make a bunch of changes here & there if you're wanting to perfect it or tweak it to your exact specifications, but, as a simple throw together meal, you can't ask for much more. I don't change it at all, save for using my own homemade taco seasoning (though I've made it with packaged, and have been equally as pleased...it just has TONS of salt that way). I say go for the beer. I have a feeling that if people think there's too strong of an aftertaste or bitter flavour, then a poor beer choice was made. I always use a lighter flavoured beer, like a pilsner (while I HATE to drink pils, they make for a mild, but delicious additive). I have also made this stove top, and find it, again, delicious. The only thing one may need to do is add an extra can-ful of water to the recipe, not necessarily to make it soupier, but so there's enough liquid to cover your chicken breasts. Oh, and something important (to me, at least) is to always rinse your black beans. If you don't, they'll muddy up the beautiful colours of this soup!
Thanks SO much for the recipe!

text:
Loved this! My husband said it's the best chicken taco soup he has ever had!  I had most of it on hand except for green chillies so I used jalepenos. It makes a lot so we freezed 1/2 for later.  The taco seasoning makes it and is listed in the first review but here it is as well: Bill Echols Taco Seasoning. It really makes this recipe. 1 tablespoon chili powder 1/4 teaspoon garlic powder 1/4 teaspoon onion powder 1/4 teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes 1/4 teaspoon dried oregano 1/2 teaspoon paprika 1 1/2 teaspoons ground cumin 1 teaspoon sea salt 1 teaspoon black pepper

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A HUGE thank you to Patti for submitting this. My husband asks me to make this all winter. (It's too hot in Texas to justify making it in July.) My in-laws love it, I love it, my parents love it. It's an all-around crowd-pleaser; you won't be sorry you made it! A few things to note that aren't in the directions: please rinse your beans before adding them to the crock pot! There's way too much sodium in the liquid used to preserve the beans; this recipe doesn't need it. Also: USE Patti's taco seasoning (the most helpful review on the front page.) I know it's "extra work," but there's all kinds of junk/sodium in those taco seasoning packages and her seasoning tastes *SO* much better. If you have the time, I find cubing the chicken breasts beforehand makes the shredding easier - it pretty much falls apart on its own.  For REAL kick-you-in-the-teeth heat, use cans of "Hot" Rotel (just one, unless you're in for the punishment.) For those nights you don't want to be up, use the Mild Rotel. ;)

text:
Ingenious concept... Dump cans and frozen chicken in Slow Cooker, spend rest of day 'facebooking'. Why didn't I think of this? Not to mention, the scrumtrulescent soup at the end of a long day of lounging... mmm. And forgiving! I used an ancient can of Miller High Life (from the back of the fridge; God knows how it got there in the first place), used pinto instead of chili beans and took RaisinKane's suggestion for Bill Echols' seasoning blend (1 TBSP chili powder 1/4 tsp garlic powder 1/4 tsp onion powder 1/4 tsp crushed red pepper flakes 1/4 tsp dried oregano 1/2 tsp paprika 1 1/2 tsp ground cumin 1 tsp salt 1 tsp black pepper). I'll probably sweat my way through bowls of this all summer long... it is SO good!

text:
I wish I could have followed this recipe to a T but I either didn't have all the ingredients or the right ones. I ended up using one can of tomatoes with jalapeno peppers and another without since I didn't want to burn any tongues off. I didn't use the beer I had, b/c it was either the cherry wheat or the blue moon which I wanted to drink later! so instead, I used chicken broth. I forgot the corn. I used pinto beans for the "chili beans" and I cooked on high for 5 hours. At the 3 hr mark I shredded and returned to the pot.  Served with cornbread from this site. I do enjoy how this recipe is pretty forgiving! sometimes living in NYC- it can pretty hard to find the usual canned mexican fare (I can't find enchilada sauce anywhere!) so this recipe was grocery store friendly. and tummy friendly!

text:
Only change I made was chicken broth instead of beer.  I make this fairly regularly. I've also made it for a few parties and it's always the first thing to go! It's been a huge hit so thanks!!   My only advice is to MAKE SURE you use the taco seasoning "recipe" that's offered in the first review. It really makes the soup. (Over time I have increased the amounts of seasoning called for because I don't feel like 1/4 teaspoon of certain spices are enough for us.) We also use it  for other chicken items that need great flavor.   I also add a few extra chicken breasts when I make the soup so they can soak up the great flavor, then put them in tacos or taquitos. Great recipe!

country:

text:
Made this for book club this week. I had some bone in chicken breast so I boiled them the day before and deboned the chicken. I used the broth for my base added Rotel w/green chilis,black,pinto & chili beans (can of each) and a can of Ranch Style w/jalapenos. I seasoned with Taco seasoning we buy the large containers and I probably used about 3 tablespoons. I also added finely chopped onion and simmered for a couple of hours the first day then heated for 30 minutes or so the next day before serving. I also added a package of Ranch dressing mix the second day. I used mozzarella in stead of cheddar, and the ladies loved it! I usually use the sour cream and chips, but no time to pick them up and make it to the meeting on time. But it is better w/sour cream & chips. Will make this a lot in the future. I really think letting it refrigerate overnight made it more flavorful.

This was super easy and delicious! I didn't have a taco seasoning packet so I used Bill Echols taco seasoning recipe as some others suggested.  I added a fourth chicken breast but will not do so next time as it ended up too thick and hearty and more like chili. I used half beer and half chicken broth and couldn't taste the beer at all. I cooked it all on medium heat in my slow cooker for 4 hours, shredded the chicken and then cooked for another hour. My husband suggested that next time I top it with a little cilantro and squirt of lime in addition to the other toppings.  We thoroughly enjoyed this and I will be making it again soon.

text:
Very tasty and quick to put together in the morning!  I rinsed the beans and corn in a colander under running water to reduce some of the sodium, and it was still salty enough.  By omitting the last three ingredients (sour cream, tortillas and cheese), I was able to drastically reduce the fat and calories, which makes it a great 'diet' dinner.  Next time I will try a bit of non-fat sour cream, and low fat cheese on top with fresh cilantro to garnish.  A definite keeper!!

text:
Love this! It's very forgiving too.  I've made a few slight variations depending on what was on hand and it was fine.  This time:  1 can pinto and 1 can black beans, 1 can petite diced tomatoes with zesty jalepinos and one can diced tomatoes Mexican style, 1 cup chicken broth instead of beer (to make up for the extra liquid in the 2nd can of tomatoes) and added 1 can drained jalepinos.  Also you can leave the chicken as is all day, 8 hours, and then shred it and it's still fine.

This recipe is a keeper....amazing!  I cut out the beer but if there was anything missing I couldn't tell. The only complaint my picky son had was that there were too many beans and there were quite a few beans so maybe next time I will reduce the amount of beans.  Even with that complaint he still asked for more!  This makes a lot of soup (serves 8) so there was plenty left over with just the two of us.  You may want to scale the recipe down if you're only serving a few people.  Make sure you add shredded cheese..it makes a big difference...hmm, hmm, good. PS-don't forget to rinse the beans well!

text:
Delicious! And so quick & easy.  I used skinless, boneless chicken thighs, added a couple of cloves of minced garlic, rinsed & drained the black beans (I hate that liquid they're in), used 1 can of diced tomatoes with roasted garlic and one can of the tomatoes with chiles, and forgot the tomato sauce (but I don't think it needs it). I also only used about 1 tsp of taco seasoning (Bill Echols' recipe from this website) and added about 1/4 tsp more cumin, and it was just the right "heat" for my family. Served it topped with crispy tortilla strips (baked) and chopped avocado.  I'm always looking for good crock pot recipes and this one's a keeper!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We found this very good and very easy. I had to make this Gluten Free so reading the label on each can was essential. Some canned chili beans and packaged taco seasonings do contain wheat flour.  I used some dried black beans and pinto beans I had soaked and cooked previously and stored in the freezer. I didn't have any beer but I don't like cooking with it anyway so I used a can of chicken broth in its place. Also, I only had one can of Rotel vs the two the recipe specified so I used one can of stewed tomatoes in place of the 2nd can of Rotel. It helped cut down the spicy factor as not everyone in the house can handle spicy foods. I put this together the night before and stored in the refrigerator so I could start cooking it first thing the next morning. The chicken breasts I added were frozen but cooked completely by lunch time, shredded easily and were very flavorful.  This is a wonderful recipe! It's fast, easy and filling on a cold day!

This is absolutely scrumptious. It's more like a stew than a soup, but it definitely has broth so it's not like chicken chili. I made my own taco seasoning from another recipe on allrecipes and I do think it added more of a bright, intense flavor. The chicken becomes infused with all these delicious flavors. The corn adds a nice crunch. The beer adds a nice hint of flavor, too. I might try it with chicken thighs next time. I did not eat it with the chips, cheese or sour cream garnish and it was totally delicious as is.

userID:
4365862
Display Name:
Brian
isPro:
False
followersCount:
9

84
favoritesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4015453.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
OK, this is obscenely easy, and tastes great.  If the most work intensive part of a recipe is chopping 1 onion, I have to try it.  To make it even easier, I used frozen chicken breasts (4 at about 1.5lbs = meat lovers).  Works great!  Reading reviews can mess me up sometimes, and with this one, it was "beer, or not to beer".  Half say use beer, and half say use broth.  I chickened out and did half and half.  In reality, beer is often used as a tenderizer which wouldn't be needed for a slow cooker recipe.  I say go with what moves you.  If you're afraid of the taste of beer, I can't imagine 1 beer leaving any flavor.  Avocado, tortilla chips, and shredded cheese makes it.  This is my third slow cooker, Mexican soup from this site.  All 3 are great: Slow Cooker Chicken Tortilla for a less hearty soup; Slow Cooker Pasole for a more meat and potatoes kind of fare; this recipe for when you want something heartier than tortilla.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2015-02-24T07:47:08.61
helpfulCount:
2
userID:

text:
I did not care for this recipe. I gave it two stars because I have used very similar ingredients (minus the beer) in other soups and it's come out alright, so I honestly think it was the type of beer. I don't think you can just say (12oz) of any beer when there are SO many kinds of beer that would completely change the flavor....SOOOO many different kinds of beer! Tried to save it with the sugar, even read that lemon juice can help....nothing could save it. Had to completely strain out the broth, rinse off the chicken, beans, corn, tomatoes, etc., and luckily I had some old homemade chicken broth and a can of enchilada sauce to salvage my ingredients so we didn't waste money.

text:
I'm giving this 5 stars because the flavor was great.  However, it was way too spicy for my liking, even after using only one can of the tomatoes and chilies.  I also substituted chicken broth for the beer. The next time I make this (and I will make again), I'll opt for 2 cans of plain diced tomatoes and use regular kidney or pinto beans.  I actually cooked my chicken breasts in the crock pot first(so I could eliminate most of the fat), and finished the soup on the stove top.  Very easy to throw together.

text:
I make this and bag it out for lunches, then just throw some shredded cheese and tortilla chips or avocado in the bag and I am out the door. Very yummy reheated as is most chili. I've made it with and without the beer and didnt really notice a difference. I did have to adjust the spices but as the poster said it is a very forgiving recipe. I also recommend taking a serving of it, reduce it in a sauce pan so it isn't so soupy, and top tortilla chips with it and some cheese and broil for 2 mins until cheese is melted. Best nachos ever!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1357129.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this to the recipe. I did not however make the taco seasoning. First off I used st Arnold Christmas ale. We could definitely taste the bitterness and smell the beer smell. I will most likely either leave it out next time and add broth or buy Guinness, I am told that is a good one to cook with. So if you are worried about the beer, as I was, that is my take on it. I also think you should make the taco seasoning they suggest you add instead of the packaged stuff. Next time I will also do that. My husband added spices to his liking around the point I needed to take the chicken out to shred it. It needed salt badly and cumin and garlic. Although they were in the seasoning I added, it wasn't enough. For those who want to know if frozen chicken is ok.. go for it! Mine turned out perfect for shredding. I did however set it to high for the first hour then turned it low for the remainder. If you are a garnish person or like toppings this soup is wonderful with sour cream, avocado, shredded cheese and tortilla chips. even some cilantro. 5 stars for a crowd pleaser and overall very delicious recipe!

text:
My entire family loves this soup! We did not use beer, but used chicken broth instead. So, you can skip the beer and not miss out on any flavor. I like my chicken to be shredded, so after it's finished cooking in the crock pot, I take it out, let it cool and run it through my little vegetable chopper (you know, the $10 kind), and it shreds it perfectly. I just dump it back in with all the other ingredients and it is delicious! (I also use White Shoepeg corn as it is our family's favorite)

text:
Made this for dinner tonight for the family. First time making any type of Mexican soup. Loved it!

However, I made some changes right from the get-go. I used a 6-Qt slow cooker so I wanted to almost double the batch.

I deleted the chili beans because we just don't like them. Instead I added two cans of black beans (rinsed and drained). Even though I doubled recipe, I only used one bottle of beer and the two cans black beans (NO chili beans at all) and 2 1/2 pounds chicken breasts (approx. 3 large breasts). Doubled everything else. The soup was just soupy enough without being too runny. 

We garnished with sour cream, shredded 4 cheese Mexican blend, sliced green onions and fresh avocado with a side of mini corn bread. Yummm!

text:
I used 2 lbs of stew beef that I had leftover from Costco.  I browned it in a large pan before adding it to the soup. I used two packets of taco seasoning also. Since I don't have a slow cooker I cooked it on the stove to a gentile boil for 4 hours, and then I spooned out the meat to shred.  I cooked it another hour after and it was absolutely delicious. This is a versatile dish with sides and accompaniments. My husband likes the drained filling in burritos.

text:
This soup/chilli is delicious! Only made on substitution:  I used a can of red kidney beans with a "chilli" recipe since I couldn't find one in my grocery store.  Used a bottle of Corona and frozen corn and there's absolutely no beer taste.  I cooked in the slow cooker on High for about 4 hours, and started shredding the chicken around the 3 hour mark.  Then put it on low for another 2 hours.  So, so yummy.  I like spicy so if you don't, then I'd definitely recommend using diced tomatoes without the chiles or only one with chiles.  You can always make spicier later.  I would probably only do 2 chicken breasts next time as well... a little too much chicken in my book.  Great on a chilly day!

this was just ok....I was afraid the spices would be too dilute when I substituted chicken stock for the beer and then added MORE stock to cover the chicken tenderloins I used. country:
None
text:
Absolutely wonderful. Reminded me of a soup my parents used to make me.

I made this soup on the stove top rather than a slow cooker. I sweated the onions in the bottom of the pot with some olive oil, then added all the rest of ingredients as indicated (including the liquid from the diced tomatoes). Added the chicken breasts whole, brought to a boil, then reduced to a low simmer with a lid on for 1 hour and 15 minutes. I then removed the chicken and shredded it using two forks, and it was incredibly moist and tender.

For beer we used an Extra Pale Ale (Rolling Rock). The spice mix indicated for Bill Echols Taco Seasoning (posted by RaisinKane aka Patti) was incredible, and really made the recipe. Will 100% make again!

text:
This was a HUGE hit. Perfect for those cold winter days - or when you're just feeling lazy. This is really more of a chili...especially when you omit the beer. Lots of flavor and taste! I followed the top suggestions:

--Use hot chili beans
--Put the chicken in raw, shred after 5-6 hours
--Skip the beer
--For the taco seasoning, make your own:
Bill Echols Taco Seasoning: 1 tablespoon chili powder 1/4 teaspoon garlic powder 1/4 teaspoon onion powder 1/4 teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes 1/4 teaspoon dried oregano 1/2 teaspoon paprika 1 1/2 teaspoons ground cumin 1 teaspoon sea salt 1 teaspoon black pepper

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
My 9 year old said I should make this soup every week. We all (husband & 3 sons)  LOVED it! I made a couple changes but they in no way changed the integrity of the recipe. We don't keep beer in the house so I used an entire container of chicken stock. I used canned chicken (so yummy!) and just added it to the soup for the last 15 min to heat it through. I wanted it to be more soupy so we could sop it up with our cheddar biscuits so I added extra tomato sauce. I buy taco seasoning in a large container instead of the taco packets - so I just eyeballed it.  I used Rotel tomatoes. ALWAYS USE ROTEL in my Mexican recipes. I put all the left overs into a 3 pint mason jar filled to the top. By evening - - when we usually get popcorn or a bowl of ice cream - everyone got more soup. The was barely any soup left. Will make this again and again! thank you Patti!!

The ONLY thing I would do differently...is add salt!  THAT'S IT!  I followed the recipe exactly like it says...but cooked it on low a little longer because I was at work all day. I used a very light beer, since that was all I had, and would probably use a stronger one next time.  HOWEVER...we could still taste the hint of the beer flavor and loved it! Those saying they couldn't taste it...must not recognize it like we do.  ;-)  It's good...and my biggest critic...husband...loved it!

text:
OH MY GOODNESS, a wonderful, easy, GREAT tasting meal! I paired this with a superb grilled corn, tomato, red onion, basil, cilantro salad, so I omitted the can of corn for the recipe--it was a HIT. Adding 1 can of diced green chilis, about a 1/2 T of Mexican oregano, 2 t of cumin, and a sparse T of sugar (to cut the acid in 1 can of tomatoes w/green chilis), I topped the soup with fat free sour cream, grated colby-jack, and crushed tortilla chips. This is in my recipe box FOREVER!

text:
I found this soup to be delicious and easy to make. I used Sam Adams Summer Ale and it gave the soup a delicious flavor that wasn't too "beery." I also just used a regular taco seasoning packet. I did add some salt and pepper. My kids LOVED this, and my son doesn't even like beans, but he ate it all up. I highly suggest NOT leaving out the beer. As someone else said, just use the right kind. Cheap beer, which is not full bodied, will not give it a good flavor.

text:
This was really good, but I did adjust it a little based only on what I had on hand.  Thankfully, I had most of what I needed, and that makes this a great go-to recipe.

I only used one can of black beans, drained and rinsed, no other beans.  I used a 10 oz can of tomatoes and a 14.5 oz can since that's the closest I had.  I also used roughly 1 cup of chicken broth instead of the beer.  Everything else was the same, and it turned out really good.

I cooked it about 4.5 hrs on high, and that was fine.  I can see me making this again in the future since it was so easy and good.

Excellent! Use the original posters recommended Taco Seasoning:

Bill Echols Taco Seasoning. It really makes this recipe. 1 tablespoon chili powder 1/4 teaspoon garlic powder 1/4 teaspoon onion powder 1/4 teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes 1/4 teaspoon dried oregano 1/2 teaspoon paprika 1 1/2 teaspoons ground cumin 1 teaspoon sea salt 1 teaspoon black pepper

text:
Made three batches of this soup in the last couple of weeks.  It's just my wife and me but we ate the first batch in a very short time.  We made no changes in recipe. Don't worry about the time too much, the longer it cooks in the crook pot the better it gets. Second batch we ate some of but froze most in serving sized portions for later and then made a fresh batch for a couple of friends that came over Sunday night for dinner. Served with corn chips,green onions, sour cream,and grated cheese on the side so they had their choice of toppings. Served with a green salad and some sliced avocados. What a hit.  We sent a large portion of what was left and the recipe home with our friends. Great recipe--thanks--Omar

text:
OMG!  The kids went nuts over this recipe tonight.  Not sure if they were just extra hungry or what, but they all went back for seconds and rated it infinity stars. WOW!  I did not use beer, but chicken broth instead and added a splash of lime juice.  I put frozen chicken breasts right into the pot and they were ready for shredding after 8 hours on low. Also used frozen corn.  At the end I stirred in diced avocado.

UPDATE: I've been making this for years now.  I pack as many frozen chicken breast as I can fit in the crock pot.  The kids ask for it all the time AND it the ONLY thing my picky 4 year old eats entirely.  One week I doubled the recipe, and she ate the leftovers 5 days in a row and cried when it was gone!  We top with green onions, chips and shredded cheddar.

text:
My picky eaters actually ate this, although I found it a tad too spicy.  I used to large chicken breasts cut into strips (not shredded) and made it on the stovetop. Omitted the beer, added chicken broth and water, garlic powder, salt, onion powder and cumin, with a touch of paprika.  Didn't have chili pepper so added 1/3 package of chili powder mix and a package of taco seasoning.  Had to keep adding water to take some of the spiciness out.  Served with Mexican blend cheese and nacho chips.  And lots of leftovers!

I made this tonight and o..m..g. So good. I didn't have the taco seasoning which I was really worried about. country:
None
text:
This was a wonderfully flavorful soup!  Even my hubby who usually isn't much of a taco soup lover (because of the "tomato-y" taste) raved about it.   It was a little bit spicy for my 3 year old, but I loved the little kick that it had!  I used a Shiner Bock beer and it gave it a really amazing taste.  Even if you're not a beer drinker, please make this at least once with the beer since it really gives this a unique taste.  This is the sixth "taco soup" recipe I have tried this winter and this recipe is the only one I will make again.   I did add about 1/4 cup of cilantro to the mix about 10 minutes before I served it.  If you are a vegetarian, you could leave out the chicken and it would still be delicious.   I topped it only with crushed blue tortilla chips.  Paired with a good asiago cheese bread and dinner was easy breezy!  Thanks for the great recipe.

text:
I enjoyed this soup but made a few changes after trying the recipe the first time.  I used a small whole chicken and poached it in the slow cooker over night the night before.  After easily striping all the meat I saved the broth and used that in the soup instead of beer or water. I liked to shreaded chicken better than the chucks of chicken I got when I used the breasts, and I haven't found a beer that complimented the flavor of the soup so I liked the chicken broth much better.   Also I went with one can of tomatoes and one small jar of salsa it added a great zip.

My only tweaks -  I used fresh tomatoes (4 vine) and cut up 6 jalapenos. I'll definitely add this recipe to my regular rotation.

text:
I can't give this a true rating because I didn't have all of the ingredients, so my rating is for tonight's soup. I only used one can of the diced tomatoes with chilies. I used creamed corn instead of whole kernel (but that was fine), a large (15 oz) can of tomato sauce, and I made the Taco Seasoning that you suggested. While the soup was cooking, I was pretty convinced that I wasn't going to be happy with the results. When I tasted it, it seemed way too spicy. In an effort to cut the spice, I added some homemade chicken stock and about 1/2 cup of sour cream. However, once on the table, with saltines and shredded cheddar, the soup was perfect! Even my picky, very UN-spice-loving son raved about it! I will be making this again!

userID:

Display Name:
logsdonr

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We love this recipe!  My modifications:
I use all black beans (2 or 3 cans).  I use 1 can plain diced tomatoes, 1 can diced tomatoes with CHIPOTLE chilies in it, one can of tomato sauce, and one small can of diced green chilies.  (the chipotle chilies add an awesome flavor!)  I use 2 or 3 tablespoons of taco seasoning from a bulk container.  I use half chicken breast and half chicken thigh meat for added flavor and a different texture (thigh meat is cheaper too).  Of course the corn and onion are the same.  Finally, I use water or sparkling mineral water instead of beer (enough to fill the large slow cooker up to 1/2 inch from the top so it won't spill when simmering). 

I love to put crushed tortilla chips on the bottom of the bowl and a little shredded mexican cheese blend on top.  YUM!!!

*The best modification is the Chipotle chilies - if you can get just a little chipotle chilies in the recipe somehow I DEFINITELY recommend it!

This recipe is so EASY, CHEAP and YUMMY!! I made it with the beer, and I don't agree with everybody that said it had such a strong beer scent and flavor.  I used a light beer, and the house smelled terrific all day. There was a ton of food. The leftovers can be used atop a green salad, over a baked potato, in wraps (if drained well).  It's a very healthy southwest meal. I added a green pepper and used one can of original Rotel tomatoes and one can hot. It was just enough kick. I also added an extra chicken breast. I'd do it exactly the same next time, and I'll definitely be making this over and over.

text:
DELICIOUS!!!!  And so SUPER EASY!!!  I love this meal!  I didn't have chili beans, so I just added a can of northern beans, since that's what I had on hand.  I also used a spicy taco seasoning that made up for it.  I substituted the beer with chicken broth instead.  And I didn't have diced tomatoes with green chilies, so I just used plain diced tomatoes and added a can of diced green chilies.  I also just left everything in the crock pot until we were ready to eat.  The chicken fell apart easily as I stirred.  We enjoyed it with sour cream and cheddar cheese and crushed chips on the top!  Thanks for such a great recipe!  This definitely goes in my favorites.  :)

city:

country:
None
text:
Great recipe! I tweaked the recipe as I always do and made it my own. This is an easy dish to make and also to make 'your own'. So many things you can add or take away. Like many of you I chose two 14oz cans of broth over the beer. I also used pinto beans & kidney beans instead of what the recipe said. I also added Yukon Gold potatoes (cubed), chopped carrots, grean beans, plus the kernal corn, etc. and left out the white onion. I'll use peas the next time. You can add or remove most anything! I used the entire package of Lawry's taco seasoning and added 1/2 tsp of cumin, good dash of pepper, & 2 tbsp chili powder. I may have even done a couple of other things but can't remember as I just create as I go along. I cooked on high for 6 hours and the chicken breasts fell apart on their own in the crock. Then cooked another 2 hours. For the garnish I had sharp cheddar cheese, sour cream and green onions & topped with tortilla strips. I served garlic bread for dipping on the side. I got that idea from a restaraunt that made an amazing tortilla soup which is basically what I considored this to be. My husband loved it and it's a keeper! Thank You Patti for the recipe!

text:
I like this recipe, I agree with the chicken stock subsitute. First, I warmed in my pot about 2 tablespoons of butter and 2 tablespoons of olive oil. Next, I threw in about four tablespoons of flour and let them work together for abour five min. on med-high heat. Then I put in my onions and let cook down for another 5 min. This adds a little more texture to the soup by the time it is ready to serve. Oh yeah, just use Rotel instead of diced green chilis and 2 chicken halves (placed in your pot for about 5 hours and then debone, and take the skin off and chop it) instead of boneless chicken, adds flavor.

text:
I reduced my chicken down to two breasts and used my own, home-made taco seasoning.  We have a family member on a lower-sodium diet, so this taco seasoning helps cut that down.  2 T Chili Powder, 1.5 T ground Cumin, 1 T dried Oregano, 1 T ground Coriander, 1.5 tsp Garlic Powder and 1/4 tsp Ground Red Pepper.  This can also be used by placing that amount with 1/2 cup water for each pound of ground beef.  Great flavor and soooooo easy!!

text:
This soup just won the "soup off" contest where I work. It competed against 6 other soups, some of them absolutely fantastic. I was shocked that I won. I have made this soup twice, each time a little different and each time, it came out great. The first time, I had no idea how much of Bill's taco seasoning would equal a package of taco seasoning. I dumped all of it in as I saw someone mention that they used 4 tablespoons of Bill’s seasoning. Well, I had to put in a lot of extra canned tomatoes, broth and rotel to counter act it. The second time I added the taco seasoning 1/2 teaspoon at a time until it was just right. I think I put in 3 to 4 teaspoons (and I did not add the crushed red pepper in his recipe.) I played it safe spice wise as I was cooking for a crowd. The one thing I can say is that you can't go off how it tastes as you are cooking it. The flavor and spices blend together in the end and taste really smooth and fantastic!

text:
Great soup for a cold winter night! I followed the recipe exactly and found that it has some heat using "original" variety of Rotel. You could use mild variety Rotel to tame it a little. Pass bottled hot sauce at the table for those who like more heat. I loved, lovedd the ease of this recipe. I assembled it the night before and stuck it in the frig. In the morning, I just pulled it out of the frig, set it on low and let it go. Dinner ready when we got home! Love that! I made some cornbread to go with it. This recipe made a thick, hearty stew. Add some chicken broth if you are looking for a thinner, more soupy soup.

text:
If you are not a beer lover, like myself, you WILL be able to taste the beer in this.  I highly recommend a high quality beer because the flavor infuses throughout the soup.  I fixed it a second time with chicken stock and it was much better.  I did not like it at all with the beer and my kids hated it...my husband, being a beer lover, did like it. Edited 9/2014:  I have now made this soup lots of times.  It is my go to recipe for taco soup.  I always add chicken stock instead of the beer and my own homemade taco seasoning.  I get tons of compliments, but the taco seasoning that I make is much more flavorful than store bought which gives it an extra kick.  Everyone raves about this dish when I take it to potlucks.

text:
This was so easy and delicious!  I think the taco seasoning is the secret... I added a little extra due to previous comments, but I don't know if that was necessary.  Other changes: I used about 8 chicken strips instead of breasts, two cans black beans only (had them on hand), added about 1/4 c. pickled jalapenos, substituted 1 c. vegetable stock for beer (sadly, no brewski in the fridge), and cooked on high for 4 1/2 hours.  Just don't forget to drain and rinse the beans before adding them... it makes a big difference in my opinion.  The chicken was indeed tender enough to break up with a ladle at the end while just stirring the soup.  This is a keeper recipe for my new slow cooker!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this 4 times and love it. I haven't used beer (hubby would kill me if I "wasted" a beer in food) so I have been using chicken stock. I use the Bill Echol's taco seasoning recipe (but reduce the Cumin by half subsequent times as my family isn't a big fan of that spice). I have tried it with a few different bean combinations and I think the best is a can of black beans and a can of mixed beans (red kidney, garbanzo, black eyed peas and romano beans). Hubby wanted it to be thicker, like chili instead of soup, so the last time I substituted the tomato sauce with tomato paste and drained the beans half-way to reduce the liquid and it worked well. We serve with sour cream, fresh cilantro and Old Dutch Sea Salt & Lime tortilla scoop chips and it is fantastic! This is my favourite slow cooker recipe.

I, like others, was hesitant on the beer in the recipe but no hesitation now. I typically like the brothy tortilla soup and this has less broth and still so flavorfull! I used trader joes frozen corn because to me it tastes like fresh corn, added juice of 1 lime, 3 chopped tomatoes and added cilantro. I also used the seasoning mix suggested by the submitter (under highest rated reviews) and it makes a HUGE difference. Packaged taco seasoning is overwhelming and I rarely use. Thanks for the soup recipe and the taco seasoning recipe!

This was excellent. I was not very confident about this recipe initially because it was my first crockpot endeavor and most of the ingredients are canned, which made me fear that this was going to taste like canned soup.  I also used packaged taco mix and frozen chicken breasts in this recipe.  It was fast enough for me to put together between school and work (20 minutes to eat lunch and prepare dinner) and when I got home from work, the entire apartment smelled like delicious chili.  I served it with tortilla chips and homemade guacamole and it was fabulous.  My boyfriend liked it, too, so it is definitely going into the rotation.  Perfect for a rainy day in Seattle, but I can see it shining as a summer potluck chili, too.

text:
One of our favorite soups.  I made it many times and adjust it with what I have in my pantry.  I always use Bill Erohls taco seasoning recipe.  I mainly use black beans-drained and canned or frozen corn, Rotel and diced tomatoes and chicken broth vs. beer.  I like the taste better with broth than beer.  I surround the crock pot with bowls of chopped cilantro, cheese, sour cream, chopped green onion and BBQ Frito's.  My family tops the soup with their fave combo's.  All my family and friends have asked and make this soup on a regular basis.  So very, very good and easy. Great for parties.  Cheap to make too.  I have used frozen chicken- breasts or tenders. Whatever I have on hand....dump and go.  Come home to a house filled with the smell of this soup.  MMM. Yum!

None
text:
This soup is really excellent!  I am only giving 4 stars because it can taste like chicken chili.  My way to get around this is to eliminate the chili beans and just use plain pinto beans.  Also I use 2 packages of taco seasoning or the equivalent of that in regular spices.  This is a crock pot absolutely full of ingredients.  It needs a lot of seasoning.  This makes the soup really taste like taco soup not chili.  The toppings of tortilla chips and sour cream is a must.  Awesome comfort food.

text:
I pretty much made this as the recipe stated and it was amazing.  I only had to change a couple of things based on what I had in the pantry.  I used Romano beans instead of black beans, and 1 can of Furmano's tomatoes-28 oz (from the States), 1 can of Primo Recipe Starters diced tomatoes with basil and garlic-not 28 oz, maybe 20 oz. (sounds gross, I know, but it's all I had and it worked) and a small can of Herdez salsa with green chilies-210 grams (7 ounces).  That's what I had on hand and the dish was a hit.  Will definitely make again.  Not sure why people thought the beer gave it a weird flavour, maybe they didn't cook it long enough???

I did place the chicken in a baggie with taco sauce and shook to season chicken then poured into crock pot with remaining taco sauce.  Very flavorful!! I think the reviewer who mentioned that there wasn't enough flavor must have had a week taco sauce because ours was perfect. update: I make this all the time.  I made it last week with beer as the recipe calls for and my husband likes it better with the beer.  You can't taste the alcohol after all the cooking.  I also now use the whole onion and again after slow cook of 5-7 hours it isn't so pungent.  We keep it in the fidge, warm helpings in microwave for many days.  Thanks for the recipe

text:
I make this soup religously now. It has become a wonderful addition to my meal planning! Thank you soooooo much for this one. I also use Bob E's Taco Seasoning (from the site). I use 1 and 1/2 cans of chicken broth, 2 8oz cans of tomato sauce, 2 cans of corn (drained), 1 can of Rotel, 1 can of black beans, 1 med onion (I use vidalia) 2 chicken breast, and plenty of seasoning. I probably make this soup twice a month. Top it off with sour cream and your favorite cheese, a little fresh cilantro, and jalapenos (if you like them) and YUMMY! The best part of this recipe is that it is just as good put back in the crock pot and reheated for lunch or dinner again the next day. Perfect!! Thank you so very much for this one!!

text:
This chicken taco soup is dynamite!!!  This recipe is perfect!  A + + + + + I used McCormick® Hot Taco Seasoning Mix from the local Meijer store.  Instead of regular chili beans, I used hot chili beans.  Since I'm on a budget, I used store brand can goods which turned out fine.  The corn chips shown in my photo are Trader Joe's Multigrain Tortilla chips, made from organic white corn and several different grains.  These chips are are a healthy alternative to Dorito's.  For those who need more heat, try adding your favorite hot sauce to your serving.  I made this taco soup twice, first using beer and the second time using chicken stock.  Both ways provided an excellent soup.  Along with the soup, I baked Grandmother's Buttermilk Cornbread, a very easy to make side dish from allrecipes.com.  What a wonderful dinner.  My wife and I loved the soup and cornbread and will have leftovers tomorrow night.

text:
I want to give this a 4.5, because the final result was delicious, especially the leftovers! However, I strongly recommend replacing the beer with broth, or maybe replacing half the beer with broth, unless you really want the soup to taste like beer. At the 5 hr mark I took a small taste and was really grossed out by the beer flavor, so I removed a few ladle-fulls of the liquid and added in a few ladle fulls of chicken broth. I'm really glad I did - this improved the flavor by a mile!

Initially I was disappointed because it was much more like a chili than I expected, but does have a very good flavor.  The cheese and sour cream really make it.  I made it exactly according to the recipe.  I just blended 1 1/2 of the cans of tomatoes because I don't like tomato chunks. text:
I always rate my recipes based on how fast my picky husband gobbles them up, and let me tell you, he LOVED this one! We even had leftovers for 2 more meals (just the 2 of us) and he NEVER eats leftovers! He even said the 2nd and 3rd meals were better than the 1st (think the flavors had more time to meld). I made this recipe exactly as written, using 1 Guinness bottle for the beer (I don't like to drink Guiness but I have 2 other recipes that I use it in and they turn out fantastic-- you absolutely cannot taste any beer once cooked). I also added sliced avocado on top when I served it. Definitely a keeper and great for a rainy weekend!

text:
WOW!  Seriously loved it!  Used RoTel Milder as my “diced tomatoes with green chilies” since my child can’t handle spice.  For taco seasoning I used Lawry’s brand.  I mixed sour cream and sharp cheddar in my child’s personal bowl before serving him (out of eyesight) so that I could shove a little extra dairy/calcium into him.  For a kid who despises beans, cheese, sour cream, tomatoes, and chilies, he ate three bowls full.  It is really that good!
I use a three-quart slow cooker and cut the recipe in half.  It fit perfectly into my machine.  The left-over ingredients after 1/2 –ed the recipe were frozen together so that I can make it easier next time (which I will be doing soon!) This recipe goes beyond five stars!  However, if I was making it just for myself I would have added a touch more spice.

text:
This is one of our favorite recipes!  Instead of making it in the slow cooker, I just boil the chicken in water until fully cooked, shred it, and add it to the rest of the ingredients in a pot on the stove.  It is done in about 45 minutes total!  The beer is not overpowering (I use Shiner Bock, since that is what we usually have).  I usually omit the onion, but it tastes great with or without it.  A little bit of sour cream and cheese top off the soup very nicely.  Definitely a perfect recipe for the cold weather!

text:
This is one of my favorite dinners to make!  I am a college student and it is so nice to toss everything in the crockpot before I leave in the morning and have dinner ready when I come home.  I have made this with chicken and beef (family member w/ chicken allergy).  When I did it with beef, I used a 3 lb roast that I trimmed off the fat cap cut into 4 medallions for even cooking.  I always use broth instead of beer (don't like the taste of beer).  I use kidney beans instead of chili beans and I drain and rinse all my beans.  I always add chili powder and smoked paprika, because the original recipe is not very spicy.  Also, I use frozen corn which I add right after I shred the chicken/beef and allow to warm.

text:
I have made this recipe several times and love it. I've made it with and without the beer and found I prefer it made with the beer, but it is important to not try and hurry the process or there is a funky beer aftertaste. Cook on low 6 hours, then remove chicken and shred, returning to slow cooker and continue another 2 hours or so. I use two large chicken breast filets, cut in half and one can of tomatoes with green chili's.

text:
Delicious soup for a rainy day. Everyone loved it and wanted to make this again.  Great feature that each person can customize with toppings. I measured/calculated each ingredient (No options).  = 21.8 calories/oz (wt) or 378 cal/cup. Total = 2270 calories in 5.5 cups, 103.9 oz (wt). I read all the fuss about the beer but I made this per the recipe using a dark Mexican beer as someone suggested. I used Modelo Negra and would absolutely use this again. The soup had a bit of a funky aroma during the early cooking but only when the lid was removed. That went away and the there was no beer taste, but the aroma in the room and the flavor was outstanding. The family commented how good it smelled and they couldn't wait to try it. Everyone loved this. I saw some comments about the seasoning. I used one packet of Taco Bell taco seasoning and a can of mixed chili beans in a mild sauce. The soup came out mild.  Would definitely recommend sticking with the recipe initially if you can. We served optional toppers including shredded cheese, light sour cream, sliced black olives, tortilla chips, and pickled jalapeno slices. Everyone added exactly what they wanted. This recipe is a keeper.

Display Name:
Donna P.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2104183.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A very good chili (or soup, if you prefer). I made the recipe exactly as stated, including using the beer. Don't change that part of the recipe; you simply cannot substitute chicken stock for beer and expect to get comparable results. The key is to use the right kind of beer. You don't want a light beer or an IPA here. Go for a dark Mexican beer like Modelo Negro. If you can pick up on the beer taste on the first day, rest assured that it will mellow out and basically disappear by the second day. If you're worried about it, don't use the full bottle. I also recommend draining one can of the Rotel tomatoes to eliminate a bit more of the liquid and make the "soup" more like chili. Delicious!

userID:

Display Name:
DanielleLyn
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/45218.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As Is, I give this recipe 4 stars.  But with modifications to fit our tastes, I give it 5 stars.  First this recipe filled my crockpot to the brim.  I did add in an extra can of tomato sauce, and instead of the beer did chicken stock.  I cooked this in the crock pot on high for 6 hours but since it was so full it never got nice and bubbly.  So the last several minutes I transferred it all to the stove to finish cooking and only cut up 2 of the large chicken breasts and it was perfect.  I did add a lot more seasoning to add more flavor like garlic powder, cilantro, parsley, etc.  And definitely garnished with the cheese, sour cream, and tortilla chips but I also think it needed a squeeze of lime and more cilantro on top.  With these additions it made it an amazing 5 star soup that we loved and will definitely make it again.  Thanks for the recipe!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2015-09-10T14:48:15.37

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We have made this recipe several times now and we changed one thing - used Limearita in place of Mexican beer! Oh that was good. It gives you the beer and the lime undertones. We've crock pot cooked it. We've added a bit of chicken broth to it, we've stove top cooked it. We've cut up the chicken to hasten the finish, being careful to cut it into chunks with the grain. This allowed us to shred it while maintaining the texture. We happen to like the flavor of jalapeno salt and we've added that at the end sometimes. When we made this the first time we used the Costco bulk taco seasoning. Now that we have her base recipe, which is fast to put together, we are hooked on it and have made a bulk container to use in place of the Costo brand. It really does take this recipe to the next level. We can make this stove-top method in an hour and a half. Happy potluckers! Thanks for a great combo of flavors.

city:
