region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an awesome, amazing, EASY recipe!  I did not use beer in the recipe and instead substituted in chicken stock in the amount of 10 ounces, simply because I had no beer on hand.  I also substituted in a can of mild enchilada sauce for the 8 oz. can of tomato sauce.  When I pulled the chicken breasts out of the crockpot and shredded them on the cutting board, I sprinkled the chicken with some cracked black pepper and Adobo without pepper (blue lid) before returning the shredded chicken to the soup.  I also added some Adobo to the soup and seasoned it to taste.  I used Bush's chili beans, Old El Paso taco seasoning, and found black beans that were pre-seasoned and corn that included mild green and red chilis in the Mexican food section of the grocery store.  I topped it off with shredded queso fresca with jalapenos as well as a dollop of sour cream and some crushed white corn tortilla chips.  Absolutely fantastic!

text:
I absolutely LOVED this dish! I did make some adjustments that I thought would be a better fit for me. Instead of the beer, I used 1 cup of water. I'm not big on eating beans, so I only used half a can of the chili beans and black beans (which was perfect for me). I don't like spicy food, so I only used regular diced tomatoes, and didn't get the can with green chilies included. To reduce sodium, I used tomato sauce and taco seasoning that was low in sodium. I was worried that my soup wouldn't be seasoned enough though given the water I added (and I only had one packet of taco seasoning), so I used the, "Taco Seasoning I" recipe that I found on this website and I think it added a perfect touch. Plus that recipe calls for red pepper flakes which gave my soup a mild kick that I knew I'd be okay with. I can't say enough about this dish. You MUST try it with the sour cream and cheese. It was the cherry on the cake. My tummy is happy. :)

This was just okay. I added toppings such as shredded cheese, sour cream and tortilla strips. The beer was a bit overpowering. Also, the recipes calls for 3 whole skinless chicken breasts which I thought would be too much so I reduced it to 2 breasts. It was still way too much chicken for the amount of liquid that this recipe makes. i will definitely make it again but I will cut the chicken down even more, add extra corn and beans and cut the beer in half or eliminate it all together and add chicken broth in it's place.

text:
Excellent recipe! I had to make a couple of substitutions based on what I had on hand: I didn't have tomato sauce, but I had an 8 oz can of chipotle sauce -- definitely kicked it into high gear, so not for the heat sensitive crowd. I didn't have chili beans, but had a can of charro beans to add along with the (drained, rinsed) black beans. I frequently find cooking with beer adds a bitter/metallic taste to the food, but I tempered it by adding some shredded carrot and a tsp of baking soda to counter the acidity, and it was awesome. Don't skip the beer! topped with cilantro, green onions, cheese, tortillas and sour cream for a fantastic meal. Thanks, Patti!

This recipe was great. Everyone loved it, including our 4yr old. While I tried to follow the recipe exactly, I was limited to what I had in the house, so some of the sizes weren't exact.. text:
This recipe is AMAZING! Please do not omit the beer because you don't think you like beer.  The beer adds a totally deeper taste to this soup! I used Corona and cooked it in the soup on the stove top since I didn't have time to slow cook this.  I also used Taco Seasoning 1 recipe by Bill Echols on this site which was delightful! Overall, this is my new go to Mexican Soup recipe I'll use from now on! My husband LOVED this and now calls it Corona Soup :)

Absolutely wonderful.  DH gave me soooo many compliments on this.  It was super easy and quick to pull together and I let it simmer for 3 hours on the stove top.  Used 3 leftover broasted chicken breasts and it was the perfect amount of meat.  Had "bold" taco seasoning mix from Penzey's and used just over 4 tablespoons.  Perfect spice.  Served with hot cornbread of course.  Thanks for sharing.  6/17/14

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/3055.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So easy so good!!  For the beer I used Guiness.  Instead of 2 cans of Rotel, I used one can and one can of petite diced tomatoes.  For the taco seasoning I took the author's suggestion of:  (1 T Chili Powder, 1/4 teaspoon each of garlic powder, onion powder, crushed red pepper flakes and oregano, 1/2 teaspoon of paprika, 1 1/2 teaspoons cumin and 1 teaspoon each of salt and pepper).  I cooked on low for 4 hours, shredded the chicken, added a can of cream of chicken soup and a small amount of water with a T of cornstarch to thicken it a little and cooked another 2 hours.  Thank you for the recipe it is a keeper in our house.

text:
Just threw this together before I went to work. I only had diced tomatoes with basil and garlic, I used it anyway. I only had 2 cans of black beans, used them. Large can tomato sauce. I added Guiness dark stout and cut up a few hot peppers I had frozen from the year before. I also made my own taco seasoning from a recipe I found on Allrecipes.com.  I like that much better, no junk just spices and herbs. I also added 1 cup chicken broth and 1 tsp Better than Boullion chicken seasoning.  Two bone in breasts gave more than enough meat.  It smelled so good  when I got home!  My son ate 3 bowls and told me how tasty the soup was.  This went into my recipe box!

None
text:
I have made this more than once. I swapped out the tomato sauce for green chili sauce. Use organic ingredients, especially for the taco seasoning so you're not getting MSG. The beer adds flavor, the alcohol cooks out (in response to someone avoiding beer because it was for work). Sometimes you have to play around with a recipe to match your own taste desires.
Use organic for the beans too to avoid BPA lining. Edens' Organic does not use BPA lining. Or soak your own dried beans.

text:
This soup turned out great.  This recipe is definitely a keeper :) 
I know a few reviews said the taste was "off" from using beer, but I used Modelo beer and couldn't taste it at all.  (Maybe other reviewers didn't cook long enough for the alcohol to cook off?)  
Also, I only used 2 chicken breasts as many people recommended, and there was PLENTY of chicken.  I think 3 might have been overwhelming. 
PS: All of my canned ingredients were low/no sodium, salt free or no added salt & it was an AWESOME decision!  I figured there was enough salt in the Taco seasoning packet & I didn't want it to be too salty.

text:
We really liked this easy recipe.  I pretty much followed directions other than using pinto beans instead of the chili beans and since we are not big beer flavor fans I used chicken broth.  Ok, so maybe that is a major change to the base flavor!  I put frozen chicken breasts in the crock pot on low for close to 8 hours since it was overnight and then shredded it and it was perfect.  I think I will do one can of tomatoes with chilis and one plain next time b/c it was a bit spicy for the kids (used Rotel with chilis, lime, and cilantro).  I added a little dry cilantro to it as well.  Sour cream and chips is a must!  Update:  I made this with the beer instead of the chicken broth and the family didn't like it nearly as much.  I'll stick with the chicken broth from now on.

text:
Absolutely enjoyed making this and LOVED each bite. To add more umph I added chopped celery and fresh diced tomatoes. I'm not a huge fan of sour cream and I like to keep my meals light, so I used non-fat plain greek yoghurt as a topping (it really rounds out the flavors) and a dash of sriracha sauce. I also didn't have 7 hours to cook this, so I put it on high, and halved the cooking time. So 2.5-3 hours on high to cook the chicken, then once cooled and shredded, another 1-1.5 hours. Seriously amazing stuff. Thanks for sharing!

Superb!! It is so good!! Cook it strictly to the recipe, superb. Vary a bit, still superb. I would not leave out the beer (as some have suggested) because I think it might be like leaving out the chicken broth in some other recipes. It is the heart of the meal, this tasty broth, so just leave as is and meditate on the earth's sea water, a complex frothy mix that you just really can't separate. Anyway, I'm cooking it now as I write, it puts me in a good mood, always.

Very good slow cooker meal! I also used two large chicken breasts (probably about 1 lb) and a Bud Light Lime (the lime flavor worked out well in this dish).  It was a little spicy for my 10 y/o daughter, but she just added sour cream to bring it down a notch.  Definitely will make again!

text:
Unlike other reviews, I found no overwhelming beer taste... Perhaps it's because I used a quality Belgian wheat instead of a cheap gut-rot inducing beer.  I totally skipped the chiles (mainly because I skimmed over the ingredients when putting together) and added instead  a mix of cumin, chili powder, can of tomato paste, and a touch of cayenne half way thru.  
Gave a nice heat and nice aroma as it simmered.  Used 2 chicken breasts and found that to be more than enough. This turned out more like a thick chili than a soup.  I recommend to use frozen corn instead of canned, much better taste. All in all it was easy to toss together and was easy to spice up to my liking.  Will make this one again for sure.

city:

country:
None
text:
I love this recipe and it's a regular meal for us. I just slightly change it. I do not use the beer for one. I bake my chicken with seasoning, and drizzle olive oil on it. Then after chicken cools I shred chicken and then start the soup in my croc pot. I salute my onion, about a half of a red, orange or yellow bell pepper, a jalapeno (you can use more or less of jalapeno) depending how hot you like) and minced garlic in a small fry pan with olive oil. Then I place ingredients I added and omit the beer into the croc. I use the rotillo tomatoes and chiles that is the "mexican" style one with lime and cilantro. Very yummy! I tried to add a pic, this site is not very photo friendly...

text:
DELICIOUS...EASY...and HARD TO MESS UP...for example, today I didn't have black beans, I used garbonzo instead....still came out AWESOME.  I love a dash of lime juice in the end...totally makes the soup.  Last week I had fresh cilantro....DELICIOUS....(cilantro turned rotten this week so did without) and still delicious.  I always use one can diced tomatoes w/ chili's vs. 2 just because the kids freak out about the spice.  Still spicy but not as bad.  We're broke this week and I'm still trying to avoid unnecessary/cheaper carbs (ie bread/pasta) so this recipe works great for rough times and good times.  Never used beer, but when it's in the house I'll use it if it's readily available.  Sometimes I only have 2.5hrs on HIGH.  Sometimes all day....still comes out AWESOME.

Full of flavor and easy. I changed a couple of things, but not because the recipe needed it, just my personal preference. Omitted the tomato sauce and beer. Added a can of chicken broth and some extra water towards the end. One of the cans of Rotel was hot.  The soup ended up being pretty hot, but good with the sour cream on top. My chicken breast weren't thawed. I put them on top of all and they cooked up beautifully. I like to start the crock pot on high to get it going, then after an hour or so, I'll turn it back down to low.

text:
This recipe turned out delicious! I would also have to say it's been the easiest slow cooker recipe I've made. I've only made 4 so far, but I honestly think it couldn't get easier than opening a few cans, a bottle of beer, and throwing in a few extra ingredients! I cooked mine on high for 3hrs, shredded the chx, and then continued cooking on high for about 45mins. I made the soup with Heineken (there was ZERO "beer" flavor so it was great). I also added 2 garlic cloves, 1/2 tsp cumin, 1/2 tsp cayenne pepper, and some cilantro. I wish I added MORE cilantro because I couldn't really taste it at all. Next time :) Served with tortilla chips, cheddar, and sour cream. Definitely a hit with my boyfriend...which makes me feel great!

text:
This is a favorite at our house. After reading the previous reviews, I've made a couple of changes.  I use 12 oz of chicken broth in place of the beer, and I use 2 (1 oz) packages of taco seasoning instead of just one at 1.25 oz.  We also like this soup with flour tortillas torn up in it.  I also cook mine all day while I'm at work (8+ hours) and then come home to shred the chicken.  It's always been fine, not overcooked.  This is a great recipe! I've made this for my co-workers and they LOVED it.  Definitely worth trying.

text:
This is no exaggeration... my husband warned me that he “hated” tortilla soup when I told him this was cooking in the crockpot yesterday.  I guess he later felt bad for his harsh words after my efforts… so as a peace offering, he offered to taste it as long as I understood that his dislike for this recipe would be directed to the food and not my cooking.  With a smirk on my face, I made him a tiny, sample size bowl.  Well, he loved, loved, loved it!  He made himself bowl after bowl after bowl, and made constant “yummy” noises!  Then he called his mom to tell her I would email her the recipe, then he asked if one day I could make a batch for him to take to work! Today he took leftovers to work which is also out of character for him!  This recipe was so extremely easy too!  I used the home-made taco seasoning recipe instead of the packaged taco seasoning, which I think made it over-the-top delicious.  I also didn’t use beer, but plan to try it next time.  This recipe is now going to be my signature dish!

text:
Great recipe! To tie the taco theme all together, top with shredded low fat Mexican cheese, crushed corn tortilla chips, and...cilantro! Served this to a group of friends and the consensus was that cilantro was a great addition, it adds a new element of flavor. This recipe is easy to modify to make it even healthier - choose low fat or low sodium options wherever possible (taco seasoning, I'm looking at you). Also don't be afraid to go off the path a bit and add your own ingredients. I added cumin, turmeric, chili powder, pepper, and a jalapeno to give it some kick. 5 stars!

text:
Started this before I left for work yesterday.  Set the crock pot on low for 5 hours, keep warm for 5 hours.  When I came home, I gave it a stir, shredded/cut up the chicken, put it on high while I gathered the cheddar, cream cheese, and tortilla chips and set out bowls.  At first I thought it might be a little on the salty side (must have been the taco seasoning I used - Chi Chi's, won't use again) but with the addition of the sour cream, it was just perfect!  My husband loved it, too.  Had left overs today (makes a LOT!) and it was even better.  I will definitely be making this again.  Simple and really tasty!  Filling, too.

text:
***I HATE BEER*** but I tried this anyway and loved it!!  I made the following modifications: 6oz can tomato paste w/ 2oz water instead of 8oz tomato sauce b/c that's what I had - homemade taco seasoning instead of a packet (any of the ones on this site are good, just make SURE you watch how much red pepper goes in b/c that's where the heat comes from) - Rotel diced tomatoes *lime juice & cilantro* instead of *green chilies* and for the beer I used Dos Equis (one 12oz bottle).  I cooked on high for 4hrs.  It was perfect... my kids (6 & 3) ate two helpings!

city:

country:
None
text:
YUMM-ALICIOUS! Made this recipe for myself and a friend who had a hip replacement and she liked it so much, she has asked for the recipe twice. She stated she likes foods that have several levels of flavor and seasoning and this one hit the mark. My tastes run a bit simpler, but I enjoyed it a lot...so much so that it will be in my regular soup rotation. Even though I am a Texan and I love my Tex-Mex...I am a bit of a wimp when it comes to "heat" and this one was not too spicy for me. Of course, your mileage may vary!

I used Bill Echols Taco Seasoning and followed the recipe to a "T" with one exception...I substituted a can of beef broth for the beer. 

I served it with mild cheddar cheese...freshly grated. Do yourself a favor and grate your own cheese...makes a big difference!

I ran it through the WW Point calculator and based on the nutritional info provided...with no substitutions, it came out to 11 PointsPlus per cup.

text:
I used stewed Mexican style tomatoes (halves, not diced) because that's what I had on hand. Also Only had the regular sized 14.5 oz can of tomato sauce so I used the entire can. The beer we keep on hand is Coors Light so that's generally what I put in crockpot recipes. Turned out great. I don't like tomatoes so was good to be able to pick around them! I also cooked on high for half the time and was still great. Husband loved it and he usually turns his nose up at soup. Not that spcy but probably due to the lack of chiles in the tomatoes. Also, read some poor reviews saying they could only taste the beer. Not to be contrary, but there is no way you would taste the beer seperately from the other ingredients unless you did something wrong. Awesome fall meal!!

country:
None
text:
This soup is amazing! I followed the ingredients and directions for the most part but made a few changes. I didn't drain any of the canned foods such as the corn and beans. I used a low sodium chicken broth instead of the suggested ingredient, beer. I made it with Heineken last time and it was alright, but it was much tastier with chicken broth. Instead of the soup smell I smelt beer all day long, and it wasn't a very good beer smell. Low sodium broth was great and it didn't make the soup very salty at all, just right actually. I used a whole packet of taco seasoning as suggested but went with low sodium as well. The soup was good enough not to have sour cream, cheese, and tortilla crushed on top but we did have tortilla chips to dip with. We adjusted the recipe to 8 servings. Enjoy!

text:
Phenomenal! This was tasteful and delicious.
This makes a ton of soup! I used three chicken breasts, which was plenty. I also used an Old El Paso burrito seasoning mix because I didn't have any taco, and that was great. I added chicken broth instead of the beer, and I think that if I had left it out, this would have been more like a chili. The diced tomatoes, tomato sauce, and the natural juices from the chicken would have been enough. I'll leave out the broth next time. Also, to cut down on the sodium content, I will rinse the beans before adding. Used HOT chili beans, and that added some oomph. Great recipe!!

I loved the flavor of this soup. I followed some suggestions and used Bill Echol's Taco Seaoning recipe from this site. I also took 4 white flour tortillas, basted both sides with lime juice and sprinkled sea salt on them. Delicious!

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Loved it!  This dish was easy to prepare and a hit with the whole family.  It's really a "chicken" chili, but just a bit lighter and just enough variation to alternate with other Tex Mex menus.  It'll definitely be in our rotation, especillay for the winter months.  I made it using a 2.5 lb bag of frozen chicken tenders.  I doubled everything else except the diced tomatoes since my son doesn't like too much chunky tomato.  I put the frozen tenders in after everything else was mixed in the crockpot.   The chicken was ready to shred after 5 hours on low.  My crew was so anxious to eat that we only let it simmer another 1 hr before eating and everyone enjoyed.  I used the homemade taco seasoning recommended below and it was plenty tasty and spicy.  We'll use it going forward rather than pre-packaged stuff.  BTW, I DID include the beer....happened to have a local brew on hand, Billy's Chilies (from Boulder, CO) which turned out to be the perfect complement.   But, just in case, I only added one bottle along with 12 oz water.  I'll definitely use beer again, but then I've been adding beer to my chili for many years and folks have always loved it!  I do think, however, that the beer you choose will either work with the soup OR stand out unfavorably, so choose carefully.  I keep a few varieties on hand to use in Tex Mex dishes and BBQ pork.  Anyway, don't give up on the beer...it can enhance!!

country:

text:
I made this soup today, but on the stove top instead of the crockpot...didn't have enough time for the crockpot. It came out with less liquid I'm sure because some cooked off in the pot whereas no liquid cooks off in the crockpot. When I first took a taste right out of the pot, I wasn't sure what I thought of the broth. I did substitute chicken broth as I don't keep beer on hand. It had plenty of zing..no problem there. I used Rotel tomatoes & plenty of the good taco seasoning everyone talks about on here. I think the different flavor was because I didn't rinse my beans, it just gives a different flavor. All that liquid from cooking beans is full of nutrients!  

Anyway, then I got the idea this would be great on brown rice. I took some cooked brown rice out that I keep in the freezer, thawed in the microwave & scooped the soup/stew over it & it was WONDERFUL. Not to mention one plate was so filling! It ended up being lunch & dinner. 

I think this will be a go to recipe for me as I have been trying to eat a lot more rice & beans. Beans are at the top of this list right under veggies & fruits to have the highest vitamins & minerals for the lowest calories. So they are a perfect food to fill up on!

text:
My husband pretty much lost his mind when I served this!  I haven't seen him enjoy a soup this much in FOREVER!  lol   I did some of the mods suggested: broth instead of beer, added cumin, more taco seasoning AND I accidentally opened a can of plain dicded tomatoes, so I added them in there as well. I think also the next time, I will dice up some onions from my garden to add in there.   Instead of  tortilla chips, I cut flour tortillas into strips with the pizza cutter and floated them on top of the soup with the cheese.  It added a nice texture to the soup, like an enchilada ...  Will be making this again per request!

text:
This soup was great.  I did make Bill Echols taco seasoning. It was too easy not to. Used chicken broth instead of the beer.  I used 1 can diced tomatoes with green chilies and 1 can Rotel with habaneros. Omitted the tomato sauce because I didn't want the thickness it would give. Topped it off with cheese, sour cream and chips. Next night I drained off the liquid and used the meat and beans rolled in flour tortilla's topped with cheese and heated in oven till cheese was melted. Yummy.

text:
Made this for a soup-cookoff at work and won!!  Everyone loved it.  I made it pretty much as is - expcept I did rinse the kidney beans and I added a can of rinsed black beans.  I drained the liquid from the corn.  I also used two cans of fire roasted diced tomatoes that had chilies in them - instead of two cans regular diced tomatoes and and a can of chilies.  Like others I added a package of Hidden Valley Ranch dressing - but I used the Spicy variety which added to the "kick".  The tortilla chips, cheese and sour cream topped it off.  I added less water than it called for because I like think soup.  A little less than a can.

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was excellent and so easy! I decided to make it on my lunch break from work and take it an hour's drive that night. I had most of the ingredients on hand and made it in a 4-quart crockpot that was filled. I used one chicken breast and one tender (anything more would have been too much for my pot), dried onion, only one can of diced tomatoes (with basil and oregano... used Rotel sauce with chilies) and left out the beer. I used chicken bullion and water to compensate for leaving the beer out, but I would've been okay without it - just a little more like a chili. I also added a Hidden Valley ranch seasoning packet and a dash of chili powder and I think it gave it more flavor. I cooked on low for 5 hours, shredded the chicken, then drove 1.5 hours with it and cooked it on high for another hour or so. I ate it with crackers and shredded cheese.

This tasted amazing and was so easy to make. It got rave reviews... Perfect for a cold rainy day! It would be great to make in big batches and freeze or to customize using different beans.

Loved it!!! I followed the recipe almost to the letter. I used chicken stock instead of the beer due to niece being a new nursing mother. Next time I will use the beer. Cooked it for 2 1/2 hrs on high because I started late. Turned it to low and shredded the chicken. Cooked for 2 more hours. After letting it cool, put in refrigerator for the next day. 
The next day heated a serving as the rest was going to niece's house. It tasted too sweet to me. I do not know if it was the corn, tomato sauce or what. Anyway, I added 3 soup spoons of liquid from a jar of Tostitos Restaurant Style Salsa - medium. Once it was warmed, I added the sour cream and ate it with taco chips. It was perfect. YUM YUM!!!

OMG!!!! This is the best recipe I've ever tried from this website and quite possibly from the entire internet! The soup tastes incredible and even looks incredible. I had nearly everything right in my pantry so no trips to the store for any ingredients that you'd use once and then never use again.  I only made 2 modifications but only because I knew they wouldn't impact flavor.  I used 2 cans of black of beans (that's all I had in the pantry) and since I didn't have the canned tomatoes with chilies, I used two 10 ounce cans of tomato sauce and a can of chopped chilies.  Perfect!  I also used Patti's recipe for the seasoning - again, I had it all right in the pantry anyway.  The flavor of this soup is so fabulous!  I used Molson beer as that's what was in the refrig for our superbowl party but I think any decent beer would be fine.  I would stay away from heavier beers but the Molson did not give it any kind of "off" taste as a few others have mentioned.  I thought it was fabulous just as is.  I know this review is long, but I just can't say enough wonderful things about the soup.  I can't wait to make it again!!  I'd give this soup 10 stars if I could!  And Patti -- I'm going to be following all the recipes that you post from now on!!!  Thanks for this keeper!

VERY BUDGET FRIENDLY!!! OMG!!!! This was sooooo Good!
I added an extra can of corn & an extra can of Chili Beans Plus chicken Broth. That way it would Fill up both my 2.5 quart Crockpots. I think it would even be Good With rice added too if your on a Budget. I Used Frozen Boneless Chicken thighs to cook in the crockpot.
 I also added More Meat From an 4 pieces of Fried chicken at the last minute too for some extra protien.
so Freaking good!

text:
I agree with the others who said to use chicken stock instead of beer. The beer gives it a funny taste so I strained it and added canned chicken stock. I added some fresh onion when I ate it rather than while cooking it and topped it with sharp cheddar cheese. Was delicious. I made baked corn chips and ate some with the soup. Will definitely be making this again.

Easy and delicious! I made it per directions with a few minor changes. I added a can of red kidney beans and a stalk of celery, used chicken broth (not beer) and after shredding the chicken I decided to add fresh cauliflower. I think this is a very forgiving recipe and I will use it again and again. It tastes even better the next day and I froze some to share with my mom the next time I visit.

text:
I think turned out really good!  I also think it's more like 10 servings...not 8 serving.  With this division to 10 servings....this is 5 Weight Watchers Points (on the 2012 Points Plus Program).  Lots of flavor - you don't need to waste calories on the cheese or the tortillas or the sour cream.
 
RECIPE CHANGES:
* I added two diced green zuccinis. 
* I drained and rinsed the black beans - not sure if you were supposed to, but I did.
* I did NOT drain the chili beans - not sure if you were supposed to, but I did NOT.
* Used Coors Light

text:
Wow! I made this today and when I came home, I could smell it from the driveway!!
We couldn't wait to dig in! 

I made it soupy not chili-like. I kept the oregano, but I also added extra cumin and extra broth... I added chili powder and some smoked paprika (our favorite spice!). I only used 1 can of tomatoes/green chilis because it's usually too spicy for our kids. I used Bud light lime, because it's what I had on hand.
My husband, who is the very best chef I know, said it is now his very favorite soup! Now THAT'S a compliment!

I had a hard time debating on how many stars to rate this.  I absolutely HATE beer, and I do not know too much about it.  I used whatever beer I had in my fridge the first time I made it.  BIG MISTAKE i guess.  It was Bud Light, and now Im reading some reviews that say the type of beer makes the difference.  Well then that should have been stated in the recipe, because it turned out quite disgusting for us.  We could clearly taste the beer.  Well my husband didn't know I put it in, but he asked what the weird taste was and after I told him he said he could taste it and refused to eat it.  I tried with the chicken broth the next time and it was DELICIOUS!!! 5 stars delicious.  But I am rating it 3 stars because I feel it deserves criticism for not being specific on the beer.  I personally will not try with beer anymore because the chicken broth was so good.  It is one of our favorite meals!!!  BTW if i rated this on how it tasted with the beer I would probably rate it a 1 star or 2.  Thats how nasty it was to us.

country:
None
text:
This is the most amazing soup recipe on this website! KUDOS! However, I do make a few changes just based on my own personal preferences; I add a chopped green bell pepper and about 3 minced garlic cloves, only half of an onion, I use pinto beans instead of kidney beans, and I use about 1 cup of chicken stock instead of the bottle of beer (I made it with beer the first time and it made a lot of "broth" - the flavor, however, is not much different). Also, I add whatever spices sound good that morning; garlic salt, cumin, paprika, chili powder, etc. Overall an AMAZING recipe! If my crock pot was larger, I'd double it every time!

text:
This soup is really good and got really good reviews from everyone that ate it.  I'll definitely make it again.  I made the following changes to this recipe:  added 1 can of pinto beans, 1/2 can of low-sodium chicken broth, two tablespoons of chopped jalapeno, 2 cloves of garlic, 4-5 drops of tapatio, pinch of salt & pepper and instead of taco seasoning, I used cumin and chili powder.  I also served it with shredded cheese, chopped green onion and 5-layer bean dip.  With the addition of these items, I would definitely give it a 5*.

text:
I just made this today...and we will be sitting down to eat in less than a half hour and I have tasted it, and tried to doctor it up and honestly am not looking forward to serving this to my husband! I have a MUCH better chicken chili recipe, and this is more chili than taco soup...but is far inferior to the straight up chili recipe. Like other reviewers have said....it doesn't even make the house smell good, like most (all) slow cooker recipes. Furthermore I used Miller beer (which is not even very beer-y) and I can taste/smell the strong beer scent (and I LOVE beer cheese soup) but this is off putting. I will NOT be making this again...and am some what bewildered as to what I will do with 8 servings! (probably more now since I put in some chicken stock to dilute the strong beer taste). :(

Rating:

dateLastModified:
2011-08-11T15:59:09.467
helpfulCount:

userID:
1037986
Display Name:
OkinawanPrincess
isPro:
False
followersCount:
220
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
513
favoritesCount:
2438
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/661917.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A very flavorful, easy soup. I was serving two people so I had to scale back on the amount. I added 3 T of homemade "Taco Seasoning I", from this website, with chopped onions and 2 cloves of fresh, chopped garlic. Instead of 1 can of whole kernel corn I used 4 fresh, sweet corn on the cob. I added the can of GOYA black beans, rinsed, 1 can Rotel diced tomatoes with green chiles and a can of chili with beans. I chose to use a 6 ounce can of tomato paste with a little chicken stock in place of the 8 oz. can of tomato sauce. I was looking for a nice hearty soup, not too thin but with a little more thicker consistency. The tomato paste made the soup a darker red color and didn't change the taste-only helped to thickened up a bit. I threw in a sprig of cilantro for flavor. I poured Corona into the crock pot and placed in 2 chicken breasts which I pressed down into the sauce. The aroma was so wonderful as this was cooking that it made my mouth water. This soup is not watery, but tasty and hearty with just the right amount of beans and fresh sweet corn. The chicken was so tender-it fell apart. The seasoning was just right, not too spicy -thanks to Bil Echols for his taco seasoning recipe.  Before serving the soup, I removed the cilantro. I served the soup with a dollop of sour cream, a squeeze of lime juice, and cilantro for garnish. A match was made in heaven with this soup and "Absolute Mexican Cornbread, from this website. (The cornbread is very sweet and tasty by the way.)

This is a keeper! I made the recipe exactly as written and it was delicious. I love a recipe where the only real prep is chopping an onion and opening some cans. I used Corona for the beer even though I'm not a beer fan, and could definitely taste it but in a very good way - I think it gives an extra something that chicken broth wouldn't. Perfect with crushed tortilla chips and sour cream, and if you get tired of soup leftovers, it is thick enough that you can strain the broth out of some of it for brilliant taco or enchilada filling. Love it - thanks!

text:
This was very tasty!  i took a lot of the reviewers advice and used 12 oz of chicken broth instead of beer (even though i love beer :) i followed the recipe almost completely, except i rinsed and drained both cans of beans, and i also added one small can of herdez salsa(along with the two cans of diced tom. w/grn chilies).  i also added garlic and cilantro, because i had some and i love it!  topped with shredded mexican blend cheese and crumbled tortilla chips.  very tasty indeed!  in a pinch, this could be made on the stove with shredded canned chicken, though in the crock pot the flavors have a nice long time to marry.....yum!  Thanks for the recipe!  This would be great camping!

text:
This recipe was incredible. We followed the recipe and made a few slight changes. Instead of beer I used a can of chicken broth. Beer just didnt sound good to me in this dish. The cans of diced tomatoes and chilies can be found in your local grocery store, its a can with both of them combined, we bought the Rotel MILD brand of tomatoes with green chilies because we are not big fans of spicy foods. This provided just enough mild spice. I used onion powder because I didn't have an onion in the fridge, but I am sure this does not make much of a difference. We used the Ortega taco seasoning brand. We didnt use any sour cream or tortilla chips, but when you serve it, top it with some shredded cheddar cheese. This makes the dish.  Other than that I made the recipe exactly as shown, other than the fact that I cooked it on a higher setting in about half the time because I was not home all day.  We ate it up and it was DELICIOUS. Definitely will be making this again and have shared the recipe with others. THANKS!!

text:
I have now made this twice.  The first time was some time back and I remember it tasting very beery.  I decided to try it again and this time it was great!  Not beery at all.  I used Bud Light (not sure what I used the 1st time so that could be the difference) and "mild" Rotel tomatoes with green chilies.  Wow, it is spicy, but not too much for us!  I used Ancho chili powder which is a mild to medium spicy chili.  Honestly, I don't think I would change a thing.  We used greek yogurt in place of the sour cream and that cut the spiciness just enough for us.  The only other thing I would suggest is to serve with diced avocados on top!  That would really smooth this out.  Thanks for a great recipe!  One other thing...I did use Bill Echols taco seasoning mix.

This one is definitely a keeper, at least as far as my mad for Tex-Mex food husband is concerned. I made it exactly as described except that for "chili beans" I subbed pinto beans. Also, it wasn't specified in the recipe, but I did drain the beans as I find the pot likker from black beans particularly can be rather unwholesome in appearance. "Beer" is rather a broad category, I used our favorite American style lager (Yuengling Traditional) which is similar in taste and appearance to some Mexican beers.

text:
Great recipe.  I had to improvise with what I had on hand.  I made this on the stove because I used a rotisserie chicken that I shred.  I didn't use  beer because I'm not a big fan of the taste.  I didn't really want a soup and wanted something more like chili, so I only replaced the beer with half a can of chicken stock.  I also sauteed the onions and a red pepper with fresh garlic that I chopped up for extra taste and texture.  I only used a 14.5oz can of diced tomatoes with mild green chilies (that still had a decent kick).  I omitted the tomato sauce.  It sounds like a lot of changes, but it was all very minor stuff.  After 2hrs on the stove on low....my husband loved it!  The recipe has a lot of flexibility, and is so easy and good.

text:
This is a wonderful, family friendly, healthy dish!  I was concerned about adding beer to the recipe, but it gave it a little something extra my husband just couldn't put his finger on.  Ironic, since it was his beer.  We ate ours with a dollop of sour cream and a few minced onions.  For leftovers the next day, I added some white rice and strained the extra broth so it wouldn't be too soupy and make burritos.  The reincarnation as a burrito was received heartily by my sons and husband.  I love this recipe.  It makes me appear to be a better cook than I am.

text:
This soup was very good.  Because we like our food spicy, I took others advice and added some extra spices, habenero sauce, etc., yet it was still too tame for us.  Next time I think I will add jalapenos and even more habenero sauce.  I cooked it even longer than the directions stated and it was pretty good.  One note: I used my old stand by, Rival crockpot, and there was so much, it barely fit to close the lid!  I ended up having to remove some of the contents so the soup could cook properly in the crockpot.  After it had cooked down some, I was able to add what I had removed back into the crockpot.  Overall, good soup!

text:
Very good.  Followed the recipe exactly with the exception of the cooking time (ran on high for 3 hours, low for 2).  I did use the beer since we really like its flavor.  Garnished with cilantro, which seemed to go really well with the beer flavor.  One negative note- I used the recommended taco seasoning recipe: Bill Echols Taco Seasoning.  Found it to be bland and ended up adding an additional 1 T cumin, pepper, and about 1 T chipolte chili powder to make it spicy.  Truthfully I'd probably give it 4.5 stars and will definitely make again.

I omit the corn and instead of the package of taco seasoning I use Bill Eschol's taco seasoning from this site. text:
This recipe is simple, quick and tasty!!! I followed the recipe to a 'T' except I omitted the beer, I hate beer and according to a lot of the reviews the beer is very potent in this recipe. I followed another reviewers suggestion and sauteed the onions before I added them to the crock pot. I don't remember how long it took to fully cook but it was well worth the wait. Also I added some ground pepper, sea salt and chili powder to suit my taste. Overall very good recipe! Prep it, set it, go and come home to a complete hardy meal! I plan to eat it with some homemade cornbread. Thanks for sharing!

This recipe saved the day!  I had my husband throw everything in the crockpot and set it on low for about 7 hours.  Took the lid off, shredded the chicken, and it was ready to go!  We didn't use a can of chili beans and only used 2 large chicken breasts.  Used the taco seasoning from the most helpful review (I think Bill Echols) and it tasted perfect!!  Reminded me a lot of Catherine's Spicy Chicken Soup from this site which I love- especially after mixing in sour cream and cheese.  Didn't have chips but it was still great.  Can't wait to have it for lunch!

text:
Did this on the stove in 1/2 hr.   My husband and I liked it.  My two older children liked it.  The other littler ones did not. It is still good with some corn chips. I modified the recipe to use what I had, but the ingredients were all in there or close... I used 1 jar of salsa (mild) and no beer...just chicken broth that had just gotten done on the stove...added the spices as suggested by reviewer, packet of frozen corn, and beef and bean chili leftovers about 4 cups. Added some shredded chicken and mixed  together.  Heated through in a pot and Voila...dinner within 1/2 hr. Served with corn chips, sour cream and cheddar cheese.  Very filling hearty meal.
8/27/11
Made again.  Omitted beer, but all the other ingredients were added.  Quick and tasty!

text:
It's so hot here in the summer (108 yesterday) that I try to use my slow cooker on the patio whenever I can to keep from heating up the house. I tried this yesterday with a couple of changes - chicken broth rather than beer and extra diced tomatoes instead of tomato sauce (too hot to drive to the store). Thought it needed a little extra flavor, so added cumin, some fresh chopped cilantro and squeezed a couple of small limes into it at the end. Garnished with sliced green onions and served with warm flour tortillas. Had some extra jalapeno jack cheese, so I set that out, too, and everyone thought it was perfect with the soup. This is pretty healthy, too, if you don't overdo the toppings.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Not the best tortilla soup I've ever had, but certainly not the worst.  The ease of prep is worth at least 3 stars!  I used pinto beans instead of chili beans, and skipped the corn. I also used about 1 1/2 lb. skinless, bone-in thighs. I used the "hot" version of Rotel (the one with habanero). Cooked on high for 5 hours. About an hour before serving, deboned & shredded the chicken, then added it back into the cooker.  Don't be tempted to serve without sour cream, cheese (cheddar, mont. jack, or Mexican white cheeses). Be sure to include crushed corn tortilla chips and lime juice--also feel free to add avocado and cilantro, too. You just have to "dress" most Mexican soups for the full flavor! Thanks for an easy, filling recipe.

text:
My family loved this.  I found it to be more of a chili than a soup.  I don't think i'll ever make "regular beef" chili ever again.  I liked it a bit thicker as thinner soup is harder for my children ( 3 and 19mths) eat and not spill everywhere.  lol  I added the beer and didn't think there was any weird flavour(as previous reviews said) I have a 7qt slow cooker so i added some extra stuff to fill it so i can freeze some.   I also added a can of chick peas, some crushed tomatoes, chicken stock, red and green peppers and some celery.  I had to omit the green chilies because of little kids.  It was great.  Will definetly be making this again.

country:
None
text:
I LOVE this recipe and make it all the time.  A few suggestions: (1) when serving a lot of people, I add an extra can of corn, (2) I found I prefer using chicken broth instead of beer, (3) Depending on whats available at the store, I have used chili beans, pinto beans, and great northern beans, (4) chopping up 2 jalapenos and adding some hot sauce is an easy way to spice it up, (5) take the extra 5 minutes to use the taco seasoning recipe -- its AWESOME, (6) to make this receipe even easier, I throw in a bag of frozen onion instead of chopping one myself.  ENJOY!!

text:
Delicious and very easy!  I made it the first time exactly as it was written and it was great - next time I didn't have the beer so I substituted 1/2 cup dry white wine and 1/2 cup chicken stock.  Also added and extra can of diced tomatoes, doubled the corn, and made it thicker with a can of cream of chicken soup - it was great with the changes as well!  Love that you can change this soup up to suit your particular taste - and I love that you just put the chicken breast fillets in the crockpot whole...a real time-saver.  (I've even put them in still somewhat frozen and they turn out beautifully!)  Thanks for another terrific soup to add to my collection!!

text:
The first time I made this, I forgot to add the cup of water and used garlic powder instead of real garlic. I drained my black beans and did not use an entire package of frozen corn. I also threw in 2 large frozen chicken breasts. I cooked it on slow for 3 hours and then took the chicken out to shred it and cooked it on high for an additional 2.  It was FANTASTIC! My boyfriend and I ate it for dinner that night and then it was my sole source of sustanence for the next three days...No exaggeration!  The next time I followed the recipe and added the water, did not drain the beans, used all the corn and room temperature chicken. I did not like it as much. Though is was still very tastey, it was less hearty.  I would however recommend either version to anyone! Easy, delicious and adjustable to anyone's personal taste. I personally like it hotter and loaded with cilantro!

text:
This recipe surpasses 5 stars in my book for ease of preparation, cost and taste!  I threw all the ingredients in the crockpot before going to bed and the next morning before work I took it out of the fridge, set it on low and forgot about it (cooked ~11 hours total)!  I omitted the onion, used spicy chili beans, 8oz of chicken broth, 2 (14.5) oz cans diced toms w/green chilis, 2 heaping tbsps of Bill Echol's Taco Seasoning and 4 chicken breasts.  Served with crushed tortilla chips and cheddar cheese, this recipe was the perfect amount of spicy and very filling.  This would be great to throw together in the morning for guests in the evening - just serve with an assortment of topping options (sour cream, cheddar cheese, tortilla chips, cilantro, green onions, etc) and you have a meal for a crowd!

This was a thick, flavorful, very filling stew (not thin enough to be a soup IMO, and I like them on the chunky side). I did substitute a can of chickpeas for the chili beans (what was on hand) and made with the beer as written. The beer gave what we though was a pleasant and complimentary flavor: we did definitely taste it though, if you're nervous about beer broth might be a good way to go. I prefer a richer more broth-y flavor to my chicken taco/tortilla soups, but I will make this again when I'm out of broth or want something unique in the slow cooker. Thanks very much for sharing :)

userID:
4092040
Display Name:
Versace

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Even though I didn't follow this to a T, I still have to give it 5 stars because it's an excellent base than can be altered easily.  I used what I had on hand and it turned out perfect!  No time for the slow cooker so I made everything on the stove top.  While I boiled 1lb boneless skinless chicken tenders, I heated everything else up in a separate stock pot.  I followed the ingredients except: I substituted the chili beans with 2 cups of cooked brown rice (didn't have chili beans on hand) & used 1 can of regular Hunt's petite diced tomatoes with no chilies.  I added 1 can Hunt's tomato sauce,  1 T each of garlic powder and dried onion flakes, and 1 can of chicken broth in place of the beer.  When the chicken was cooked, I shredded it and added it to the stock pot with the other ingredients.  I thought it needed a little more liquid, so I added a couple ladles of the leftover broth from boiling the chicken.  It was ready to eat after a few minutes and even better the next day.  This is a top-notch base recipe all around - budget-friendly, easy, very tasty and can be brought to the table in 30 minutes.  We didn't feel the need for the cheddar and sour cream, it was tasty enough without the added fat.  The tortilla chips do add a nice touch, but it's still great without them.   I have had soups similar to this in upscale restaurants but I prefer this homemade version hands-down!

text:
Love this recipe!  I used frozen chicken thighs - its tough to find a recipe that works well for thighs with all their weird shapes and parts, but this one is perfect, since you shred the chicken.  Dropped them in frozen and timing was still perfect.  I did amp up the spices, using 6 tablespoons of taco seasoning, and then adding about 1/2 tsp each of cumin, chili powder, garlic powder, and paprika.  Also added around 1 tsp of onion flakes.  I think I will just double the raw onion next time instead.  Also, drain all the beans to keep this from getting too soupy.  Thanks a ton for sharing this recipe - I love it!

text:
We really loved this soup! Ours actually came out more like a chili consistency, but I'm not saying that as a bad thing. Since we were really wanting that soup consistency, we froze half, and added more chicken stock to the half we planned to eat. Amazing flavor!! The corn stayed crunchy, the beans were not mushy at all, and the chicken had a great flavor. Delicious!  The only changes we made were: Chicken stock instead of beer per others' suggestions Cooked onion before putting in crockpot per others' suggestions 1 can tomatoes and chilies & 1 can fire roasted tomatoes 2 chicken breasts (there are only 2 of us)

text:
This is a fabulous base recipe!  I would say it's more like chicken chili than a soup.  I had to make several modifications so I could make it for dinner spontaneously.  I made it in a stock pot (chicken pan fried, shredded and added afterward) in about an hour or so.  Because it was spur of the moment, I didn't have all the ingredients on hand, but my substitutions were GREAT!  The best one to mention is that I only had one can of the Rotel tomatoes, so I used my favorite salsa instead for the other 10 ounces.  That was a great addition since it also had cumin and other flavors that it added in.  I used chicken stock as other reviewers did and kidney beans for the chili beans.  Thanks so much for a great recipe!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I wasn't "sold" on this recipe while it was cooking as I cheated and lifted the crockpot lid a few times and the aroma didn't strike me HOWEVER! the flavours REALLY come together in this dish during the last couple of hours and like many stew-type dishes, this soup is FABOULOUS after it's been sitting in the fridge for a day or two.    I normally find chicken breast too dry but it becomes so incredibly tender and juicy in this dish. I'm happy that I do not need to substitute the white meat for dark meat and can keep this recipe so healthy.   This freezes really well!  I defrost a large container of this soup in the fridge overnight and the next night, a quick reheat makes for a hearty, homey meal!  I added extra green chili bec my husband likes this soup on the hotter side - a bit too hot for me so a tbsp of sour cream stirred into my serving makes this just perfect.

text:
One of our favorites! SO easy to prepare, just open cans and dump. Some changes I make: I do not use the beer or the tomato sauce, instead make up chicken broth with Better Than Bullion and water to replace these.  Also, I use Chipotle Taco seasoning. This gives it an incredible flavor, but is sometimes hard to find. I also find that the chicken breasts can go in frozen and cook thoroughly.  Throw on the cheese and chips, and it is a hearty meal!

This recipe is wonderful and SO easy. I used the "Mexican" Chili beans as well as "Mexican" flavor tomatoes/chiles which added some more of the cumin taste to the soup. text:
AMAZING!  And it gets better each day you eat it!  It is definitely THICK - I ended up using a whole 12 oz of beer, and an entire can of chicken broth.  It could have handled even more liquid to make it more soupy and stretch it out a little longer (my husband and I were practically in mourning when we ate the last helpings).  I baked up corn tortilla strips in the oven and threw them in the slow cooker for the last 10 minutes or so.  And as others said, definitely add sour cream and shredded cheese.  This is a GREAT recipe to keep on hand for others - sick friends, families who just had babies, new neighbors, etc...a REAL CROWD PLEASER!

text:
This is a no fail recipe.  I tried it a month ago and it was well liked by al my guests.  I used the spice mixture that Patti gave in her comment and it was so spicy most people "cut" it with sour cream.  I enjoyed the spice level, however.  Kids even ate it and liked it.  This time I'm making it with McCormick's original taco seasoning.  It will be ready later today but I think the spice level will be lower.  I did not use beer.  Substituted chicken broth the first time, and a 5.5 oz can of V8 juice + 6 oz. water this time.  Added a large clove of garlic each time, too - personal taste.  Thanks for a great recipe!

This was great...perfect for for after football practice. I made a few changes based on what I had in the kitchen...didn't have any tomato sauce, so I used tomato paste and some water. Also, based on previous reviews, I added about 1/2 the amount of beer called for and substituted chicken broth for the other half. I used my own blend of spices that I use for taco seasoning, and instead of corn I cut up some corn tortillas and threw them in the slow cooker too. They made the soup nice and thick and gave it a great flavor. We'll definitely be having it again!

Tasty and SUPER simple to make. I timed it -- this only took me 4 minutes to get all ingredients together, then open and dump into the crock pot. I used frozen precooked chicken strips and was able to shred them later in the crock pot just fine. Nice and spicy, great texture and the crushed tortilla chips on top give it just the right amount of salty and crunch. Even my mother-in-law liked it!

text:
I used a 9.75 ounce can of chicken breast meat and cooked on low for 5 hours. It was wonderful! The beer gives a unique but good flavor. Even my kids loved it! The first time I made this, I used spicy diced tomatoes with chilis and it was a little too spicy for the kids. This time I used Rotel's MILD diced tomatoes with green chilis and it was perfect! I served it with a dollop of sour cream, a little shredded cheddar, and tortilla chips. Everyone loved it! I will be making this regularly now!

text:
The entire family loved this soup! Although it irritates me when people make changes to the recipes, this one was easy to substitute for what I had on hand.  Try adding cut green beans, and using salsa (I used a medium hot Chi-Chi's) if you don't have diced tomatoes with chiles or taco seasoning.  Add some cumin and cilantro to taste and I think you have about the same soup-delicious!  I took the lazy way out and cubed the chicken before I put it in for the day so I wouldn't have to shred it later.

I made this soup for the slowcooker but wanted to speed things up a bit, so I started it out in a 5 qt pot on the stove and cooked for about 30 min or so until the chicken was done. I shredded it and then put everything in the slowcooker for about 2 1/2 hrs. It tasted delicious! I did add the beer but used Budlight since several of the reviews said the beer taste was overwhelming. The only other thing I did differently was use Pace chunky salsa in place of the rotel.

text:
No wonder this soup got so many stars!  It's excellent!  I followed the recipe exactly except for the beer (didn't want to use my Guinness).  I just substituted that with low-sodiium chicken broth.  I made this twice and realized that the key in tender chicken is breaking it up really well.  If you don't break it up well, it'll just turn out like any ol' slow-cooker chicken breast - tough and chewy. This is great to freeze too!

I have never reviewed a recipe before but I had to on this one.  This is possibly the best slow cooker recipe I have ever made.  I have a 6 qt. slow cooker so I doubled the chicken recipe, used a 30 oz. can of tomato sauce, used only one can of the diced tomato with chiles, and it came out awesome.  I used 2 cups of frozen corn since I didn't have canned corn.  I also used the recipe for the taco seasoning described in the 1st review from the person who submitted the recipe, however, omitted the red pepper flakes and decreased the chili powder amount because I have small children.  The entire crockpot was devoured - each person ate 3 bowls each.  It was truly amazing!  Thanks for such a great recipe!!!!!

This was very good.  And I don't think it gets any easier than this.  The hardest part was shredding the chicken.  Since some reviewers noted the flavor of beer, I went ahead and used chicken broth instead.  And since the recipe does not specify, I did not drain or rinse the beans.  Since it came out well, I assume this was correct.  I also cut down cook time to about 5 hours by cooking on medium.  And tortilla chips in the bowl definitely gave it that little extra heartiness and flavor.  This is a keeper.

text:
I made this for a  pot luck lunch we had at my work. I followed it exactly as follows and got many complements on the dish. I however am not a big fan of beer and I could smell and taste the hint of beer which threw me off a bit. I didn't notice the spice but my husband the next day did. The second time I made this, I changed a view things and it was absolutely delicious. I used a can of Chicken broth instead of the beer, regular tomatoes instead of ones with chili peppers and omitted the tomato sauce and onion and to me it was perfect. This is a great and easy recipe to follow to the tee or to make any variations to suit your tastes.

userID:

Display Name:
hearhoofbeats

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/165922.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
One bite in to this delicious soup, my husband declared it "a keeper." I subbed 12 oz of vegetable stock for the beer, just in the interests of keeping calories down. I also only had one can of Rotel, so I added about half a can of extra water. To reduce the sodium content, I drained and rinsed the beans, then dumped them back into the can and filled with water to get the proportions right. We also used Bill's Taco Seasoning as recommended (it's on this site as Taco Seasoning I), but cut the salt in half. To make this meatless, we used about half a bag of Quorn chicken-style chunks instead of the chicken. I made the soup a day ahead and added the Quorn when I reheated on the stovetop, but I'm sure you could add it a couple of hours before serving. I loved this with crushed tortilla chips on top. It was plenty spicy for my tastes, but my husband added hot sauce. We're already looking forward to the leftovers!

text:
I followed this recipe and added a few changes for more flavor and was not that impressed.  I added fresh garlic and some sea salt and pepper. I used all organic ingredients, which are pricier and was disappointed at the result. After reading others reviews, I have to agree that the soup goes wrong with the addition of the beer. My soup had a very strong beer flavor. This is a good base for a soup, but next time I would use chicken stock and and skip the taco seasoning and use my own seasons that are more fresh. There are much better recipes out there for this type of soup.

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2009-01-03T20:22:03.98
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
2499634
Display Name:
Kristy
isPro:
False
followersCount:
5
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
27
favoritesCount:
140
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/135199.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Best soup I think I've ever made.  I decided to make it into a true soup, however, instead of a chili.  To do this, I added a 48 oz. can of chicken broth in addition to the beer.  Other modifications: used the recipe author's directions to make my own taco seasoning, used frozen corn, and used a can of diced tomatoes, a small can of mild green chiles, and a small can of hot jalapenos.  One other tip: toward the end of cooking, I decided to pull the onions that had floated to the top because they were still quite raw, and saute them for a few minutes in the residual liquid before returning them to the slow cooker.  This worked nicely.  The soup was MUY picante, but sooo good.  Garnished with lime, avocado, crushed tortilla chips, sour cream and cheddar.  I will make this again and again and again and again.
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
I am not typically a fan of soup, but this was easy, tasty and pleased the whole family.  I did not use the 2 cans of beans the recipe called for, as I did not have them on hand, and I am not a fan of beans, and it still came out great. I also placed the chicken breasts in frozen...they were so tender that I only had to poke them with the tongs a few times to get them to shred. I cooked on low for 8 hours. Definetely add the sour cream, a healthy handful of cheese (cheddar or monterrey jack) and fresh avocados on the individual bowls before serving--it makes the soup. I was not all that impressed with the smell and taste while it was cooking, but was in for a great surprise when it was done. I will make again!

Display Name:
LucyLoo

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4811530.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is AWESOME soup! My 20 year old son loved it also.  I did make some changes.   1) I used 5 boneless skinless chicken thighs, as we prefer dark meat 2) I used the "Taco Seasoning 1" recipe on this site instead of the package of taco seasoning. (Bill Echols taco seasoning) 3) I used frozen corn 4) I am not a beer drinker, and did not have it in the house, so used chicken broth. If I had beer in the house, I would have added it. 5) I used 2 cans of chili beans (we love beans). I found chili beans at Safeway, S&W has them. The can that was labeled "chili beans" was really a can of pinto beans, chili peppers, onion and garlic in a zesty tomato sauce.   This was a very hearty soup, more of a chili (probably because I used 2 cans of beans), and it was delicious! When finished, we topped with shredded Mexican cheese and sour cream. I will definitely make this again!

EDIT: I made this again and used beer instead of chicken broth, and the beer version is much better. I also used a mixture of chicken breasts and thighs. The only other changes I made were to add 2 chopped poblano peppers and 1 chopped red pepper to up the veggie content. Squeezed the juice of 2 limes in it at the end. Delish!

text:
Only gave it four stars b/c I didn't have all the ingredients on hand to try recipe 'as is', but my husband and I LOVED the result of what I did have! As others suggested, I used Lt. Red Kidney beans (2 cans undrained) instead of (1 can) Chili beans, kept corn/black beans, onion, tomato sauce, & taco seasonings the same, used (1 can) no salt added diced tomatoes, added 1 Cup of salsa instead of the diced tomatoes/green chilis, & no beer. Also used 3 frozen chicken breasts, cooked on high ~5 hours and everything was done perfectly. Usually I don't add sour cream on top of soups, but with this one, it was a MUST for pulling out the flavors a bit more. Delicious!! UPDATE: used the chili beans as recipe says second time I made this, and didn't like the flavor. Felt like the taco seasoning and the chili beans were too much of the 'same thing,'so made soup 'blander'. Will only use Kidney beans from now on! Excellent recipe!! Thanks!!

text:
Yummy! Ok, so I made a few minor changes, as some other reviewers suggested, I subbed out the beer in favor of one can of chicken broth, and cut the actual amount of chicken down to two large breasts.  Since I LOVE spicy foods, I made the taco seasoning (the way the author recommends in her review) but added some extra chili powder, cumin, and a touch extra garlic powder.  I cooked it on low for 10 hours, because that's just how my day worked out.  Even though it turned out more like chili than soup, it was the absolute BEST chicken chili I'd ever had! I will definitely be making this again, it was amazing!

text:
I'm editing this after tinkering with the recipe a few times.  I've found that using chipotle-flavored taco seasoning gives the soup a bit more zip, which we prefer.  Cooking for a longer time (up to 10 hours) over a very low setting also seems to make the chicken tastier and easier to shred.  Topping with sour cream, shredded cheese and tortilla strips is a must!  Thanks for sharing the recipe!

text:
This way exceded my expectations!  Unbelievably easy to put together and really good.  I subbed 12 oz chicken broth for the beer and added a couple of shakes of garlic powder and cumin.   I also added extra chicken. We shredded some of the chicken and chunked some of it.  I topped with sour cream, shredded Mexican queso cheese and lime Tostitos corn chips.  I liked the soupy consistency but did notice as we were eating it the chips softened and thickened the broth - really yummy.  We are used to having soup and grilled cheese so for a Mexican flair I served cheese quesadillas on the side. I definitely will be making this again.

text:
ok...admittedly i'm not the best cook in the world...nor did i follow the recipe to the "t" but....i'm thinking something else is just not right cause it doesn't sound like it should have gone that wrong....it turned out quite sweet-ish and really thin, and not "taco"-tasting at all...here's what i did/didn't do:
**what are "chili" beans anyway?  i used red kidney beans.  i did not drain the 1st can of (red) beans (i doubled the recipe since it had such good ratings!) and i may not have drained one of the cans of black beans.  could that be why it was so sweet (definitely sugar in some brands of canned beans)?
**i ended up putting the onions (2) in last since i wanted to get the chick started cooking...and i thought they were pretty prominent tasting...?too much vs maybe it was important that they were on the bottom?
**beer -- my husband had only bottles of "leffe", a "strong beer" (so it says on the label)...but i used only 1, instead of 2 (my kids thought they could taste it...don't know if it was power of suggestion or not)
**i did add a touch of chili powder and cumin, a pretty small amt for such a HUGE vat of stew/soup
**cooked on high, instead of low, about 5 hrs altogether
**at the end i thickened it with a little cornstarch (that shouldn't change the taste, should it?)
any thoughts/comments would be appreciated..especially any suggestions to improve on it now ... i have tons of leftovers!!! :)

text:
I know this would be five stars with the beer.  I, however, used two cans of low sodium chicken broth instead.  Why chicken broth instead of beer?  I don't waste my beer in food - I'm on a budget.  Why two cans of broth?  With one can it seemed too much like a stew or chili - too thick.  I wanted more of a soup-like texture.  Everything else followed exact.  Huge hit!  Everyone went nuts over this!  SO EASY.  I will definately be making this again.  Hopefully right after payday so I can spare a couple beers and try it that way.

text:
I thought this recipe had great flavor but too much spice for us.  I used the taco seasoning listed here and it was way too spicy.  I think I'd cut down on the quantity.  I made this with 1 can of black beans, no chili beans because I didn't have any.  Also made with chicken broth instead of the beer.  Only used 2 1/2 breasts but that was enough for us. I cut up my chicken first and just cooked it the whole time and it turned out great (I tossed it with some of the seasoning before throwing it in).  I think this is a great recipe with great flavor but I'll have to tone it down a bit.  We had the sour cream & chips that helped take some of the spice out.  Got even spicier the next day but we suffered thru it because the basic taste was great.  Only made enough for 2 meals for the 2 of us - maybe we just eat a lot but it didn't go as far as some of the other reviewers said!  Very easy too!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Have made this several times.  I have tried a few variations and think I finally have it perfect for my taste.  I have added extra tomato sauce and a can of diced tomotoes, but felt it ended up too soupy an dulled down the taste.  I've tried an extra packet of taco seasoning, but this left it too salty.  So, in my last batch, I made the following adjustments, and it turned out great:  Used frozen corn (canned corn, yuck!), 2 cans of drained black beans (love um), chicken broth vs beer, and the biggest change was I added about 4-5 chopped chipolte peppers and a little of the adobo sauce in which it was canned.  As expected and desired, this gave it even more of a spicy punch.  My grocery store does not carry the spicy version of the Rotel tomatoes/chilies, so I wanted to spice it up a bit without having to add to the salt via the taco seasoning. This freezes well which is a huge plus.

This is the best thing I've ever done in a crock pot!  My hubby loved it.  I did use chicken broth instead of beer and added some extra cumin and chili powder.  I also added a can of kidney beans. I rinsed all the beans except the chili beans to try to keep the sodium down a little.  There are very few low fat recipes that don't require trips to the store for produce and lots of chopping.  This is easy to put together with ingredients that are already in the house and it couldn't be quicker!!

I made this according to the recipe and used the Bill Echols Taco Seasoning Mix also on this site. It was FANTASTIC as a soup. This was very good! I cut up the chicken and served 40 minutes later...I'm not sure why you have to let it go for another 2 hours, because the chicken was definitely cooked. At the same time that I shredded the chicken, I also added about 1 cup of rice, deciding that I didn't want "soup". It ended up just a little thicker, more like a chili. The texture of the rice was also better, I think, than it just being a soup. Overall, it was wonderful! I can't wait to have it for lunch tomorrow.

text:
Really tender chicken and tasty soup. Ours was more like a chili as I used a large can of diced tomatoes and no tomato sauce, but it was great. We scooped it up with tortillas instead of crushing them into the soup/chili.

My only complaint is that the flavor was a little dull. Next time I'll add more chili powder (used the seasoning recipe recommended on here and it didn't seem to be powerful enough to add much flavor) or possibly some chipotle peppers with adobo sauce for a little more kick. I'm not a hot spice freak, but this could have used a little more oomph. But I wouldn't have been disappointed if I had served this to guests.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/94049.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe! I always end up making changes to every recipe I make, so here is what I will do differently the next time I make it.
1. Reduce the amount of chili powder. I used Patti's recipe for taco seasoning (in the reviews.) I thought it was a little heavy on the chili powder. Next time I will reduce it by half and maybe add some cayenne or a dash of hot sauce to get some heat without the chili flavor.
2. Use two cans of black beans instead of one black and one red. The red beans (combined with too much chili powder) made my brain think I was eating chili.
3. Even this time I used 12 oz. chicken stock instead of the beer. I don't like beer and was afraid the flavor would come through. Also, I am pregnant and can't have alcohol (no, it doesn't all cook out!)

Other than that, thought it was just wonderful. Will definitely be making this again soon.

text:
I made this for dinner the other night and the only change I made was to cook the soup on high for about 5 hours (instead of low).  After I cubed the chicken and added it back, I turned the temperature down to low.  The end result was a really yummy soup, but both my DH and I found that it was the cheese, sour cream and crushed tortilla's that really made this dish.  As a side note, this makes a lot of soup, so if you're eating leftovers, the soup gets really thick once it cools, so you might want to consider adding more liquid (chicken stock?).

text:
This is a wonderful recipe that takes so little effort.  I have made it twice, once with beer, and once without.  It's good either way, but the beer does make it better.  I made it for a family get-together and decided to decrease the chiles to better suit everyone's taste.  I used one can regular tomatoes and one with chiles, and it was still very good.  This gets pretty spicy with both the chiles and the taco seasoning.  I also add a can of tomato soup, about 3/4 cup of cream (sounds crazy, but good), and thickened it with a little cornstarch.  Everyone loved it.  Don't leave out the "fixins", adding the cheese, tortilla chips, and sour cream really adds to it.

text:
This is a great easy recipe.  I dump in everything and then add left over chicken meat or even better left over pork (dark meat) and cook on high about 4 to 5 hours. I use all chicken broth and finish with crushed tortilla chips and a dollop of sour cream.  I make this at work and everyone loves it.  To save time, I put it all together the night before and put in the fridge.  Put in on in the am and it is ready by lunch!

text:
Not bad. I made it on the stove top. Cooked the chicken in the oven first while the rest of the stuff simmered while covered. Then added the chicken and cooked about 30 minutes on medium(let it come to it's own mild boil, don't rush it), took them out and shredded the chicken, added them back in, cooked a little while longer(does it really matter how long?). Added dashes of cumin, red pepper flakes, chili powder, and some hamburger seasoning I had. Served with crescent rolls, and of course the cheese, sour cream and crushed chips. Also, the diced tomatoes added in were chili ready, used fiesta canned corn. And used minced onion instead of the onion(heaping tablespoon). Plenty left over :)

text:
A staple in the house during the winter. So easy. I have cooked diced chicken on hand in the freezer so this is a quick meal to throw together. I didn't use the chili beans but used kidney beans one time and pinto the other time. I use a can of chicken broth instead of the beer. Cooks well on the stovetop if in a super hurry. The soup freezes well for later -- just remember to pull it out the day or two before. Thanks for the great recipe.

text:
Ok, this soup/stew is awesome!!! First, it just does not get any easier to prepare. Second, it is just plain delicious.  My husband is a little bit picky and really does not care for beans of any kind.  He LOVES this soup!!!  He loves it so much the leftovers don't even last long!!  Wonderful with corn bread or tortilla chips. I also love that I can adjust the "heat" level by the choice of tomatoes and green chilis. I have used the regular once, lots of good heat. And I have used the mild, still really nice flavor.  Great for winter days!!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tis the season for soup like this!  And it was much tastier than I expected from just a bunch of cans dumped in a pot.  I made it on Monday night and my fella and I have dipped from it all week, finishing it off on Thursday.  I actually made it on the stove top, dicing the chicken breast and browning in olive oil first, then adding the onion, taco spice (+ extra "chili" spices from my rack) then a can of coors light (even cheap beer worked) to scrape up all the yummy browned bits. Then added the remaining ingredients and simmered 2 hrs.  I only used about 3/4 of the beans to cut down on...er...you know...The Toots, and never had a problem.  I used no-salt corn and tomato sauce, even though I have no problem with sodium.  Delish served plain or with the suggested toppings and corn chips.  A guacamole salad would be great to round it out.  Thanks for this keeper!

text:
I'd probably rate this a 3.5.  I should have cut the recipe in 1/2 since there are only two of us!  But I think I'll freeze some.  It was good; I thought the flavor was enhanced with the cheese and/or sour cream dollop.  Was hesitant to pour beer in the crockpot, but I did it.  Couldn't taste it at all, but it may have been the very very subtle undercurrent of sweetness I could taste in the broth. Accidentally used a small can of tomato paste, rather than tomato sauce.  Didn't hurt it any.  Used fire-roasted diced tomatoes for added flavor.  Made Taco Seasoning I from this website, rather than using a store-bought packet.  Only used two chicken breasts.  Got a late start on this, and even put the chicken in frozen (cut up), so put it on high for 5 hours. It makes a lot; my crockpot was full to the brim! Served it with chips and Guacamole (by Bob Cody) from this website.  Thank you, Landmarkpatti!

text:
DELICIOUS! I followed the recipe exactly except I used the taco seasoning recipe from this site, drained one of the cans of tomatoes (which were 14.5 ounces, not 10 ounces), and used Sierra Nevada for the beer. Using a homemade taco seasoning is nice because you can control the amount of salt going into the soup. Rinsing the black beans is immportant because most of the time they are packaged with salt to keep them fresh. My soup wasn't too salty or too spicy, as others have said. Instead of 5 hours on low, then shredding the chicken, I did three hours on high, shredded the chicken, turned it to low, and let it sit for another few hours. This recipe couldn't be easier.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2006-02-01T17:59:27.14
helpfulCount:
1

50836

MSCLAUDI

This is a keeper!  So easy and delicious!  I did make a few changes based on other reviews (and the fact I can rarely leave a recipe alone!). I used two cans of tomato sauce and decreased the water to 1 cup.  I added a bunch of minced garlic, cumin, oregano, and basil. country:

text:
I used chicken broth instead of beer, threw it all in the instant pot for 25 minutes and let it depressurize on its own and it was PERFECT! The thigh fillets shredded perfectly, didn’t need salt. Next time, I would only do 20 minutes or depressurize it sooner. We ate it with tortilla chips/flour tortillas, sour cream, shredded Mexican cheese, fresh cilantro and a squeeze of lemon. My 10 and 11-year old LOVED it!” This creates a lot of servings, too.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
