photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7321609.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe but with a few adjustments, most notably, swapping out the beer and using 12 ounces of low sodium chicken broth instead. I also use 1/4 cup of taco seasoning instead of a standard packet as this recipe originally calls for. To make it less of a chili and more of a soup, reduce the chicken breasts from 3 to just 2, and make sure they are totally thawed and not frozen when you put them in. To make it even thinner, sometimes I just cook it without the chicken breasts and then add in some leftover chopped chicken from a roast chicken dinner (2 cups of chopped chicken), during the last half hour of cooking. Increase the chicken broth to 16 oz if going this route though. Enjoy!

This was quite a good recipe and was tasty, but I had serious problems because I used a beer (a blonde ale) that had a slight bitterness--the bitter/hoppy flavor was hard to get rid of. So, an important caveat: USE ONLY LAGERS AND OTHER VERY LOW BITTERNESS BEERS IN THIS RECIPE!

Made this on the stove top. Delicious. Sautéd to brown onion and garlic in a little veg oil first with some diced poblano, then added pre-cooked rotisserie chicken. Used mckormick taco seasoning packet. Definitely a keeper recipe!!

This recipe was so easy yet so delicious.  Only made a few minor changes.  I used my Aroma rice cooker by the way.  I first sautéed the chopped onions in a tablespoon of minced garlic (about 5 min).  Then I added all the ingredients as listed.  I used one 14.5 oz can of diced tomatoes and added 1/2 cup of salsa (I used the medium heat kind they sell in the glass jars).  Everything else was the same but at the end I added some heavy cream to make the soup creamy instead of the optional sour cream.  So delicious!

text:
I had thee worst cold today when I made this soup.  No variations on the recipe at all.  Towards the end of the day I took the chicken out to shred and it dawned on me due to the cold I had absolutely NO sense of smell or taste!  I shredded up the chicken and tasted the soup and could not tell if I needed to add anything.  When my husband got home I asked him to taste it and let me know what I needed to add.  Two bowls later he said "Nothing, the soup has great flavor!"  So, I can't say it was great, but everyone else loved it.  Next time I make it I'll make sure I don't have a cold!

text:
I have made this several times in a crock pot. This last time I made this recipe in a Dutch oven, in my pellet smoker. I also put a whole chicken with a chipotle rub on the chicken, then setting on a small cookie cooling rack on to top of the Dutch oven with the chicken setting on the rack. All the chicken drippings drops into the Dutch oven to add flavor. Turned out great with a smoke flavor 
Note: I use 32oz of chicken broth and not beer per the recipe

This soup was easy, I had all the ingredients on hand except the beer, so I used a can of chicken broth instead. I cooked the soup on the stovetop substituting 2 cans of Costco precooked chicken for the chicken breast called for in the recipe. I have made this so many times because it’s such a huge hit in my house and super easy to make. Also I’m not a beer drinker at all, you can’t taste it. The pickiest of eaters will devour this. I started adding the large jar of corn, and I’d add one more can of beans, whichever I had on hand. 10 mins before serving I’d dump about half a bag of shredded Mexican cheese in there with a cup of sour cream. Mix it in, then serve. Makes dishing up easier in my house!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6585871.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made it twice now. We love it so much and it's even better as leftovers! It's adaptable to personal taste like the author says. I do not use beer as we are not beer drinkers (find me a good wine and I'll throw it in) so I sub 14oz. can of low-sodium chicken broth. My other half does not do spicy, so everything is pretty mild (4 T taco seasoning, 1/2 t of cumin and 2 cans of Rotel the original recipe). I have used chili beans and have also sub for pinto beans as its what I had on hand. I also use sweet corn instead. I have used fresh garlic (2-3 med. size cloves) and also garlic powder (1 t) - we love garlic. Any version is delicious! It is great for leftovers or it would be great for potluck or entertaining (Superbowl perhaps?). Top it with cheese, sour cream, and avocado and you WILL NOT go wrong!! The tortilla chips are great but warning they end up soaking up liquid and become mushy. Great recipe, thank you!!! :)

I've made this twice. Once with the beer (per the recipe) and once with two cups of chicken stock in place of the beer. Both were very good. My family enjoyed it more with the chicken stock instead. This is a simple, easy, DELICIOUS, satisfying, and healthy meal.  My kids who are picky eaters asked for seconds!  Notes: (1) I used the taco seasoning the author recommends. Perfect seasoning. (2) I used one can of Rotel (for the tomatoes w/ green chilies) and one can of regular diced tomatoes (13 oz).  (3) Also, frozen corn instead of canned. Just my personal preferences. We will make this over and over again. Thank you for the awesome recipe!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3930066.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This turned out really good. My original goal was to cut it in half.  Glad I didn't. I chopped up 1/2 of a red and 1/2 a white onion that was in the fridge that needed using up, but that was more like a cup than half. Then I bought Ranch Style Beans vs Chili Beans oops..one can tomato with green chilies and added one can of green chilies. Frozen corn, because I don't care for canned.  I used the 8oz of tomato sauce because I bought the wrong beans and used about 6 oz Shiner Black beer. I had taco seasoning from the bulk Healthy Living section of my store, and probably used 3T maybe more. I didn't add chicken because I was cooking for myself and planned on adding leftover shredded chicken from enchladas for the BF's serving. After reading reviews on the thickness, or suggestions that you could use it as a dip, I wanted soup. So I added a carton of vegetable broth and a little extra water as well as cumin. Put the cooker on low and headed to work. Later that night I added the drained black beans and  set it on high while I made a sweet cornbread.  Just a small amount of heat and topped it with fresh cilantro, green onions, sour cream and white cheese.  Will do again!!

Delicious soup, I think the beer really made a huge difference. I've made soups like this before, but they have never had such great flavor. It was thick and so yummy! text:
I made this recipe just as written but did not add the 8 oz can of tomato sauce cuz I didn't have it. I did use Mexicali corn.  My diced tomatoes with green chilies were  larger  cans(I pureed them since the boys don't like chunks of tomatoes). So with the 12 oz beer & 28 oz of tomatoes my slow cooker was full.  I started it after lunch -probably around 1:30 & the chicken was half frozen so cooked it  on high until 5 pm.  Shredded the chicken, putting it into the soup made it so 
thick with chicken and yummy.  We did not add sour cream or cheese.  I used plain tortilla to scoop up some of this delicious soup.  I'll make this again!

text:
This is my new favorite recipe.  I use the Taco Seasoning 1 recipe from this site too (which I make in bulk to always have on hand).  I've tried mixing in some home made salsa and adding a little more spice, but in general, it is perfect as written.   As others have noted, I used a dark beer (black IPA).  I love that I can keep almost all the ingredients on hand for use anytime and it is even better left over for lunch the next day.  My kids, who normally don't like beans, will also eat this without a complaint.  I've shared this with multiple people and they all love it!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Our whole family loved this with just a couple of tweaks. It's been my experience with chicken that when cooked in a CP all day, it tastes Funny. Like it has a weird texture so instead we seasoned the breast with garlic/onion powder, diced in bite size pieces and whitened in olive oil with fresh garlic. And put the pieces in the CP. WOW that made ALL the difference in how the chicken came out. 
I didn't have chili beans so I used kidney beans dusted with chili powder. As for the beer, (HighLife)this time I used it since I was out of chicken broth and said nothing while I watched everyone gobble it up then told them. "WHAT? THERE'S BEER IN THIS?!? We wouldn't have known if you didn't say anything." Served with crumbled tortilla chips and cheese.

Everyone I have ever made this for LOVES this soup! I love that it’s sooooo easy to prepare. Only changes I make it to use a can of chicken broth instead of the beer, add a clove of crushed garlic, pink beans instead of chili beans, and when it’s all done cooking I put some chopped fresh cilantro and mix it into the whole soup. text:
I love this recipe as and have made it at least 10 times. BUT it is important to note that the size of the chicken breasts matter. Our chicken breasts at my store are HUGE weighing 2 lbs each and If I used 3- and I have- there is too much chicken and the flavor is watered down. I try to use the smallest breasts I can find.

text:
I'd give this about 3.5 stars. I followed the recipe as written but used the Bill Echols Taco Seasoning recipe instead of a store bought packet. Perhaps that's why I found this too spicy? I'm not sure. I was very glad to have the sour cream and cheese to cut some of the heat. It tasted good, but I think there could have been more beans. They were pretty sparse. I'd definitely add another can of black beans. My family ate and enjoyed this, but the leftovers didn't move too fast out of the fridge.  I loved how easy it was to make though.

text:
Love this recipe. All three of my boys are happy when I make this. I usually use a Corona for the beer. Nice light flavor. A neat cooking hack I’ve learned because my shredded chicken always looks awful, put your chicken in a bowl and shred it with your electric beater. Sounds crazy but it shreds it perfectly. Just be sure and use a large bowl because it can be messy!

Display Name:
Lisa Kasparian

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
One of my favorite recipes on this site! I've made this many times and my boyfriend loves it as well! I follow the recipe with a few adjustments. I double the amount of corn. I also recommend Trader Joe's taco mix and a small can of green chilies for a little extra spice. Like other reviews, I recommend the beer be a dark Mexican beer. I cook on low for 6 hours and shred the chicken and cook for 1 more hour on low. I serve soup with corn chips and toppings like shredded cheese, avocado, green onions, sour cream, cilantro, and lime juice.  It is more like a chili than soup, but maybe because I add extra goodies! I'm making this again for dinner tonight!  Yum! :)

text:
This is my "go to" taco soup recipe.  Love that I can basically dump all the ingredients in the crock pot early in the morning, including frozen chicken breasts, and it is ready when I get home from work.  The soup on its own without cheese, sour cream and chips is hearty, healthy and low fat. It’s was pretty good. Changes I incorporated: I seasoned boneless chicken thighs with Cuban and Mexican seasoning rub, I seared the chicken in peanut oil to lock in flavor, added green onions and fresh cilantro to soup, switched the tomatoes with green chilies for fresh pico de gallo with chopped jalapeños, left out the crushed red pepper due to jalepenos inside of pico mix, and I kept the bones in the soup after shredding the cooked chicken for additional flavor.

Good base recipe. I did this stovetop on low for a good while. I added more tomatoes, hot sauce, crushed chili peppers, cumin, seasoning salt, and a little bit of lemon (to increase acidity without adding even more heat). I used ground beef instead of whole breasts. All told this filled 5 16 oz containers and an 8 oz container. Good for a week of dinners under 10 dollars.

text:
Great recipe. I used chicken broth instead of beer, but I didn't need the full amount because I like it thicker. I also didn't have much time, so cooked on high for four hours and then the chicken shredded nicely. I cooked it for another hour on low, but that probably isn't necessary. I used the taco seasoning recipe from the author's comment, but used healing amounts of each ingredient. Honestly could probably just double or completely. It wasn't spicy. And I also used a whole package of ranch dressing seasoning. Next time I will double this recipe because it barely lasted us four days! Served with chips (note self- buy the big bag) and bread (from a seasoned loaf). It was great!

text:
I wasn't sure what kind of "chili beans" to use, so opted for plain pinto beans, drained and rinsed.  To compensate for possible lack of spice, I added about a third of a 4.5 ounce can of green chilies (put the rest on the table for addition to the soup to suit individual tastes).  I also substituted a package of frozen Green Giant roasted corn for canned corn - better flavor, color, crunch.  Whole family really liked the soup so this recipe is a keeper.

I have made this recipe as stated. It was good. The second time around I tweaked it to my palate. I doubled the recipe. I added approx. 1/4 cup of hot sauce, a couple tablespoons of chili powder, and a dash of cumin. At the end of the recipe I added two jalapeno peppers seeded and chopped and a couple tablespoons of fresh chopped  cilantro. I added the peppers towards the end because I like them crunchy.

I used to LOVE this recipe, but then I became a Vegetarian.

I'm not a Vegan, so I did use Organic Mexican Style Blend Cheese.

Loved this.  Used chicken broth instead of beer.  I didn’t have the cans of tomatoes with chilies so I used a large can of tomatoes and a small can of green chilies . I think if I had used regular cans the salt taste would have been overwhelming.  This was much healthier and perfect taste.

text:
This recipe is great as is, but my husband likes a kick . So i make a few modifications. He loves this soup so much that he requests it all the time and I always make it for his birthday. 
I add 1 sliced jalapeño and 1/2 jar of Frontera Habenero Salsa.  I use frozen corn instead of canned. I use one can of black beans and leave the chili beans out. I use chicken thighs instead of chicken breasts because they have a  little more fat and flavor.

text:
I have never cared for taco soup but I had a lot of chicken that was already cooked to use up, so I tried this recipe. It was so yummy! We are still eating it and it seems better everyday. I followed the basic recipe with the exception of using cooked chicken that I added near the end. I also have my own recipe for the taco seasoning and I used that. Usually I really tweak my recipes but it was not necessary with this one.
*** I just made this again with ground beef and we loved it even more! I did not brown the meat before putting it in the cooker, I just broke it up in small pieces. I did add a bit more taco seasoning, and used V8 instead of the tomato sauce, put the cooker on high and it was done in 4 hours.

Could use a little extra spice to make it better, so I'll play with that next time but I'll definitely make it again.

text:
Oh my goodness. This is now one of my favourite recipes! My boyfriend loved it as well. I made it with the recommended Bill Echols Taco Seasoning recipe. Amazing and flavourful with the perfect amount of heat. I am in Canada and we don't have "Rotel" which is the US company that makes "diced tomatoes with green chilies". I did however find a store brand version at "Save On Foods" under the "Western Family" brand. So to the other Canadians.. we definitely have a suitable equivalent here! It's labeled as "diced tomatoes with green chilies and lime juice". I used it in mine and it was perfect.

text:
Best crock pot recipe yet!  Just too darn easy!  I did mix up the taco seasoning that was suggested.  I did not have beer on hand, so used chicken broth.  Used one can of Rotella, one can diced tomatoes.  I did cut up my chicken, and mixed up the night before, placed in the refrigerator.  Plugged in the crock pot the next morning on low, cooked for about 10 hours.  IT WAS A PERFECT DINNER!  Topped off with some chips, cheese, cilantro.  Will be making this again!  Thank you for the recipe!

text:
This recipe was bland at best.  I used the taco seasoning recipe that the original poster recommended, but after reading some of the comments, I increased all of the spices by 1/2, except for the crushed red pepper.  In spite of that, I had to add more cumin after cooking to help the flavor.  

There wasn't enough liquid to the soup and there was too much chicken compared to the other ingredients.  I plan to reduce the chicken to only 2 breasts and supplement the remainder with more beans, 12 ozs of broth, diced fire roasted tomatoes, and rework the spices.

text:
I liked this.  Followed the recipe exactly (except I mixed the seasonings suggested by the person that posted it instead of using a packaged taco mix).  I could taste a mild beer flavor which didn't bother me as I like beer-if you don't I would suggest using some type of broth instead.  This dish is very mild-if you like spicy food you should add more seasoning.  Also, it looked really thin when I took the chicken breasts out to shred them, however when I put the shredded chicken back in, the soup was quite thick-I did use 3 really large breasts.

text:
I made this recipe exactly as written using Modela Dark Beer and the full recipe for the Bill Echols Taco Seasoning.  After cooking for 4 hours, I was concerned that the consistency was very watery and soupy so I made the decision to remove the cooked chicken breasts and pulse them in my food processor.  I added the cooked chicken back to the pot and this thickened it beautifully.  I used some shredded Pepper Jack Cheese I had on hand and this was so good.  Thank you for a terrific, easy recipe.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Needed a recipe where I just shopped my pantry and this was it. I did the Bill Echols taco seasoning as another post contained the exact measurements. 

I had some variations since I didn't have everything in stock: I used raw 1/4 Cup black beans (ensure you can cook it for 8 plus hours in slow cooker), no beer in the house so used 1.5 cup chicken broth, chicken thighs, and a can of baked beans  since i did not have chili beans. 

Overall i slow cooked for 4 hours high, then forgot about it and by time i returned i put it back for another 4 hours high. For me i mainly needed the black beans to soften, everything else was cooked and simmering. We liked it, and added shredded cheese, chopped cilantro and chips to it.

It's almost a tortilla soup, or chili. Delicious!

text:
We loved this!  My 10 year old said it might be the best meal he has ever eaten!  I had to make some substitutions based on what I had on hand - 1 jar of my home-canned tomatoes (for bought ones), 1 can of tomato soup (instead of tomato sauce) to offset the acidity, a can of mixed beans (for the chili beans).  Plus lots of garlic!  You could definitely use any kind of bean in this soup, or add even more.  Also, the beer cooked perfectly into the dish - even thought my hubby and I are not beer drinkers.   We topped it with lettuce, cheese, green onions, mushrooms and crushed tortilla chips.  This will become a regular dish in our house!

text:
I was snowed in and had most of the ingredients on the pantry shelf but did substitute chicken broth for the beer. I made the Bill Echols taco seasoning from recipe provided by RaisinKane aka Patti.  I used a can of diced tomatoes and 1 can of Ro-tel tomatoes with green chilies and also put in 1 can of washed and drained kidney beans that is not in the recipe.   By doing this I added more chicken broth than called for.  I think this is a recipe that can be played with and made to suit your taste.  Everyone loved it.

text:
I admit that I made some changes to this, mostly because I didn't have everything on hand. I used a can of Mexican stewed tomatoes and one with tomatoes with chilis. I also added a small can of chilis. I did not use the chili beans or tomato sauce. I used chicken broth instead of beer, but next time I will try the beer.  I also added 2 oz. of ranch dressing mix. It has so much flavor and is just the right amount of spicy. I love recipes that have some bite, but more flavor than heat and this one does. I also love that the chicken just cooks in the crockpot.

Display Name:
Kathy

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674140.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I attempted to make this exactly as the recipe was written, but misread it and had to make some adjustments after the fact, which actually turned out to be super fantastic. I mistakenly used two cans of diced green chiles instead of two cans of tomatoes with green chiles. I didn't have a package of taco seasoning, so I made "Taco Seasoning I" from the recipe on this site. I used a bottle of Smithwick's beer. (I was going to use Miller lite, but couldn't find any in the house - thankfully, as it turned out.) I guess given the mistake, along with the homemade seasoning, this turned out way too spicy for my taste. I read up on how to cut down on the heat of spices, and subsequently added close two cups of shredded cheddar cheese, and about a tablespoon or so of sugar. I put it in the fridge overnight to allow the flavors to blend and had it for lunch the next day. I topped it with a little bit of cheese and sour cream. OMG, best soup ever!

text:
Very delicious recipe! I always use chicken thighs instead of breasts as they're more tender. I also used Octoberfest beer, which I could taste and thought it went well with the comfort food & fall vibe. Some people mentioned they prefer adding chicken broth instead of beer, but I don't think that would taste as good. I thought it was the perfect amount of spicy using diced tomatoes with green chilies. My boyfriend doesn't like cheese/sour cream but I do, so I just added the toppings to mine and we were both happy. Would definitely make again!

text:
For the beer I used Warsteiner and for the taco seasoning I use Alton Brown's recipe. It is not a bad recipe; not the best taco soup that I have made, but it is pretty quick and easy. For me the biggest flaw with this recipe is the lack of depth to the flavor. There is flavor, but it is neither complex or satisfying. The soup ends up with just a hint of something, but is too wan to carry the day.

userID:
12176211
Display Name:
SnugglePuggle
isPro:

16

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3385639.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family and I loved this!! I made a few changes but overall it's a great recipe. I substituted chicken broth/stock for beer, added 2 cans rotel diced tomatoes with green chilies, 1 can mexicorn, 2 cans regular corn, 3 cans black beans drained (half a can with seasoned juice), 1 can spicy chili beans undrained, 1 whole onion and 1 green pepper cut into pieces. I used about a 1/4 packet of taco seasoning then added a couple taps of garlic powder, cayenne, paprika, cilantro leaves and white pepper. Topped with tortilla chips and mexican cheese, it was just the right amount of spice! Great, heart warming soup for a chilly night (or a warm Florida one for me).

text:
This soup was delicious - both my daughters (6 and 8) gave it thumbs up. I used chicken broth in place of beer and at the end I heated up a can of cannellini beans in the microwave, puréed in the food processor and stirred in to thicken. The soup was just too watery for our tastes and I guess we wanted more of a chili consistency. I cooked in the slow cooker a little over 5 hours on low and that was plenty of time. Any more and I think the chicken would have dried out. Served with some plain Greek yogurt (that cooled down the spice for my daughters). Yum!

text:
I did not have tomato sauce (which I assume was meant to me tomato puree, not ketchup - Kiwi here!) or tinned tomatoes with chilis. So I used two tins of regular tomatoes, I added some crushed chili - maybe 1/2-1tsp and a 2 tbsp tomato paste to try to compensate for my slightly wrong ingredients.
It was beautiful! It needed no seasoning adjustments. The flavour and texture was spot on. It was almost like a stew in terms of consistency. It got gobbled by the family.
I just had it with sour cream, cheese and a bit of fresh cilantro (fresh coriander for the Kiwis reading). It was filling as it was. I did not need the chips with it but I am sure they would have been nice.
I am making another batch for my work lunches this week (I am not sharing it with my family this week, it is all mine!)

country:
None
text:
I, my family and friends love this recipe.  I have made it several times now for dinner, potlucks, and parties.  Even one of my "cook-challenged" sons makes it for himself now!  The original recipe is great but for those who nix the beer, the correct beer enhances the soup ten fold.  I use Sapporo beer as it was on hand when I first made it and it really makes this soup even more yummier.  Since I love tomatoes, I always use a full 15-16 oz can of tomato sauce instead of 8 oz.   For the spicier batches I have chopped up and added one of the Chipotle peppers from a small can of  "Chipotle Peppers in Adobo Sauce" (taking out the seeds though for those who are sensitive to such).  I also have used crushed fresh garlic which is nice but doesn't really enhance the already great flavor.   This is such an easy recipe to make and is a great meal that goes a long way for those on a tight budget.

I have made several recipes via slow cooker & grill that call for beer or wine. I found that if the people don't see & you don't tell .   .. . 10 out of 10 don't find anything to complain about.
Face it. After 5 hrs in a slow cooker or 20 minutes on the grill .. .all the alcohol has cooked off. It's a mental obstacle for some people. My mother-in-law loved my grilled chicken until she found I had marinated it with wine.

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-06-09T17:57:59.79
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
16317247
Display Name:
Phebe Wair
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
13
favoritesCount:
651
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3676687.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I LOVE taco soup and this  one is the best tasting one I have really enjoyed. However, I fixed it on the stove top. Same ingredients with a few additions. I used a 6 qt. Dutch Oven, first I browned the onion in 1 Tablespoon of olive oil on med heat for approx. 4-5 minutes (stirring occasionally . Push onions to side and add the chicken to the oil and lightly brown (4-5 mins. Each side). Add the remainder of the ingredients. I then added 1-15.5 oz. can (drained) Garbanzo peas and 1-32 oz. box of chicken broth. Stove top cooking evaporates the liquid faster than slow cooker, so I knew it would need more liquid.Although, water can be used instead of broth but, I wanted as much layers of flavor as possible. Turn up the heat, bring to boil,  put lid on and turn heat to low and cook for 1-1/2 hours. Stirring occasionally. Take chicken out and shred,  add chicken back to soup. That's it, it' s ready to bowl-up and add your favorite toppings, serve, and enjoy. We like crushed white tortilla chips or fried tortilla strips. This is one to cherish in your 'go to' recipe file.

city:

country:
None
text:
Recipe was a huge hit at the Firehouse. One thing everyone keeps saying about taking out the beer; leave the beer in and make sure you get a good expensive Mexican Lager beer. I used Dos Equis Amber($18 for a 12 pack) and because I made the meal 4 times larger, I used 4 12 oz bottles of beer and you can't taste it at all. Don't use IPA's or Ale's they are to bitter and have too potent of flavors to be added. Also don't use some cheap light watered down beer, there is too much water in them and not the right type of flavors.

text:
This is an excellent recipe.  I've made it many times, and it is always scrumptious and perfect for dinner guests.  I have always used bud light lime, and could always slightly taste and smell the beer, which I personally didn't care for.  I forgot beer one time and used hard cider, which worked fine....however I read another review on here that said to use a dark Mexican beer, so I bought Modelo Negra at Safeway, and I must say it made the difference.  No beer taste or smell at all.

text:
No alcohol is allowed in my family's diet. I substituted chicken broth for the beer. I added some garlic and used only 1 can of Rotel . When I tasted the soup at the end of cooking time, I found it little bit bland. It might be because of the changes I had to make or the brand of Taco seasoning. But, adding little cumin and some chopped Cilantro made the soup taste a lot better.
I served this topped with some avocadoes, sour cream, cheese and some corn chips. It was a very comforting meal in a cold winter night

We love, love, love this soup.  We use chicken thighs which shred right in the pot with a little stirring eliminating the take out the breast and shred step. Made this exactly as directed with the suggested taco seasoning. I added a little extra chicken stock just to thin it and stretch the recipe.  Using a good dark beer is key.  Negra Modela is my go to beer.  It's tasty and easy to find.  My husband and I loved it but it was just touch too spicy for our eight year old. He liked it very much but sadly has not inherited our love of a little extra heat. This will definitely go in to our winter rotation minus the crushed red pepper.

Display Name:
amers7777

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We have been making this soup/stew for three years now - usually at least twice each winter. It's great for warming up on a cold night, and any extra freezes and reheats beautifully. The additions that we have made are a couple of teaspoons of pimentón (smoked Spanish paprika), maybe a teaspoon of cumin, 1 roasted jalapeño, 1 roasted cubanelle 2/3 roasted habanero (if you'd like to add some heat), and 3 cloves of crushed garlic. In addition to the garnishes listed, we also top with a little cilantro, a wedge of fresh squeezed lime and avocado.

text:
This has become one of our weekly meals.  The first time I made, my mother wasn't going to eat b/c she doesn't like tacos b/c she doesn't like the taste of the meat.  This worked great b/c it has chicken instead & the taco seasoning is used to season whole soup not just meat.  She loved it.  I also have a picky son who doesn't like tomatoes, but he loves this.  We tried it using beer first time & chicken broth second, I prefer the beer, it enhances flavors better.  I made no changes to it except I use chicken tenders instead of whole breast.  Thank you so much for giving me a recipe so we aren't eating the same thing over & over.  We love it & we eat it with fritos.   :)

text:
I love making this recipe this time of year.  It is super easy to make and taste like you spent hours making it.  I double the recipe and make my own taco seasoning.  I pressure cook a whole chicken which makes its own broth.  Once my chicken is done (25 min) I shred and add the broth to the pot with the rest of ingredients. Tortilla chicps, sour cream, cheese and avocado on the side and you have a hearty meal.  I do omit the beer and it is still delicious.

text:
not sure i should even rate given the changes I made but we all do tweak things to our liking, budget, and on hand items. First off i was impatient and wanted tonight so I diced a red onion and sauteed in butter than transferred to my soup pot and then i sauteed 3 pounded out chicken  breast in same pan coated with chili powder and some garlic and salt. In the soup kettle i added 2 cans of corn , one can of seasoned black beans, once can of petite diced tomatoes (with garlic i believe) Instead of plain tomato sauce i added a can of hunts garlic and onion spag, sauce. I had no beer so I added three beef boullion cubes cuz thats what I had....and three cups of water, one and 1/2 packages of taco seasoning, about a teaspoon cumin (eyeballed it) and some garlic powder and additional chilli powder.  Some one mentioned sugar and i always add a little to my spag sauce  so I added a tablespoon of that too. diced up my chicken pretty small and threw it in...boiled for a while as I stirred than simmered for a while, had my boys (10 and 12) taste test advising that i would be adding some  cheese on each bowl with a dollop of s,c and some tortilla chips!!! THEY LOVED IT!!!  so there are my two cents for what its worth...go with your gut ... i cant remember the last time i followed a recipe to the T

text:
Excellent flavours- spice up it up as much as you'd like.  I also do this soup on the stovetop.  Brown the diced chicken in a little olive oil along with chopped onions and garlic.  Add to the other ingredients and simmer for about an hour.  I omitted the beer, used a splash of red wine vinegar,  and added chopped cilantro before serving with a little cilantro on top for garnish.  I once served this soup to 40 people and it was a huge hit!  Lots of second helpings!

text:
This was great!  Yes I was one of those that did read the reviews and changed it a bit.  Which is why I gave it 4 instead of 5.   I can tell that if I hadn't made the changes it would have only been a 3 or 4 star recipe.  I doubled the taco seasoning, instead of tomatoes with chilies I added fire roasted diced tomatoes and then a small can of diced chilies, added frozen corn and lastly added 2 of the homestyle stock gel packs.   I agree with others and use a GOOD quality beer.  Remember if you wouldn't drink it because of the flavor then don't cook with it!  Will do this again but tweaking it.  A little too heavy on the tomato for us so I'm going to eliminate the sauce and see how that goes.
UPDATE:  So for those that like this soup but get heartburn from all the tomato you can sub the can of tomato sauce with a can of pumpkin.  It will give it the kind of creamy texture and you can't taste the pumpkin.  Kids and husband said it tasted the same.

Hit the spot! Very similar to slow cooker Chicken Tortilla soup but chunkier/ less soupy. Great topping for nachos or baked potatoes. Instead of taco seasoning packet I used 1 tablespoon chili powder, 1 &1/2 tsp cumin,  1/4 teaspoon garlic powder, 1/4 teaspoon onion powder, 1/4 teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes 1/4 teaspoon dried oregano, 1/4 teaspoon paprika, 1/4 tsp ground chipotle pepper, 1 tsp sea salt and 1 tsp black pepper and a bay leaf. Delicious!!!  This recipe makes  a full crock pot and only lasted 2 days in our home. No need to substitute anything. It's perfect the way it is. Very flavorful. I made this last night for guests.  It was a great hit!  I didn't change anything except to add some heat with red pepper flakes and serve hot sauce on the side.  Also, I rinsed the black beans before adding, although the recipe didn't specify.  I used a crock pot liner so clean up was a breeze.  The chicken breasts were frozen when I put them in and after 5 hours, when I took them out, they just fell apart, making the shredding process easy peasy.  I will definitely keep this one and make again.  Less fussing in the kitchen means more quality time with my guests!  Thank you Patti, for a "keeper".

text:
My personal opinion is if you're going to make a recipe for the first time, always follow the directions to a tee, and make changes accordingly, or make notes for next time. But you'll never know what you truly think of it as long as you're fiddling with the recommendations. Now, if you have allergies or a devout disdain for any of the ingredients, that's all together another story---and change away! But all that to say, I followed this recipe as closely as I could, even following the suggested "taco seasoning" (even though I already had  my own prepackaged taco seasoning on hand), and it was delicious. And after eating it, I would honestly say that if I had used the taco seasoning that I had already on hand, it wouldn't have been nearly as good. I also used a 12 oz bottled Pacifico beer---cause it was the lightest and cheapest we had. Just follow the directions if you can, and it'll be a treat!

Do not use 3 whole chicken breasts. That's gotta be a mistake. I used 4 chicken breasts (the halves, not full breasts) and I had to add more liquid. I used chicken broth instead of beer, and when I determined it wasn't "soupy" enough, k added extra chicken brother and a bottle of (uh oh, this is Canadian)... Mott's Caesar. It's a Clamato juice with vodka. Tomato based. Use Bill Echols Taco Seasoning recipe, but double it. Everything else I stuck to the recipe. Really great. Definitely top it of with sour cream, avocado, cheese, and tortilla strips!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Well, this is a keeper! My two-year old really liked this soup, spices and all.  I took the original poster's advice and made used her taco seasoning (minus the 1 tbsp. of chili powder--didn't have any).  (1/4 teaspoon garlic powder 1/4 teaspoon onion powder 1/4 teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes 1/4 teaspoon dried oregano 1/2 teaspoon paprika 1 1/2 teaspoons ground cumin 1 teaspoon sea salt 1 teaspoon black pepper).  I also didn't have beer or the green chiles, so used chicken stock and omitted the chiles; we didn't miss them.  Recipe is very versatile and easy to adapt the canned ingredients to what you have on hand (I subbed kidney beans for black beans).  I also just made on the stove top instead of in the crock pot and it was lovely.

text:
Let's start with the good news. I'm not a beer fan at all, but I didn't taste any beer at all (I used Killian's). The other good news is that I am the biggest weenie when it comes to spicy food, and I was able to eat this just fine. 

Now for the bad news. To be perfectly honest, I don't understand the five star ratings. I just made this tonight and I thought it was pretty bland.  I wonder, though if chicken broth would be better to give it more flavor. I'm not sure if I would ever make this again, but maybe I'd try chicken broth and I would add a lot more spices... not sure what spices, but it needs more. I was definitely underwhelmed. My boyfriend wanted to rate this three stars, and I wanted to rate it two... I'd give it two and a half stars.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed this recipe exactly. Used Modelo Especial as the beer (light Mexican beer), drained/rinsed both cans of beans, and used the Bill Echols taco seasoning. It had a great flavor with the perfect amount of spice! I'm from Texas, and this was as good as my favorite TexMex restaurant tortilla soup. I used three frozen chicken breasts, left it all in the crockpot for 8 hours on low and 1 hour on warm (waiting for guests to arrive). I shredded the chicken straight in the crockpot instead of dirtying another dish. I had avocado slices, pico de gallo (premade at HEB), chopped cilantro, tortilla chips, and shredded cheddar for guests to add as toppings. And last but certainly not least, I squeezed half of a key lime over each serving - really gives it a nice fresh zing! Definitely will make this again.

text:
I used the recipe as is. The only thing I changed was that I used ground beef instead of chicken. That is a personal preference. Red sauce = beef, white = chicken or pork but that is just me. 

So my picky teen ate two bowels full to the brim (mind you don't know where she puts it and there are no signs of her eating like this anywhere on her body). Husband also said he could eat this and chili in the same week the two were very different in taste for those that are wondering. I thought it was good. It reminded me of a spicy vegetable soup(not my favorite) but it had enough of a Mexican flare to be just enough different that I enjoyed it also.  I will make this when I am being pestered to make a "vegetable soup". Over all it is a good soup. I didn't think it was "lick the bowel" good but my family thought it was.  It makes a lot. I had left overs and enough to freeze for another meal. Fingers crossed that it freezes well. Also THE BEER IS A MUST IN THIS RECIPE. It does not taste the same without it.

text:
I thought I had a really good chicken taco soup recipe...until I tried this one!  I was worried about not draining and rinsing the black beans because I've never had a recipe that didn't, but I didn't drain them and it was fine.  I didn't have any beer and substituted 12 oz chicken bullion.  I was out of tomato sauce and substituted a big squeeze of ketchup!  It was still delicious!  Really, from now on this is my go-to chicken taco soup recipe.  Best I've ever had.

text:
Made this and loved it! Here's the changes I did to the recipe:

Because I have teens in the house who pick out onions out of everything I make, I left the onion out of this recipe but added green onions as garnish at serving time.

I added two cans of corn instead of one.

I used 2 packets of Taco Seasoning Mix, 1 Chicken, 1 regular. 

At the last 30 minutes to go, I added 3/4 cup sour cream to the soup. This made it even more creamier.

I garnished with Sour cream, green onions, avocado, and crushed Tostitos Lime Flavored Tortilla Chips. Dash of Cholula or a squeeze of lime.

It was awesome.

text:
This soup was super easy to make and SO good!!  I substituted a can of chicken stock for the beer; added a generous amount of cumin; a few dashes of Penzey's Chili Con Carne; and 2 garlic gloves.  It had the perfect amount of spice.  My fiancee normally adds Tabasco to soups but did not this time - yet it was not too spicy.  The chicken shredded perfectly after about 4 hours in the crockpot.  We topped it with sour cream, shredded cheddar cheese, and crushed tortilla strips.  Cornbread on the side.  Definitely a 5-star recipe!!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I first made this for a Halloween party and I've made it over and over since! Ive been asked for the recipe several times. I love this recipe because it is so easy and it can be easily made gluten free. I use 2 pounds of chicken breast instead of 3 breasts because that can vary quite a bit with the giant chickens now. Use GF beer and McCormick's Taco seasoning because it is GF.

The hardest part of this recipe is shredding the chicken. This is where patience comes in because if you cook it all day on low, it is much easier to shred than if you try for high for 5 hours or so. 

I have made this once without beer because my dad didn't have any GF beer and while good, I think the beer gives it a richness in the broth that is otherwise missing.

text:
I absolutely love this chili/soup!
I've made this about 5 times now and each time I've made it a little differently.
Here is what I have determined thus far:
I prefer either chicken broth or Hard Apple Cider such as Angry Orchard in place of the beer.
Also, don't be afraid to add chickpeas and all sorts of other beans to this recipe to make it more of a chili.
It's great spicy or medium!
I love adding avocados as a garnish/different texture.
Don't forget the tortilla chips, sour cream, and cheese!

I didn't have exactly the right ingredients for this, but luckily it's very flexible - even to the extent of using plain ol' Miller Lite for the beer. I only used 1 can of tomatoes and about 1 pound of "Refried Beans Without The Refry" (recipe from this site) with the black beans. I made it today for dinner tomorrow, but know from my oh, so necessary testing that this is good already - I can hardly wait to heat it up tomorrow. It makes a bunch so we have some frozen for another day. Matching the soup with some sweet Texas cheese cornbread and guacamole and I'll be all that! Thanks for sharing the recipe with us.

text:
I have made this recipe several times and it is so easy and delicious. The chicken ends up perfectly tender and shreds easily. I make my own taco seasoning (from AllRecipes.com of course!). The only part I keep experimenting with is how much beer to add. The first time I followed the recipe exactly and it was way too strong. I think the trick is to use a beer that you really like and since I'm not really a beer drinker it throws me off if I use too much. Last time I used about half the amount of beer and tasted the beer ahead of time to make sure I liked it and it turned out perfect.

The first time I made this, I used thighs instead of chicken breast thinking that dark meat cooks better in the crockpot.  It was good, but thigh meat doesn't shred the way breast meat does, so I was frustrated with it.  I made it a second time with chicken breasts and it was sooo much better!  At the time of this review, I've made this recipe several times as well as for my extended family once and everyone loved it.  I will definitely keep this as a staple in my stack of recipes!

text:
This is a great recipe! I usually don't review highly rated recipes because the ratings normally speak for themselves; however I felt the need to review this due to some of the remarks that I read. Many people stated that the beer took away from the recipe. In my opinion this is not at all the case! I actually don't care for beer at all and surprisingly could taste it in the soup, but I found it added a great bit of flavor to it. Maybe it's the type of beer you use...I used Heineken. I loved it! I also don't normally care for spicy things, but somehow with okay with the bit of kick that was added to this soup. I didn't alter the recipe at all, and I actually get the sour cream and cheddar cheese with cottage cheese. It probably sounds disgusting but believe me it was good. I will be making this again and again...

text:
This was a hit for our family and I love how easy it is to make. 
I used Bud Light and it tasted great (not beer-y at all). I put  this together with frozen chicken breasts at 11 am and kept it cooking on high for 2 hours, then turned it to low before leaving the house. When we got home after our daughter's basketball game that night, it was fully cooked and scrumptious!
It was a tad on the spicy side for my 3 year old- but the Rotel I used must not have been mild and the chili beans may have been seasoned. 
This may become a regular meal for us....and I'm thinking about making it when we go camping. Thanks for the recipe!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1316715.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is a great place to start for Taco Soup, but it is in need of some changes. The beer is a problem. I tested it out by putting a fourth of a cup in and it completely changed the flavor. It didn't not better it and I can imagine that putting the whole can would have killed it for me. The KEY INGREDIENT of this recipe IS the TACO SEASONING! If it's not flavorful enough, add more taco seasoning! This is not enchilada soup. Adding cumin and chili powder caused major problems for me. I ended up having to almost double up on ingredients. But the taco seasoning really is what makes it! Everything else is personal preference. Also, sauteing the onions in butter first and using tomato paste totally added some great flavor!

5

text:
This soup was very tasty!!!  I did make some changes to make this more kid friendly.  I used one can of diced tomato with chilies, plus added an additional can of tomato sauce.  Since I only had an economy size bottle of taco seasoning I used about 1/4 cup more or less.  I cooked the soup on high for 5 hours then I took the chicken out but the soup was sort of missing something.  It was a bit spicy and just salty.  I added a some sugar to taste and it really brought the flavors of the soup together.  Then I added the shredded chicken back in and it was perfect.

I was looking for something to make for dinner and saw this, looked like something my family would enjoy.  I also liked the high ratings but after looking at the reviews am unsure.  I really don't know why people even rate a recipe at all if they didn't make it! Really? I think it's a five star only to find out you rated your own altered recipe! city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried this recipe a few weeks ago and really enjoyed it.  I made few changes to the recipe.  I used Bush's brand mild chili beans, 2 cans of mild Rotel, 2 cups (16oz) of frozen corn, and a Sam Adam's Boston Lager.  For the chicken breasts, I used 5 (2 lbs.) of Perdue's individually-wrapped chicken.  It turned out to be about the right amount of chicken for my preferences.  The only thing I noticed is it was still alittle spicy for my taste, but not mouth-burning.  I believe I will use one regular can of diced tomatoes next time to tone down the spice.  But it was delicious and I strongly recommend it with some crushed plain tortilla chips and grated cheddar, especially good for a cold winter day, or even a Superbowl party!

Half way through the cooking process I tasted the soup, it was really spicy and tasted awful. Really bad aftertaste of the beer. I had to fix it. I removed as much of the juice as possible, about 4 cups. Replaced it with 4 cups of chicken broth and a can of cream of chicken soup. Then, I made some Spanish rice and added it to the meal. Served the soup with all the fixings and it was a hit! I definitely would NOT add in the beer next time and I would use half of the taco seasoning.

text:
Yummy, easy, can't go wrong!  I made it for Christmas lunch - a little unorthodox (pardon the pun) but it was a hit!  Rave reviews from family, and a number of second helpings were had. 

The onions didn't soften as much as I would have liked.  It's possible I chopped them too big.  Next time I would soften them stove-top or chop smaller, just to be sure.  

Our family likes spicy, so I used some chili powder and a little cayenne.  You could also add crushed chilis and/or garlic powder - to taste.  Really, you can't go wrong!

userID:
6686187
Display Name:
halfnotes
isPro:

11

84
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/611568.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family loved this!  I had to make a few modifications because of what I had on hand.  I drained and rinsed the chili and black beans, used frozen corn (about a can's worth), used 2 cans diced tomatoes without the chilies and then added a can of diced chilies.  I used 12 oz. chicken broth instead of the beer.


This was a last minute meal idea so I did not make it in the crockpot.  I cooked it on the stove top and from start to finish took a little less than 45 minutes.


I boiled the chicken in salted water until it was almost cooked through, then chopped it up and set it aside.  I sauteed the onions in a tablespoon of olive oil and once they were softened, I added the taco seasoning.  Once that was thoroughly combined, I added everything but the chicken and brought it to a boil.  Once boiling I added the chicken and returned to a boil then reduced the heat to a simmer.  I only had time to simmer 5 minutes before we ate it.  My kids topped theirs off with some crushed tortilla chips and my husband and I ate it without any additional toppings.  It tasted wonderful!!

I substituted a couple things and it turned out to be one of the best soups I've ever had.  I used one soup size can of Rotel w/ habaneros (HOT) for tomatos and chilis, and some smoky chipotle paprika seasoning (2T and 1T of fajita seasoning) in lieu of the taco seasoning.  I also used about 8 oz of beer (chef's privilege on the remaining 4 oz!)  This is a layup crock pot recipe and I would have paid $5-6 for a bowl in a restaurant and been HAPPY about it.

I made this yesterday for myself and some coworkers for lunch. One hates beans and despite that she nearly licked the bowl clean it was so good. My changes were chicken broth subbed for beer, only used half a packet of taco seasoning because that's all I had, and frozen corn instead of canned because that's what I had on hand. I served this with light sour cream and shredded sharp cheddar cheese toppings and it was truly delicious.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
WOW! But this is what I did different...instead of the tomato sauce, I used a can of Rotel Mexican(lime and cilantro). The chili beans I used were spicy. The 3 skinless, boneless breasts weighed in at a little over 2lbs. I also added a tsp of smoked chipotle pepper (a personal fave!), along with a tsp or so of salt, a half tsp of smoked cumin, and about a tbsp of garlic powder-NOT garlic salt; it's a big difference! My soup turned out amazing! The heat was medium for us, so maybe omit the chipotle pepper if you're not a fan of heat. But definitely add the cumin! It's a perfect addition for anything Mexican, but doesn't add the heat. YUM!!

text:
This soup was delicious! It is kind of like combining chili and chicken tortilla soup. It is a tad spicy, but I followed the ingredients list exactly and wouldn't change that. I accidentally put it on high for the first 2 or so hours, so I knocked an hour off of the cook time and it was fine. Make sure to have a large crock pot, because it will be needed. It will cook down, but a large one is needed at first to hold all of the ingredients. The sour cream, cheese, and chips to top, as suggested, worked perfect. ty

text:
Sooooo easy and delicious! I made it in a hurry and didn't read how much tomato sauce you were supposed to put in until after I dumped the 15oz can in... I decided to cut back on the chicken broth (which I used instead of beer) to compensate for the extra liquid. I also didn't have as much time as it suggested for cooking, so I put in on high for 4 hours and left the chicken in the whole time. I used McCormick's Chicken Taco Seasoning, and topped with sour cream and chips. I remembered while taking my last bite that I was going to add cheese - it didn't need it (and neither does my waist)! Thanks for this recipe, it's a keeper and I'll definitely make it again! (Maybe I'll even make it the right way next time)   :)

text:
Turned out great! Everyone loved it and somehow mine made way more than 8 servings. I'll be eating taco soup all week now. I used the Bill Echols Taco Season recipe as recommended but didn't have cumin and added a little cayenne. I accidentally misread and put a can of vegetarian chili instead of chili beans. WHOOPS! Once I realized that, I only used one can of diced tomato w/green chills and added about 8-12 oz of water in addition to the beer (fat tire) since I thought the chili would add a lot of flavor and salt. I'm not sure how much chicken I used because I could only find thinly sliced chicken breast. It may have been equivalent to 4 breasts in the end. Turned out PERFECT and I don't even regret the chili mistake!

Excellent.  I like to make things as written first, since that is the only fair way to rate a recipe, but I only had "hot" chili beans, rather than regular.  This made the soup a little too spicy for our children but the sour cream took the edge off.  Next time, I'll be sure to use regular chili beans. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Other modification suggestions: Add beer, chicken, AND vegetable broth to make it more soupy and add even more flavors (more vegetable than chicken as the chicken creates some of its own). Instead of just chicken breast, we used chicken thighs as well to have a mix of white and dark meat. I like yellow squash in my tortilla soup so we sliced some and added it about 2 hours before serving so that it wouldn't be too mushy. Also, instead of garlic powder as others have suggested, we added 6 whole cloves of garlic that soaked up all the juice while adding their own flavor to the soup. Cilantro is a must.

This soup has only a few ingredients but so tasty. I only use half the amount of cream cheese so the squash flavor isn't overpowered by the cream cheese. This is a recipe that I use every fall.

text:
Love this recipe! I was a little wary of the beer, but it added a lovely aroma and taste. I used Sam Adams Light to try to cut back on the calories a bit and because we're watching our sodium intake, I added frozen instead of canned corn, used no-salt-added tomato sauce and diced tomatoes (plain, I added a separate can of green chilis instead), and used previously cooked dried beans in favor of canned. The only downside is that after the first night, most of the liquid was gone (and my attempts to make more resulted in sub-par leftovers). Next time, I'm going to double the liquid. I like my soup to be soupy, not chili/stew-like.

This soup turned out great! My husband had two bowls. I cooked it on HIGH for 4 hours and it was perfect. The tenders quicked much faster than the breasts. I will definitely make this again it was so easy!

text:
I first made this for my other half , who honestly, was less than eager to try it. After he had munched his way through 3 bowls, it was safe to assume we had a winner. I have since prepared it for group events, family get-togethers and pot lucks and it is always popular, the recipe requested over and over. The first time I prepared as per the recipe but ever since I have made my personal version, as follows:
I use a British wheat beer, tomato paste as opposed to tomato sauce, frozen corn instead of tinned and added an extra breast. I also cook on low for at least eight hours and use a fork to start pulling the meat apart after about 6 hours without removing it from the slow cooker, it really falls apart by itself. Very nice!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
THIS WAS DELISH!! I made this when I had an empty fridge & needed dinner. All I had were dried beans (black, small white & great northern) & frozen homemade chicken broth, which already had shredded chicken in it. I didn't use a slow cooker just simmered everything on the stove. Followed recipe, but excluded beer & chili beans. Didn't have diced tomato, so cut up a few grape tomato stragglers I had & added some sliced pimientos for color/texture.  Added crushed garlic and followed poster's recipe for taco seasoning which was PERFECT! I'm keeping that for ALL future taco/mexican dishes. I also didn't have tortilla chips so I baked some cut up corn tortillas that were coated w/olive oil.  Luckily, I had some left over sour cream..that just brought it all together!  This will surely be a dish I crave and our new regular soup dish for my family! Thank you.

text:
JUST MADE THIS LAST NIGHT & IT TURNED OUT VERY GOOD.  IN MY EYES, IT WAS CHILI, WITH CHICKEN.  IF YOUR LOOKING FOR A HEALTHY VERSION, I RECOMMEND LEAVING OUT THE TACO SEASONING (ENORMOUS SODIUM), & ADDING YOUR OWN SEASONINGS. THE REST OF THE INGREDIENTS ARE PRETTY HEALTHY. I ALSO OPTED FOR THE BUSH CHILI BEANS. I ADDED A CAN OF MILD & A CAN OF MEDIUM. HAD A SLIGHT KICK TO IT, SO ADJUST ACCORDING TO YOUR TASTES. OVERALL, I WILL BE MAKING THIS AGAIN!

text:
Great recipe! I made a few changes based on previous reviews & personal preference... Left out the chili beans (the 1 can of black beans was enough for us), added minced garlic, a pack of ranch dressing mix, used a Corona for the beer, and in addition to the beer I also added homemade chicken broth since we wanted a soup, not a chili. I used 2 big chicken breasts which was plenty. Also to make it more kid friendly for my little ones, I used a pack of mild taco seasoning mix as well as mild Rotel tomatoes.

text:
I made this for a staff lunch and everyone loved it.  I doubled the recipe and made the following small changes:
Used 1/2 beer and 1/2 chicken broth for liquid;
used Trader Joe's fired roasted corn, frozen instead of canned corn;
added 1 T chopped garlic and 1 tsp. smoked paprika.
For toppings, I added diced avocado and cilantro to the mexican cheese and sour cream.
Delicious!

text:
This was delish! I followed the recipe exactly (except I used frozen corn). I used Blue Moon Summer Wheat for the beer and there was no funny or bitter taste. I also used the recipe for taco seasoning by Patti (in the top review). I mixed all ingredients and put my frozen chicken breast on top and cooked on low for 8 hours. Took the chicken out and shredded it and mixed back in for 2 more hours. Served with Mexican shredded cheese and sour cream. It was a huge hit. So easy. Will make often.

text:
Made this today - used water instead of beer and instead had the beer with dinner ;) Also used skinless on the bone chicken thighs (5), which I find more flavorful as well as being cheaper. I also used Trader Joe's Taco Seasoning as I didn't have time to mix my own before work.  

When making again, I will use the custom taco seasoning recipe (and make extra to have on hand) and top with cilantro.  VERY easy and quick to put together and is forgiving of modifications to the recipe.

Great recipe! I love that there is no prep work required other than a bit of slicing. It wasn't necessary to remove the chicken to cut up; it flaked apart easily with a little help from a fork. This recipe is a keeper.

text:
The best part about this soup is the ease of preparation, with everyday ingredients found in the fridge and pantry. The only alterations I made were to substitute 1/2 cup of salsa for the tomato sauce, couple of bay leaves, and red pepper flakes for some heat.  I used a bottle of dark stout, which I thought added that extra richness and color to the soup. We enjoyed it very much!

text:
This was a hit with my family!  I didn't have enough time to do this in the crockpot, so I altered it to a stovetop version.  I included all the ingredients except the chicken and simmered for about an hour.  Also, since I didn't have rotel, I substituted a can of diced tomatoes and a can of chopped green chilies.  About 15 minutes before serving, I added precooked shredded chicken.  This was so flavorfull and not too spicy for my young children.  Thank you for a great recipe!

text:
This is a delicious hearty soup on a cold winter day!   Here is a tip for anyone who interested in making this soup that may be wondering how much chicken to buy:  The package of skinless boneless chicken breasts I bought weighed around 2.3 lbs., which was plenty.  When I made this soup, it yielded approximately 8 quarts.  I had plenty left over to put in the freezer!

text:
I made this yesterday for a super bowl party happening this evening.  It was so delish that my hubby and I ate most of it for dinner last night so I am making it again right now for the party.  Yesterday's version was done with chicken broth instead of beer, as all we have on hand is pabst blue ribbon and that didn't seem robust enough, and I used the Bill Echols Taco Seasoning recipe, all of it.  I rinsed the beans, using black and pinto.  Loved the soup, but it didn't have much liquid in it.

Today's version is done the same as yesterdays', but I subbed a 14oz can of ground, peeled tomatoes for the small can of tomato sauce, hoping for more liquid.  Hope it makes it to the party intact, it smells awfully good!  Will serve it with sides of sour cream and shredded cheddar, and blue corn chips for dipping or crumbling, diners choice.

This recipe is a keeper, so easy and soooo good!  Thanks Patti

text:
I suppose it would be better if I had not drained the chili beans. I hesitated but when I saw diced tomatoes with green chilies, "undrained", I automatically thought I should drain the chili beans, silly me. I found there's something missing in the soup so I added a cube of chicken bouillon and it made a difference. It has a nice kick which I didn't expect at all but I love spicy food so no complaints about that. I only used 2 full chicken breasts though because I think three would be way too much meat for this recipe. Actually I would use less meat but more tomatoes and corn next time for personal preference. I don't think the beer is overpowering at all(I used Mexican beer). Overall this recipe is very simple and easy to make. I'll make it again.

text:
This recipe is a dream come true because you can use it so many ways. I used it as advertised (a soup) the first night. For leftovers, I took a slotted spoon to let the juice drain off and used it as the filling in a taco shell - awesome! For another dinner I drained off the juice again and used it to top a plate of tortilla chips and had awesome nachos. I bet it would be great as a baked potato topper, too. I only had dark beer in the house at the time of preparation so I just used broth and it was still fantastic!

I actually want to give this one 4.5 stars.  To spice it up a little, I added some red pepper flakes and cayenne pepper.  I also put the onion into the food processer which liquified it somewhat.  I didn't have any garlic or I would added that, as wll.  I cooked it on low for about 8 hours.  Served it with the dollop of low fat sour cream and sprinkled with low fat medium cheddar cheese.  I also crushed lime & chili chips over the top.  I highly recommend this recipe!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/153047.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This dish was very good! I made some substitutions based on what I had on hand - 1 can of chick peas instead of chili beans, 1 can of stewed tomatoes instead of tomato sauce, 1 cup chicken broth instead of beer, 1 can of Rotel, 2 packages of taco seasoning and like 5-6 chicken breasts. Mine turned out really meaty and was perfectly seasoned. I cooked on low for 6 hours because I was way from home. After shredding the chicken I cooked for 1 hour on low. We didn't eat it until the next day and MMMMM! I put half away in the freezer for another time and I can't wait.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2011-10-15T20:09:31.817

text:
My boyfriend and I loved this recipe. It works great as both a soup, or you can drain a little of it and use the chicken/bean/corn portion to stuff in a soft shell to make a chicken taco. Both sooo yummy! I definitely recommend using the beer too, instead of just broth. It really gave it a yummy, unique zing that plain ol broth wouldn't do. My only complaint/question is I made the taco seasoning recipe that the creator of this recipe listed (it is in the first review), and since it does't indicate how much of the seasoning to use, I used it all, and it was WAY TOO MUCH!!! WAY TOOOOO SPICY (we were avble to fix it) but it was way too hot to leave as-is. Does anyone know how much of the actual seasoning to use?? Thanks!

text:
Fabulous! I was a little skeptical putting this all together. I had to make several subs. I only had 1/4 of an onion, replaced the tomato sauce with a can of tomato paste and a can of water, replaced the diced tomatoes and chilis with a can of stewed tomatoes (in the blender for a few seconds) and half a can of mild salsa. Also only had mozzarella cheese and only black beans. I used 3 tsp's taco sauce and could have used more. I figured with all these substitutions that it would be awful. I was wrong and my picky eaters loved it! It just needed a pinch of salt.

text:
What a warm and inviting soup!  I made it today for the first time and it was a hit with my very picky teenage daughter.  My husband loved it also.  I substituted chicken broth for beer, per previous reviews and it was very tasty.  I used kidney beans instead of black beans as that's what I had on hand.  I will definitely revisit this recipe many times!  I turned the crock to "high" for the last hour or so to really thicken and soften the vegetables/beans a bit more.  Served with corn muffins, sour cream and cheese for a satisfying one bowl meal!

text:
I love this recipe, make it all the time. Perfect dish for summer because using the crockpot helps not heat up the house. I do use chicken broth instead of beer and I only use about 6oz of it. I also drain all of the canned stuff to make it thicker, so for us it is more like a chicken chili. I always serve it with chips, cheese and sour cream on the side, we tend to use it as a dip. Very filling just the same and the leftovers freeze and reheat very well!

text:
Wonderful and flavorful! Made this for a work potluck and everyone raved about it!!! Will make this again and again!
Edited: I have made this the traditional way as well as a more milder version to be more kid friendly. For a milder taste I used 1 can diced and 1 can tomatoes with chilies, 1 can chicken broth instead of beer. Both taste amazing! I also have taken leftovers and drained the excess liquid and cooked enchilada style with flour tortillas in the oven for 30 min. with some of the drained liquid and cheese baked on top. It is fabulous! This recipe is so versitile and EASY!

region:

country:
None
text:
For being easy, delicious and healthy. I made this on the stove top and sauteed the onion and garlic with a little cumin.  Then after all of the ingredients were dumped in (I used 32 oz box of chicken bouillon), instead of chicken, I floated 6 frozen Boca burgers in the broth until they were soft. (Microwaving them makes them hard) When soft, I pulled them out and diced them up.  For those following weight watchers, I calculated this to be only 2 points per cup before adding cheese or sour cream.  Yum.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is so good!  Instead of raw chicken breasts I bought a pre-cooked whole roasted chicken and removed the meat from the bones.  I added the chicken at the end just so it could heat up.  I also added a T of chili powder and a couple tsp of ground cumin.  I substituted kidney beans for the chili beans and chicken stock for the beer.  Served it with shredded cheddar, sour cream and crushed tortilla chips.******UPDATE*****If you are using the entire roasted chicken then double the recipe or else there is WAY too much meat.  I just used half the roasted chicken and froze the other half for later.

Oh my goodness!  This is a WONDERFUL recipe!  I was looking for a chili....and this was a little thin as it is intended to be a soup.  So, I just scooped out about a 1/2 cup of the liquid, added a bit of cornstarch to the liquid, stirred it up until it was thin.  Added it back to the soup and WOW !!!! Instant hit with my kids. No other alterations necessary~ I'm making a double batch next time!

This soup was excellent!!!! I followed the exact directions and it came out just how I wanted it to. I was a little worried that it would be more like a chili but it was more like a soup, which is what I wanted. I used rotel tomatoes with chilies (one mild, one regular) and the regular gave it quite a bit of heat. Next time I think I will do both mild but everything else came out great. I used a low sodium taco seasoning as well. I will definitely be making this again!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the best soup known to man kind!  I have made a few changes based on other reviewers recommendations, using chicken broth instead of beer and using 2 cans of black beans instead of the chili beans.  If I don't have the time to wait for the slow cooker, I will very lightly simmer the chicken for about an hour (i'm sure less time will suffice if you are in a serious time crunch but I've never tested it...), take the chicken out and let it cool.  Make sure to not BOIL the chicken unless you want rubbery chicken.  Then I will add the remaining ingredients to the home made chicken broth instead of adding boxed chicken broth and let simmer on the stove.  When the chicken has cooled enough to shred, I add it back to the soup and cook for another 15-20 minutes.  I haven't had a chicken tortilla soup in a restuarant this good, YUM!

text:
This soup is blah- it calls for way too much chicken and it's bland.  I honestly don't see how is has so many good reviews.  I've made something very similar before- it's called taco soup and I used ground beef- it also called for a can of olives.  This was a bit different but tastes about the same.  I tried to follow the recipe as close as I could.  But I also tried to cut the sodium content- rotel and chili beans have a ton so sodium in them! I also used that Echols recipe for the taco seasoning.  I added about 5 cloves of garlic- because garlic makes everything better- but not this soup!  I really wanted to use the beer- but I wanted a dark mexican beer like someone mentioned but we never got around to buying it so I used 12 oz chicken broth.  I also added 3/4 red bell pepper because I had it in the fridge.  I added 4 chicken breast halves and there is A LOT of chicken in this.  I think the 3 WHOLE chicken breast is an error because that would be 6 halves.  Oh yeah and I did use the mexican tomatoe sauce like someone recommended.  Overall this soup needs more seasoning, it is so bland!!!.  I don't think my small substitutions made a big difference.  I don't see how people find this spicy?  Maybe some jalepenos and a lot more cumin/chili pepper next time?  I topped it with cheese, sour cream and homemade corn tortilla chips.

I won't make this again.

text:
Excellent! I didn't have chili beans, so I subbed canned pinto beans. I threw in 28 oz of diced tomatoes instead of 20 oz, and tossed in extra seasoning-- chill powder, garlic powder and cumin. I also put in about 1/2 cup of salsa and several jalapeno slices for that extra kick! I set it on low at 11 a.m. and by 7 p.m. it was ready to go! I served it over spanish rice, and instead of spoons we used homemade tortilla chips drizzled with salt-- divine!

userID:
4532595
Display Name:
CheddarIsBetter
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
6
favoritesCount:
32
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This will be one of the life-saving recipes I can turn to during a busy day---you set everything in the slow cooker, turn it to low, and you come home to a wonderful-smelling house and a tasty meal at the end of the day.    Some tidbits about my changes: I used "hot" taco seasoning to give it a little kick, I used closer to 16oz of beer, and I also ended up adding some chicken stock to the mixture to create more liquid for the soup.  Also, I didn't want it to be so heavy on tomato and spice, so I thought the chicken stock would add flavor and prevent the tomato/spice flavors from being TOO dominant.  Addtionally, there isn't really a need to have to open up the slow cooker just to shred the chicken.  I ended up leaving it in there for 8 hours, untouched, and I took out the chicken and shredded it with forks just before serving.  It's better not to have to open up your slow cooker, because it makes the temperature drop a lot and thus increases cooking time significantly.  All in all, a great recipe, and very forgiving/accommodating to different tastes.
Review:

5

text:
I LOVE this soup!!! The flavors in it are wonderful, I used the Bill Echols Taco Seasoning recipe as suggested. I wasn't sure about the beer, so I put in half a beer and half chicken broth. You can't detect a beer taste in the slightest, and I'm not a drinker, so I would be able to tell. I added a little bit of fresh chopped cilantro, and a squirt of lime juice as well. The best part...this recipe is EXTREMELY easy! Put everything in the crock pot in the morning, go to work, come home...dinner is served! I will make this again and again. Thank you so much!

text:
Just had 3rds on this hearty soup! But I made a few changes. Here's what I did - same ingredients and used the seasoning recipe that the author posts...but changed beer to 32 oz free range chicken broth, added an extra can black beans, 1 can kidney beans, and extra corn. Used Hormel VEGGIE chili. Also gave "generous" measurements when it came to the cumin and chili powder. I also had a half bag of frozen peppers/onions so I threw that in as well. This is AMAZING and will replace all of my tortilla soup recipes as it is the easiest to make and tastes the best!

text:
I used chicken broth instead of beer and only used 1 can of the diced tomatoes since I'm not a huge tomato person.  My first bowl of it actually wasn't so great.  So on my second go at it, I added the sour cream and fritos instead of tortilla chips and they both made a HUGE difference... The fritos makes it taste more like a taco and the sour cream mellows out the taco seasoning, which I thought was too strong at first.  Will definitely make again!!

I make this at least once a month and freeze half of it so we can eat the leftovers. It's sooooo good and sooooo easy. text:
I can not stand beans, and I thought this recipe was FABULOUS! My husband wants me to add this to the weekly rotation...he said it was better than chili, which is a huge compliment. He even asked me to send some leftovers in his lunch tomorrow.   I left out the beer and added 1/2 a can of cream of chicken soup and 3/4 can of chicken broth. I also left out the onion as my family doesn't like. I also used canned Mexican corn, and 24 ounces of diced tomatoes with green chilies.   Don't forget the chips, sour cream and cheese! It makes it even better!!!  Great recipe!! Will make again with the above substitutions.

text:
OMG - so delicious!!! After reading everyone's reviews I followed some substitutions: I used a can of chicken broth instead of beer and I used the taco seasoning by Bill here: http://allrecipes.com/Recipe/Taco-Seasoning-I/Detail.aspx ----- But I added 1/2 tsp of Chipotle for some extra kick! ---- I also substituted a can of Chili beans with Pinto beans since the Chili beans has a sauce pre-mixed in and I try to avoid the extra salt and preservatives. ----- I drained the beans and can of corn but I dumped the cans of tomato w/green chilies in with all it's juice.  I followed the cooking instructions exactly and it turned out PERFECT. I will most definitely be making this dish again and again!

Rating:

dateLastModified:
