userID:
1032812
Display Name:
Michelle Roth-Kiva
isPro:
False
followersCount:
97
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1009
favoritesCount:
2526
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2689406.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Pretty good and certainly easy enough to whip up  on a busy weeknight! All I had to do was chop an onion (last night), open a bunch of cans this morning, dump everything into my slow cooker, turn it on and LEAVE!!! B/c of the ease factor, I even had spare time to make homemade taco seasoning (Bill Echols) :) I did make a couple of substitutions, basically to accommodate what I already had in my pantry. I used an 11 oz. can of Mexicorn, (2) 15.5 oz. cans of diced tomatoes with green chilies (I figured that it was OK to do so since I used less corn...), HOT Mexican tomato sauce (La Preferedia brand) and, as mentioned b4, Bill Echols taco seasoning for the packaged stuff. I used Corona for my beer and Busch's chili beans in medium sauce. And since I only had frozen chicken breasts available, I dumped those in the slow cooker with everything else. Set on LOW for 8 hours with excellent results (because I leave for work at 7 AM, I set my sc for 8 hr.; I don't get home until close to 7 PM and my warm setting will only run for 4 hr. MAX). Served steaming bowls with a sprinkling of shredded monterey-jack cheese, chopped cilantro, a squirt of fresh lime juice and tortilla chips for dunking! My fiance commented that he'd be happy if I made this again (and he HATES beans!!!). I think I'll try this with ground beef (pre-cooked) next time!  Play around with this - it can be easily changed to suit your tastes. Tx. for sharing, Patti! :-)
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2010-03-12T05:24:44.27
helpfulCount:
0

text:
Delicious and super easy! All you do is dump everything in the crockpot and you have a tasty, hearty soup at the end of the day. I substituted a can of chicken broth for the beer because I'm not a beer drinker and I only used half an onion because that seemed like plenty for me. Otherwise, I followed the recipe exactly. You can taste some spiciness but not too much at all. The soup is great with sour cream and cheese, but the soup has a really great flavor on it's own. Very satisfying.

text:
This is a fantastic, easy soup. I made just a few adjustments - I used 2 -14.5 oz cans  of diced tomatoes with green chilis, 2 packages of taco season and an additional can of great white beans. This soup had a nice kick but not too much. THE KEY to this soup is the quality of the beer. Use a hoppy quality beer or a quality stoudt for optimum flavor. I used Sierra Nevada Torpedo and it was perfect. Guiness would also be a great choice. PS: Shredding can be a pain, I just cut into bite size morsels.

I thought this was delicous!  With some minor changes.  I added 1 tsp of garlic powder, 1 tsp of cumin to the taco seasoning. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband and I have both had head colds, so something warm and spicy sounded perfect, but I was starving and did not want to wait until tomorrow to eat this! So I thawed some chicken breasts in the microwave while I boiled 2 cups of water for some chicken broth (I am not a beer drinker...) I cooked the chicken on low in some oil and fajita seasoning while the broth boiled. I added all the ingredients (+ some dried red pepper and garlic salt) to the broth while the chicken "slow cooked" and tried to let everything stew. Once the chicken was cooked I shredded it in the seasoned oil, then added it to the soup. In an hours time, I had some AMAZING soup that was spicy enough to clear my sinuses! Can't wait to have the leftovers for lunch tomorrow :D

text:
NEW FAVORITE crock pot recipe! Used one can each of black beans, kidney beans, and chili beans (cause we like beans in this house), and a small jar of salsa in place of the tomatoes with chiles (cause that's what I had), and it was delicious! Cheap to make, and I think you could sub a lot of ingredients depending on your preference/pantry supply and it will still turn out great! I liked it served over rice and hubby liked it served over rotini noodles. This one made it into the TNT recipe book for our house - thank you!!

text:
Wow... I have never had a more delicious taco soup...  So hearty and flavorful!  Couple changes I made: used 15 oz. can of tomato sauce instead of 8 oz, because it looked like it may dry up after cooking so long.  Also, did chicken tenders and left in for 8-9 hours (only took out at end to shred).  Chicken came out practically melting and shredded so nice and easy.  This was a BIG hit with me and my husband.  He said this one is definately "a keeper!"

text:
This soup is unbelievable and very good for you!  It is packed with protein and fiber.  I did make a few changes.  I always cook the onion first before adding it and I always use low sodium taco seasoning. Plus, I add 1 cup of heated low sodium chicken broth about an hour before it's done.  I've never had to add salt or any other seasonings and the little bit of extra liquid makes it a perfect consistency.  This recipe is definitely a keeper!!

text:
I've been searching for the perfect tortilla/taco soup and unfortunately this just wasn't what I was looking for.  I should have realized this when the submitter was unsure as to whether to call it soup or chili.  The beer didn't work for me, even though I do use beer in chili. And I had to add 2 cups of chicken broth to get this to the consistency of soup.  Even then I was disappointed with the results - it took a fair amount of sour cream and avocado to balance out the tastes.  I ended up throwing most of this out.

text:
Loved this soup. Subbed chicken broth for beer and added the whole 15oz can of tomato sauce. I used cannelleni beans instead of chili beans cuz that's what I had. Next time I will soften my onions first. After six hours in the crock pot they were still crunchy. I only used two large boneless chicken breast (which I put in frozen) and it was plenty of chicken. I cooked the first hour on high and then turned down to low. Makes a lot so I have some for my lunch today. Very good!

text:
With alterations to suit our taste, this soup was delicious!!!! We don't care for the beer taste, so we leave that out. I have not made it with the corn, but would try that someday.  I also added cumin, because I really like the smokey flavor.  I add a can of diced green chilies, too.  I have put frozen chicken breasts into the crock pot and they cooked just as well as thawed ones.  I then pullled them out to shred them, returned them to the crock pot for another hour or 2.  I love this soup for football and Sundays as an alternative to chili. (only because we can't eat chili every week!)

text:
I have made this three times now, and it is so good!! I double the chili beans, black beans, corn, taco seasoning and chicken- use frozen chicken breasts- it fills up my large slow cooker that way. I cook it for about 7 or 8 hours on low- usually at night. The chicken is so tender- it shreds with two forks! DEFINITELY use Bill Echols "taco seasoning I" from this site!! Serve over some tortilla chips- I add sour cream, my husband and kids do not- too good!! Freezes well too!!!

text:
Love this. Would not change a thing except, I did it all stovetop. I seasoned the chicken breast and stuck them under the broiler on low untill the juices ran clear then set aside to cool while I assembled the rest in a large pot. I shredded the chicken an added and let simmer until the onion was done, but still just a little crisp (personal choice).  Topped with the crushed chips and sour cream.  All was done in about an hour and still yummy! Made it several times and will keep in my recipe box for future use!

text:
My whole family enjoyed this dish including my 13 month old (with a spoon of sur cream.)  I was making this with what I had on hand so I made 3 substitutions.  I only had 1 can of rotel so I substituted diced tomato for the second, I used great northern beans in place of chili beans, and I used cooked chopped turkey that we had frozen after Thanksgiving in place of the chicken.  I am looking forward to trying this again using the homemade taco seasoning.  This worked great to use up leftover meat. I completely recommend it.  My three year old said it was "dewicious" and she is pretty picky.

text:
I love this recipe.  I only gave it 4 stars because of the changes I made.  I used boneless/skinless chicken thighs instead of breasts because they were on sale.  I used chicken broth instead of beer as well.  I stuck the chicken thighs down into the mixture to cook.  I cooked it for about 9 hours on low (the time i was at work), and when i came home from work, the chicken thighs were tender and juicy.  I shredded the chicken, and it ended up an amazing, hearty, heathly soup.

text:
This soup was great! Super easy to fix and easy to modify if you need to. I didn't have canned tomatoes with chiles, so I used a can of diced tomatoes and threw in some green salsa. My husband doesn't like spicy chiles/soups, so he added some ketchup and honey to his bowl plus some shredded cheese and he LOVED it! I ate mine spicy but will compromise and probably make it with ketchup and honey in the crock pot next time. I also skipped the chili beans and only used one can of black beans, as he also doesn't like a lot of beans in his soups. Topped with sour cream, shredded cheese and crushed tortilla chips this soup was FANTASTIC! :)

None
text:
If you have any doubt, CHECK IT AT THE DOOR, and make this soup because it is amazing!!! If using Patti's suggestion of Bill Echol's Seasoning mix, you have to make about 1.5x the stated recipe to yield 1.25oz as called for by recipe. I used beer, nothing bitter about it. I also added about 2C chicken broth, only bc I wanted a thinner soup, not a thicker chili consistency. Of course I added more of the base ing. like paprika, salt, etc. but I recommend tasting it at the 5 hour shredding mark to see how to adjust to fit your tastes. My only wish* would be for the chicken to be flavored somehow prior to adding it in the mix. Maybe as leftovers it will absorb more of the flavor of the soup, but as is it tastes like excellent soup with really moist boiled/shredded chicken tossed in. Still the best soup I've had in awhile though!!!!

text:
This was *so* delicious! And I could not believe how easy it was - if you can use a can opener, chop an onion, and stir - you can make this. Most of the ingredients I already had on hand, and what I didn't have was not expensive to go out and purchase. I ended up using a 28oz can of diced tomatoes, and a small can of chopped green chiles because that's what I had in my pantry. I also omitted the beer because we don't drink alcohol, and used a can of chicken broth instead. Other than that, I stayed true to the recipe. My kids normally do not like chili, but they asked for seconds on this one. Thanks!
**Update : I made this again this week, and used a 28oz can of Diced tomatoes w/ green chiles, and it came out much spicier! My husband thought it was perfect, but sad for him - I'll never make it like that again. It was just too much for me and our little ones. Still great, definitely a keeper. I'll just stick to the toned-down version :)

text:
Delicious! I followed the recipe using the top taco seasoning recipe on this site, a can of Bud Light beer, and seasoned to taste a bit at the end with chili powder and garlic salt. I wanted this to be thinner like soup, so I added about 2-3 cups of chicken broth. **Update: I've made this quite a few times and always have to do some doctoring. I added a jar of enchilada sauce and got closer to what I was looking for. Finally, I followed a helpful (and odd) review to add dry ranch seasoning. It worked like a miracle! You can't even tell it's there, but it added the flavor that was missing. I will always add the ranch seasoning now.

text:
I looked over this recipe before I decided to make it to see if it was different from the one I already make. The cook time on this recipe is too long. I usually bake about 4 bone in chicken breast on 350 for about 25-30 minutes depending on the thickness. I use either home made chicken broth about  or store bought(about 1 1/2 cans) add can corn, black beans, can of mixed beans, either diced tomatoes with green peppers and onions or can of rotel tomatoes, a package of taco seasoning, and a pack of hidden valley ranch dry seasoning packet(this gives it a very good flavor.) Of course you would cook 1 chopped onion, 1 red and green bell pepper then all all other ingredients along with the shredded chicken and simmer for about 30 minutes. This soup has no end to the things you can add.

userID:
1554570
Display Name:
the4taals
isPro:
False
followersCount:
116
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
704
favoritesCount:
40
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3158466.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made a revamped version of Slow Cooker Chicken Taco Soup by RaisinKane aka Patti for Allrecipes Allstars Canada.
#ARSoupsUp #soupoftheday

This is the recipe I made:

2 onions, finely chopped
2 cans baked beans, Bush's vegetarian
2 cans black beans, drained and rinsed, PC Blue Menu no salt
1 can Del Monte Southwest corn, drained
1 can Fire Roasted Rotel
2 cups no salt tomato sauce, Hunt's
2 cups homemade chicken stock, from the chicken I roasted
1 tbsp homemade taco seasoning, no salt or sugar added
1 tsp each garlic powder, onion powder and black pepper
1 1/2 lbs shredded chicken
1 small lime, juiced

Add all the ingredients except the chicken and lime juice to a large slow cooker. Stir to combine. Cook on high for 6 hours. Add the chicken and lime juice. Stir to combine. Turn off the slow cooker and let sit for 1 hour to heat through. Serve with shredded cheese, sour cream and tortilla chips. Makes 8 to 12 servings. I usually freeze the leftovers so we can have it at a later date.

This is going to become a soup staple for me.  I especially like that the prep work is 98% opening of cans! text:
Just made it...and found it to be very much like chili, but without much complexity, flavor-wise; just very salty (even with low-sodium taco mix) and spicy (which is fine with me, I like spicy). Had to add some brown sugar to taper off the saltiness and add a bit of richness. If I made it again, I think I'd use dark beer instead of amber ale, and make my own spice mixture (ended up having to add some cumin, oregano and coriander at the end).

country:
None
text:
We loved this one; I was a little worried about the beer, but it gave the soup a great flavor. We didn't bother cooking raw chicken breasts - instead we bought and shredded the meat from two rotisserie chickens so we wouldn't have to wait all day to eat it. We also sauteed the onion in a little olive oil to brown it and soften it up. It was really delicious, and the soup has a little kick to it. We'll definitely make this one again. We topped ours with crushed baked tortilla chips and low-fat sour cream, and it was delicious.

text:
I make this over and over again whenever my freezer runs out of leftovers!  It's so good as is and the only change I've made is I use mexican style spicy tomato sauce, but it's not necessary.  It makes a ton and freezes and reheats beautifully.  I did find I need to cook the chicken a little longer before shredding (shredding it before it's fully cooked is much harder) but that's it!  Other than that it's a simple, healthy, delicious soup.

text:
We absolutely loved it! I made this chili on the stove with a few changes. I didn't have any beer and substituted with 1 c. chicken broth and used canned chicken breast that was shredded before adding to the pot. Used 1 can black beans and 1 can pinto since that was what I had on hand. The taco seasoning recipe was fabulous and will use it from now on! At the end of cooking I did add a little cornstarch w/water to slightly thicken. Great flavor and hearty meal! Total cooking time was about 1/2 hour. Thanks for sharing!

Ooooo yummy!  I made this today for the first time.  It's super super melty great.  My best suggestion: USE THE BEER.  The alcohol and 'beery' taste cooks off - it leaves the greatest flavor - truly unique.  Like others, I used two full packets of taco seasoning (4 T total), and added some cumin and chili powder.  I also added 3 huge cloves of garlic.  I used pinto beans instead of chili beans.  Other than this, I followed the recipe exactly. It's really a treat.  I will make this again for sure.

EXCELLENT! I followed the recipe as is, with the exception of substituting chicken broth for beer and using diced tomatoes WITHOUT green chiles (personal preference). Delicious and so easy! I love that you don't have to precook the chicken. Everything goes into the pot, the flavors all blend together, and you end up with a flavorful, hearty soup. I topped it with Fage (greek yogurt) instead of sour cream and crushed tortilla chips and they were the icing on the cake. I will make this again and again!

Oh num! Eating this is like being hugged! Instead of the tomatoes with chilis I used regular canned diced tomatoes and finely diced 3 jalapenos (seeds, ribs and all since they seemed mild). Turned out to be the right amount of heat for me. I also used the submitter's suggestion for the taco seasoning ("Taco Seasoning I" on this site) which was very good, but I added some extra oregano. Used the entire recipe of that seasoning (I like things highly seasoned). Otherwise kept to the recipe. Used Becks beer, kind of a pricey import but gooooood. I'll be making this often.

Both my husband and I really enjoyed this meal.  I had initially chosen it for him, as I am not a huge fan of spicy or black beans, but I liked it so much we will have it again as leftovers tonight!  The only deviations I made were as follows:  Didn't have the beer so I left it out.  Instead of packaged taco mix I used one that I made from the taco seasoning recipie on this website, it's great!!!  I added just about a tbsp. of the seasoning.  It had just enough spice for him and not too much for me.  I put everything in the crockpot at once and cooked for 4 1/2 hours, it came out perfect!!!

text:
I love the concept, and it was a hit with my Mexican roommates!  I detected this weird bitter/sour background note, which I attribute to the beer, per other reviewers.  Next time, I will use white wine or chicken stock. Also, I think there was a little too much onion, so I would chop up a smaller one.  I would also just dump in one container of salsa (reduce the liquid) instead of two, and I would add some garlic.  So, with some minor tweaking, this is an excellent crockpot dish, and I would make it again.

country:

text:
Alone, this recipe is very delicious (5 stars!), however, I added a few things the second time I made this soup and it turned out even better (worthy of 10 stars). I cooked it on high over the stove for 1.5 hours with already cooked chicken ("Boiled Chicken" recipe on this site) added a full bundle of fresh chopped cilantro, left out the chili beans, added 1/4 cup of lime juice, 1 can of diced tomatoes with green chilis, 1 bottle of beer, and used several shakes of cayenne pepper and chili powder to really bring out the heat of the soup. This recipe is such a wonderful and hearty dish, and can be modified to your liking. I don't like to measure ingredients but instead just throw things in as I go (tasting in between). Thanks a lot for this recipe -- it is definitely a keeper!

userID:
2248230
Display Name:
Leanna
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
19
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome recipe!! I'm from a family of great cooks and rarely get recipes that I end up loving from sources other than family, but this one is now in my arcenal!!  I had to change some things according to what I had on hand but I loved the end result:  I used 2 cans of white northern beans instead of black beans and chili beans and tomato juice (didn't measure...about 3 cups) instead of tomato sauce, because that's what I had.  I also used chicken stock I had frozen from previously roasting a chicken instead of beer.  And, I used some leftover green pepper, onion, and celery I had sauted the night before and had left over (that added a lot of flavor!). I used the recommended taco seasoning mixture but halved the crushed red pepper.  I only had about 4 1/2 hours instead of the recommended 7 hrs, so I did the following to speed things along:  seasoned both sides of the chicken breasts with the taco seasoning and then sauted them in a little margarine to get it going.  I then combined everything in the slow cooker and cooked on high for 4 1/2 hrs.  The meat was still tender and fell apart and had great flavor!  I like things spicy and, even with reducing the crushed red pepper flakes to 1/2 the amount, this was still just a little too spicy.  I don't mean to insult the original cook by changing the recipe so much but I had to work with what I had!  I'M SO EXCITED TO FIND THIS RECIPE!!  DELICIOUS!!
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2009-03-06T06:45:57.703

text:
This was amazing! Still eating the leftovers today for lunch. I was so sad to be full after only the first bowl! I left out the corn because I didn't want the sweetness, and I replaced the beer with a can of chicken broth. I also used a 15 oz. can of tomato sauce instead of 8 oz., and I squeezed in the juice of one lime. I also used frozen chicken breasts. Cooked on low for 3 hours, then kicked it into high for another 2 hours as I was pressed for time. Don't skimp on the sour cream and cheese...it really makes this dish!

I was very hesitant in making this soup. But it kept being recommended on the recipe exchange with rave reviews. So...I finally made it. And I was glad I did.  The only change I made was with the taco seasoning. I made my own from a recipe on this site and it made it outta sight. I also added some chopped pickled jalepeno. https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/208151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm SO pleased to write my first review for this fabulous soup!  I tried it the first time because I had everything on hand, and now I make SURE to have everything on hand because it's so full of flavor and truly could not be easier to make.  A few ideas: 1) using frozen diced onions, which I always keep on hand, makes it super-quick; 2) I love it with cheddar, sour cream, and a sprinkle of fresh cilantro over the top--the cilantro gives it more dimension; 3) if you're not a fan of beer, or would prefer not to use it, a can of chicken broth is a great substitute; and 4) I put everything in for 4 hours on high, shredded the chicken, stirred it all up, and enjoyed it right away.   Yum, yum, yum!  This is, literally, dumping cans into a crock pot, with no prep time at all, and results in a hearty, flavorful meal!

text:
I made this tonight for my family... 3 kids ranging in ages & hubby.  It was so yummy! Even my youngest who is very very picky ate it up.  It wasn't spicy in the least (although my hubby and I would have liked it spicier... but kept it mild for the kids) I used pinto beans instead of chili beans (couldn't find them here in Canada) and added a small amt of green chilies as I also couldn't find diced tomatoes with them already added.  I used chicken broth (as others had mentioned) instead of the beer.  With the sour cream, cheddar cheese and chips, it was a fun meal.  Thanks for sharing this... p.s it was my first meal in my brand new slow cooker.  Will make it for years to come, I'm sure.

text:
This has quickly become one of our favorite meals! I will admit, the first time I made it, I left out the onion and tomato sauce (didn't have any) and used chicken broth rather than the beer - we loved it so much that way that we keep making it the same. I used chicken breast tenders and it works wonderfully (don't need the extra step of shredding and continuing to cook for 2 hours - we just shred it in the crockpot right at the end). We use mild chili beans and mild Rotel tomatoes w/chilies and it still has plenty of zip! Yum yum!

Mine gets thicker when it goes in the fridge, so leftovers are perfect on top of a salad.

text:
This is one of those rare recipes that is just perfect the way it is. I also love that it's so simple and easy--the only "work" part is dicing the onion.  I have made it both in the slow cooker and--when I decided to make it last minute--on the stovetop (and still turns out just as good).  I like the beer in it, but only use about half a can (mostly so my kids don't freak) and eyeball some chicken broth so that it's a little more soupy than stew-y. I also use the taco seasoning I recipe.  Don't forget the cheese and sour cream--it finishes it off nicely!  Thanks for the great recipe.

This recipe was very good. I've never done a taco type soup before so I decided to give this a shot. I didn't have some ingredients on hand, so I just used two cans of black beans, one can of regular diced tomatoes and a full can of tomato sauce. I also didn't have the seasonings on hand (except for taco seasoning) and this recipe was still delicious. I added garlic powder, salt, and red pepper flakes and it was very, very good. However, I do think the beer gave it a bit of a bitter taste, but I hate beer anyway. May try the chicken broth next time, but my husband LOVED it the way it was. Highly recommend serving with cheese and crushed taco shells/chips and any other dressings  you see fit. delicious

text:
I made this recipe yesterday.  I couldn't find diced tomatoes with green chilies so I used canned stewed tomatoes and a separate can of chopped green chilies.  I also used low sodium tomato sauce and taco seasoning to keep the salt to a minimum.  Next time I'll make the taco seasoning recommended but it was delicious this way too.  I topped it with some low fat sour cream and grated cheese and it added a lot of flavour.  Great recipe for this freezing cold weather and healthy too.  Thanks very much.

Wonderful flavor! I only made a few minor changes. I used frozen fajita style chicken, changed the tomato sauce to 1 28oz can crushed tomatos, and a 28oz can whole kernel corn not drained. Other than that left recipe as is. I used a bottle of Miller Lite. The beer is a must for flavor. Does not taste like beer at all but everything comes together to make a great tasting soup/chili flavor.Have Texas Pete, cheese and corn chips on hand to serve. Mmmmm Will make again and again. Thanks for the recipe!!

text:
WOnderful, very very easy recipe that is very healthy too.  I would recommend substituting chicken broth for beer.  I also had to sub out canned tomatoes with chilies (too spicy for my boys)with reg toms and used pinto beans instead of chili beans - you can control the quality of the flavor better.  You can sub tomato paste and water for the can tomato sauce depending on what you have on hand.  Recipe makes almost a double batch - which is a bonus as this recipe freezes well.

This is pretty good but didn't 'wow' me. I prefer another taco soup recipe on this site as far as taste, but I do like the ease of the slow cooker.  I used Bill Echol's Taco Seasoning I from this site. I used mexicorn, one can of mexican stewed tomatoes and one can of diced tomatoes and added a tablespoon of chopped jalepenos.  I didn't have any tomato sauce so I used a can of tomato soup plus 1/2 can of water. I cooked it on low for 5 hours, shredded the chicken and put it back as directed, then turned it on warm all night.

text:
Second try w/ this recipe.  This time I only used one 10 oz can of the Rotel brand green chiles/diced tomates and  did not use any tomato sauce.  But . . . I added another small can of green chiles, again, sans the diced tomatoes.   I thought it was a lot better this time -- it has a little kick, but it's good.  Last time it was way too acidic, too tomato-y, we're not huge tomato fans here.  I also used 2 cans of 99% f/free MSG/free chicken broth instead of beer which worked well.  Replaced the chili beans w/ pinto beans, which I also liked better.   Also used a MSG free taco seasoning.    Next time I'm going to go bold and use the beer instead of chicken broth.

text:
I made this for a cousin's get together weekend and everyone loved it and asked for the recipe. I did use the home made taco seasoning as recommended by the poster and substituted a 28 oz can of diced tomatoes and 1 small can of chilies for the 2 10 oz cans of diced tom w/chilies and used a can of pinto beans not chili beans. I cooked overnight shredded the chicken the next morning turned it off for a couple hours thanback on an hour before serving. It was just spicy enough and I will be making it again very soon,  Very easy!!
just another note, I have made this with beer and with chicken broth  I think the flavor is far superior using the beer!!

I didn't want to wait so didn't do the slow cooker method. I boiled my chicken in water with garlic, pepper, and hot salt. While cooking, I put other ingrediants in pot except chili beans and beer (used chicken broth instead). I also added a can of green chile enchilada sauce.  My hubbie gave it a 4 saying it had too much chicken (he'd rather eat beef) and not "soupy" enough. I gave it a 5 because it was the perfect amount of heat - left some fire in your mouth but not your stomach plus it was ready to eat in under 30 minutes.

text:
Wow, this is super good.  I did follow the suggestion of one reviewer and made my taco seasoning, here is what I did. 1 tablespoon chili powder 1/4 teaspoon garlic powder 1/4 teaspoon onion powder 1/4 teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes 1/4 teaspoon dried oregano 1/2 teaspoon paprika 1 1/2 teaspoons ground cumin 1 teaspoon sea salt 1 teaspoon black pepper.  I added cheese but did not do the tortilla chips, who needs to mess with perfection.

This was a great, easy recipe that I'll make again.  My changes were: 2 cans of 14.5 oz Red Gold diced Tomatoes with Chipotle, 1 an (4 oz) green chilis, 5 small chicken breasts.  I used Yuengling lager & the flavor was awesome, but our kids didn't like it that much. Leftovers were very, very tangy, still good, but next time I might leave out the green chili's.  This would be a great super bowl party recipe as it's more like chili than soup.

text:
This is a great and easy recipe - especially for a group.  I made a few minor changes - I did not use the beer, but added a can of chicken broth.  I also added a little bit of additional cumin (app. 1-2 tsp.).  The soup was looking a little thin for my taste, so I also added a small box of Velveeta - this made it the absolute perfect consistency and also a wonderful cheesy flavor without being overdone.  Definitely a keeper!

text:
Yummo! This was great! and per suggestions made Bill Echols taco seasoning. I was worried because it looked so super watery but once the chicken was shredded it really thickened up. I also used tongs to "tear/shred" the chicken. I have a large family so I used 1 can each of chili beans, northern beans and black beans and 2 cans of corn all drained. I used the beer, was worried about that too but it came out pretty good. Will definitely add this to my rotation. FYI I started this a little later in the day than I had planned and my chicken was frozen -so I cooked this on High for 6 hours.

This was one of the best tasting meal I have made in the crockpot!
I made just a couple of changes however.
I added two 15oz. cans of red enchilada sauce and 1 15 oz. can(instead of 8 oz.) of tomato sauce in place of the can of chopped tomatoes and chilis. All chili beans, no black beans. All changes were just personal preferences.
Made some corn bread to go with it and voila,deelish!

text:
This recipe is awesome! I changed up the ingrediants just a bit to use stuff I already had on hand. I use fajita style chicken strips, 1 can tomatoes with green chiles, 1 can regualr diced toamtoes and chili beans with hot sauce. Kept the rest of the ingrediants the same. It was still plenty spicey. Let it cook on high for 2 hours and then on low for 2. My whole family enjoyed this. I will definitely be making this again!

For those who are on Weight Watchers, I plugged this recipe in and it came out only 6 PointsPlus per serving.  The best part is, except for the beer and taco seasoning, all the ingredients are power foods!!!  I made this soup exactly as directed and it was fabulous.  We had it for dinner one night and was so good I decided to use it as the appetizer for my cookout the next night.  It was a huge hit.  The best part about this soup is that it couldn't be any easier to make. For those worried about the beer, the alcohol cooks off and you can't really taste the beer.....

Got rave reviews when I made this last night.
Changes I made:
* used chicken thighs for more flavor in the meat
* added masa flour to thicken the soup
* added veggies: mushrooms, zucchini
* sauteed veggies and onions and garlic before putting in to add more flavor
* added lime juice towards the end

Will definitely make this again.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This taco soup is so easy to prepare and so delicious that it's impossible not to give it a 5 star rating! I followed the recipe exactly, and I let it cook in the slow cooker all day. The meat shredded with ease, as well. I topped each bowl with a little shredded cheddar cheese and a dollop of sourcream, as suggested, and that added a slight creaminess to the more brothy soup. This recipe makes enough for plenty of leftovers - it's a filling soup - which were eaten readily in my house. Although I think this recipe is perfection, it's also a flexible recipe that others can tweek to their liking. Also, I used packaged taco seasoning for my first time, but I will definitely try 'Bill Echols taco seasoning' that is listed on this site, below this soup recipe. Thanks Patti Kane for sharing this tasty soup!

text:
I made this for dinner tonight and everyone absolutely loved it.  My husband has been wanting me to make taco soup and I couldn't have found a better recipe.  I do have some left overs and I think I will make some cornbread to go with that tomorrow.  I only made a few slight changes.  I had three very large baked, boneless, skinless chicken breast halves left over from something else that I used.  I just shredded them and added them in for the last two hours of cooking which cut my cooking time down to 5 hrs.  This was also plenty of chicken for us.  The tortilla chips, cheese, and sour cream added to the bowl at the end make it absolutely perfect!  Thanks for such a great recipe!!  It is definitely a KEEPER!

text:
Yummmo!  This soup is delicious!  I did not have time to do it in a slow cooker so I did it on the stove top in about 3 hours.  I first seared the breasts in a pot and then covered them with the other ingredients until it boiled and then turned it way down and let it simmer.  I did not use beer and instead used two can of broth and it still turned out fabulous.  I added some cilantro to the soup during the last 10 minutes for a fresh taste.  The family loved it!!!

This recipe is fantastic1 I'll definately make it again. I would categorize this as more of a chili. I love the addition of corn! If you like it a little thiner, like me, you can add some vegetable stock...I used some homemade that I had on hand. Garnish is a must. Crushed tortilla chips, sour cream, shredded cheddar, chopped fresh cilantro, Cholula (or other hot sauce). 
My favorite part of this recipe is how incredibly fast and easy it is!

userID:
2825861
Display Name:
lisa-dc
isPro:

0

0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is not a gourmet recipe, but it is simple to make and tastes delicious.  I add 2 tablespoons of Bill Echols' taco seasoning to the crockpot, and I use another 2 teaspoons on the onions (which I saute in olive oil, along with 2-3 cloves of freshly minced garlic, until soft).

As for liquid, make sure you drain the beans or the finished product will be too liquidy.  I've experimented with several kinds of beer and have found that Amstel light adds just the right depth without being overwhelming.

I've found that I can shave 1.5 hours off the total cooking time by shredding the chicken after 4 hours (vs. 5) and then cooking for an additional 1.5 hours (vs. 2).

Thanks for the great recipe!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-02-24T08:56:53.953
helpfulCount:
0

text:
This was very tasty and great, but a little too spicy for my taste.  My kids wouldn't eat it b/c it was too spicy. I would suggest cutting using the mild Rotel tomatoes, (and if using the seasoning mixture instead of a taco seasing packet) - 1/2 of the pepper suggested and skip the crushed red hot pepper.

I also used a can of chicken stock and can of cream of chicken soup instead of the beer, and a litle bit of Velveeta cheese to have a thicker consistancy like stew.

This recipe is a keep though!  Yum!

text:
Fabulous!  I added in 1/3 cup of onion instead of a whole onion, and added in about 5 oz of corn instead of a 15 oz can (that's a lot of corn!).  The only other change I made was just before serving: remove about 3 Tbl of soup liquid into a bowl and add in 1.5 tsp corn starch.  Add back into soup to thicken it up just a little.  Both my husband I loved this recipe, and I'll be making it again!  Thanks for sharing!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1992890.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I didn't think this was as fabulous as some of the reviewers, but it was very good and we will difinitely be making it again.  I made a few changes and will change one more thing next time.  The changes I made were to put in my own seasonings instead of the packet, make 1.5 C each of cooked black beans and pinto beans instead of the canned beans, blend the tomatoes before putting them into the soup (we don't like tomato chunks), add three pressed cloves of garlic (might add more next time), and use 6oz turkey stock plus 6oz beer instead of 12oz beer.  The only thing that we didn't like about the recipe was the onions, they weren't cooked enough when the soup was done and my husband thought there were too many.  So next time i will use 1/2 an onion and saute it a bit first.  I will also only use 2 chicken breasts next time, there was a TON of chicken!  I might further increase the amount of beans and decrease the chicken to save money.  But over all really good recipe!  And so easy!

I made a few adjustments as well.  At the end of cooking, I added a little chili powder and some brown sugar.  I wanted it to taste a little richer.  Also, next time I will try to substitute chix broth for the beer.  The beer taste threw me for a loop.  Guests raved about the soup though. It was a little spicy for my kids.  I will for surely make this again and would recommend it.  It's easy and yummy!

text:
This one is always a crowd pleaser and so easy.  It is easily my best crock pot recipe and I have tried a lot of crock pot recipes.  It is flavorful, weight watcher friendly and ridiculously easy to prepare. I always use fat free chicken broth in the place of the beer but otherwise stick with the original recipe.  It is great because nothing has to be cooked ahead of time and the only thing that needs chopping is the onion.  It takes minutes to put together and my 2 and 5 year old love to help me dump the cans into the slow cooker.  Even my very picky mother in law enjoyed it and actually asked for the recipe!

text:
Loved this recipe!  I made it 5 days ago and I had the last bowl for lunch today.  I have to say it got better every day!  I did hae to make a few changes as I didn't have exactly what the recipe called for.  I had plain old diced tomatoes, no chili beans but Chili starter in a can with chili beans.  I used frozen corn and very little onion.  I started out using a whole can of Bud Lite, thinking since it's a light beer it wouldn't overpower the soup.  For my taste it still was too strong so I added a whole 14.5 oz can of Chicken broth on top of the beer.  It really helped tone down the taste of the beer. I was fraid the soup would be too think but it wasn't at all.  THe soup is definitely a keeper, I plan to make it all winter long!!!  Thanks for sharing!

Easy, inexpensive, healthy, and most of all delicious! I used a cut up chicken which I stewed and shredded. I added 1/2 a tsp. of salt, about 8 ounces of the broth I cooked the chicken in, and 2 tbls chopped cilantro after cooking was complete. I wouldn't skip the beer, it really added to the recipe. All 9 people I fed it to enjoyed it! Thanks so much for a great recipe!

userID:

Display Name:
Dianna S

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family and I love this recipe!!! I make it on a regular basis now and everyone gobbles it all up every time! I also definately recommend using Bill Echols taco seasoning found on this site. The variations I use in this recipe are: adding a whole can of chicken broth and only 1/2 - 3/4 bottle of beer, 2 tsp minced onion instead of a chopped onion (my husband is not a big onion fan), use 3 fully cooked shredded or cubed chicken breasts and I cook it on the stove top for 45 min to an hour. We also serve it over some white rice and add shredded cheese, sour cream, chopped avocado & fresh cilantro on top. This is a very filling meal and the flavors are magnificent (even as left-overs)!

This recipe was amazing, and my whole family loved it.  A little tip thought, if you or someone in your family isn't huge on really spicy food, substitute at least one of the cans of diced tomatoes with green chiles for just a can of diced tomatoes alone.  It was a bit too spicy for our tastes, which honestly could have less to do with the chiles and more to do with the brand of taco seasoning.  But yea, a great recipe.

text:
This was awesome!  I made a couple of adjustments purely out of what I did and didn't have on hand.  Left out the chili beans and the beer, used two packages of McCormick Taco Seasoning and added 2 cloves of minced garlic to the soup.  Also used 5 breasts as opposed to 3 and it can be eaten as a thick stew or even rolled up in flour tortillas!  I served it with the above extras as well as some fresh avocado and lime - this is a big hit in my house and everyone who tries it wants the recipe!

Okay, this was great, I really really liked it.  The youngsters found it to be too spicey, even though I only used the "chunky" rotel tomatoes.  My hubby, who loathes soups, was extremely happy to strain off the broth and chow down on the "real" food.  I believe he even had thirds, which is pretty amazing. text:
My family LOVED this.  Hubby took the leftovers in his lunch and had to share with the guys at work!  I didn't make in the slow cooker because I decided late to make this.  So here's what I did.  I seasoned my chicken with salt, pepper, and garlic powder and roasted in the oven until cooked through.  Then diced and added to the other ingredients that I had already started simmering on the stove.  I did use chicken broth in place of the beer.  Next time, hubby (who is Mexican-American) asked that I use hominy in place of the corn, and pinto beans in place of the chili beans.  We loved this recipe!

Extremely tasty and easy too! Hard to ask for a better soup recipe! A wonderful combination of flavors and easily adjustable if you want to add more heat, as I did. Don't bother trying this on HIGH, just set your crock pot on LOW and let it cook 8-10 hours. The soup tastes better the longer it cooks and it makes your entire house smell great! Served it with tortilla chips to crush on top... will make this one again for sure!

Then, right before going to bed, I thought about what I'd be making for dinner the following night.  Thinking "taco soup", I promptly took some ground beef out of the freezer and put IT in the fridge too.  So...I used both in the soup, and it was great!  I loaded up on the spices and added some garlic and Tapatio.  It had just the right amount of heat for all of us.  I served it over tortilla chips, adding sour cream, cilantro and cheese to the top.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was really tasty. The kids loved it! I didn't have chili beans, so I used a can of pinto beans and added half of an envelope of dry chili mix. I used a 14 oz. can of diced tomatoes and a 4 oz. can of green chilies instead of the combination of the two in one can only because I didn't have it. I also added half a can of water because my mixture looked almost too thick and the water seemed to make it the perfect consistency.  I used about 8-9 frozen boneless, skinless chicken tenderloins (Costco) and placed them on top of the mixture as the recipe states. I will be making this one again!

text:
This is a very tasty recipe. I made it at my house and all the neighbor kids happened to come over and they loved it.  I then made it for a church function and people wanted more more more!  I would not recommend leaving out the beer as some  of the other reviews have stated.  The alchohol helps tenderize the chicken (cooking it for a long time does that also).  I would recommend using a decent beer with good flavor though (I used Stevens Point Amber--inexepensive and tasty).

WOW!!!  This was PHENOMENAL!!!  Easy to make and DELICIOUS!!!  I made dinner for my boyfriend and I last night.  I served this soup with "Absolute Mexican Cornbread".  YUM!!!  I made this recipe exactly as stated EXCEPT I added a half-can of green chiles AND a half-can of jalepeno peppers. I did not service with chips or sour cream to save on the calories, and it was still fantastic!

userID:
918694
Display Name:
PLAYKITTENPIE
isPro:
False
followersCount:
13
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
26
favoritesCount:
395
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3714.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So simple and delicious! I had to substitute a few ingredients, as our small grocer didn't carry some things. I used kidney beans instead of chilli beans. I used Sprite instead of beer. I used plain-diced tomatoes and a separate can of green chillies. I also used a bit more seasoning.   One reviewer had said that someone had to be home to shred the chicken and another had said to precook and shred the chicken first but neither is necessary.  When I made it, I followed the directions but had to leave it over night to cook (about 10 hours).  I shredded the chicken right before I served it, mixed it in and it was perfect! I topped it with chips, cheese, sour cream and (my most favourite addition) a sprinkling of fresh cilantro. The next day I used it as a burrito filling, that was yummy too.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2005-12-12T18:36:58.433
helpfulCount:
0

I followed the recipe exact, except that I used a whole chicken – the flavor was out of this world! text:
Very easy to make.  Very healthy.  One problem I had was that I used homemade taco seasoning (Bill Echols from this site) and for me it was too spicy.  Will make again with packaged seasoning.  Also I expected more of a chili consistency and it was more soupy.  When I make it again, I will cut out some liquid, perhaps less beer and I will drain the tomatoes.  Overall a good soup for a cold day!
